PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Sir Condor Laucke) took the chair at 10.30 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MULVIHILL; GIETZELT

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 68 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the National Women's Advisory Council is representative of the views, needs, and aspirations of the majority of Australian women.

That the draft plan prepared by the National Women's Advisory Council to promote discussion on the mid-term United Nations Decade for Women is a statement of principle to be considered by women, and when completed, presented for consideration and adoption by the Australian Parliament.
It is our wish that the Government recognise the value and importance of the role of the N.W.A. Council, in what it has to offer to both Women and the Australian Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MULVIHILL; GIETZELT

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 80 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. A petition of the undersigned citizens, residents within the Federal electorate of Barton, respectfully showeth:
Our dismay at the reductions in the total expenditure implemented in 1980 and proposed for 1981 and in particular on government schools and colleges.

Our concern at the immediate and long-term effects such reductions are having, and will have, upon the educational needs and welfare of the children and students within public schools, Technical and Further Education Colleges, Colleges of Advanced Education and Universities.

Our further concern that education, which is a major element in the public sector of the Australian economy, has been consistently down-graded from a position of importance in the development of the national economy as a whole.

Our affirmation that Australia's own development depends upon the development of its most important natural resource, our children, and that education must be restored to a position of major priority for this task by this and all future Federal Governments.
We call upon the Federal Government to immediately restore and increase substantially its allocation of resources to education in government schools and colleges in order to achieve these ends.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
The Clerk-A petition has been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Deregulation of Trading Hours
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned respectively showeth:
1. That we wish to express our strongest opposition to any deregulation of trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory.

2. Past performances have proven that longer trading hours do not lead to increased sales. However, they do increase costs, because shops have to be staffed for longer periods. To cover these increased costs, retailers are forced to increase prices and reduce staff levels. This means that longer trading hours increase both prices and unemployment.
3. There is no real consumer demand for longer trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory.
4. The deregulation of trading hours would force small Retail Companies out of business.
5. Extended trading hours would gravely disrupt weekend recreation and family life of shop assistants.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Stop the deregulation of retail trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory by disallowing the Ordinance which amends the Trading Hours Ordinance, 1962.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, 12 sitting days after today, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance 1981, as contained in Australian Capital Territory Ordinance No. 9 of 1981, and made under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910, be disallowed, on the grounds that:
(a) The Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances has found that the Ordinance does unduly trespass on the rights and liberties of citizens;
(b) The Minister for the Capital Territory has given an undertaking that the Ordinance will be replaced before Anzac Day 1982; and
(c) The Ordinance is selective in its operation, having effect only in relation to Anzac Day marches.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Leader of the Government in the Senate received any complaints from members of the National Country Party about the activities of the Government Information Unit as a result of disclosures in the Federal Parliament? Has the National Country Party expressed its concern that members of the Unit are working exclusively for the Liberal Party? Has it said that, if the Unit's functions are to engage in partisan political activity at the taxpayers' expense, part of that activity should be directed towards helping the National Country Party as well?
—The answer to the three parts of the question is no.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, is prompted by the homilies we received late last night from Senator Chaney in relation to rank and file rights in trade unions. I put this to the Minister: Quite frankly, does he not think, because of what his party believes in, that we should have an equivalent injection of rank and file rights for members of private hospital funds and not have gauleiters like Cade and others who are elected under a collegiate system rather than by the rank and file subscribers?

—I am delighted by Senator Mulvihill's frankness and by his allusions to last night's quite wide-ranging debate. I think the main issue affecting the establishment and operation of health insurance funds in Australia-I take it that is what the honourable senator is referring to-is that they should bring to the subscribers the benefits which the Government is seeking. Those benefits are security, certainty and a wide coverage.
—And decision making.

—The honourable senator says 'and decision making', but it is the benefits to the consumers that concern this Government, as they concern this Government in so many areas. The operations of the funds should be directed to that end, and to that end only.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. In view of the dependence on the telephone of certain groups in society, including invalids, in the event of emergency or hospital needs, and because of the increasing difficulties associated with the use of the telephone system, can the Minister advise the Senate what measures, if any, the Government will take to prevent a complete collapse of the telephone system?

—What it will take to prevent a collapse of the system is, of course, an early resolution of the dispute on fair and just terms, and the Government is trying to do its part to facilitate that. However, the honourable senator asked a particular question concerning the capacity of those who depend upon such communications, particularly invalids, hospitals and others. I think within the last week I indicated, in referring to this matter in answer to a question, that the unions had made it clear that the life and limb provision was one they wished to cover. I think all Australians would want to see that those who are dependent upon telecommunications in a particular way, the kind of people Senator Watson has referred to, are not disadvantaged by any union action.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Minister for National Development and Energy that, when Senator Button asked him on 14 May to account for the far more optimistic Rundle assessment in his Press release of 2 February than appeared in the National Energy Advisory Committee report which that Press release accompanied, he said it was due to a typographical error. Later he supported that claim by quoting from a letter written to the Australian Financial Review by his departmental head. Was his departmental head present on 2 February when he, that is Senator Carrick, gave this different and conflicting explanation? Senator Carrick, in reply to a question asked at the Press conference, said:

QUESTION.PARA: I don't think there is any significant difference between us-moderate to good and good are of a reasonable judgment, a reasonable parallel of judgment. What we do know is that the Rundle developers say that they will-and they are people who-and that is the partners and Exxon, say they will produce 18 to 20 thousand barrels a day by 1984 and that they hope to produce 240 thousand barrels a day by 1988 so that's 8 to 10 years on our calculation is a reasonable one.

That, of course, backs up the Press statement and not the NEAC report. Also, I observe in passing, that conflicts with the International Energy Agency draft report which had been prepared several months before. If Senator Carrick's departmental head was present, why did he not draw Senator Carrick's attention to what both he-the departmental head-and Senator Carrick now claim was a typographical error and instead allow Senator Carrick to continue misleading the Press and the Stock Exchange about the Rundle project?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —If 2 February is the date when I held a Press conference, it is likely that the permanent head of my Department was present. I do not know, but that is easily established. It is likely that he was present. The facts are established, and I take it that it is accepted by the Senate, because a permanent head of a department has said this, that what happened was not any attempt to mislead anyone but a typographical error by some--
—Why didn't he say so then? That is the question.
—Mr President--
—Why did he allow you to go on talking up the shares?
—Order! The Minister is responding.

—If, indeed, Senator Walsh continues to interject in this place, I have the opportunity to decide not to give him an answer. If he wants a factual answer, he will treat the Senate with courtesy, because when answering questions I propose to treat him in a manner consistent with his own courtesy. I mean that quite clearly. Having said that, I will proceed. The fact of the matter is that the departmental head has said that what happened was that in a table attached to a document which was handed out a typographical error occurred in the Department. I do not think that anyone will say that is an inaccuracy. I take it that people accept the departmental head's situation. It so happens that neither he nor I had looked to check the fact. We just assumed that the typist or the officer concerned had repeated the table. Of course, it certainly was not obvious to me upon that occasion. Why this matter is persisted with I do not know, because it sadly draws attention to what can happen to any human being in the Public Service-that is, a public servant, like any other person, is capable of making an error. If Senator Walsh wants to do that, be that upon him.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the International Energy Agency report, we will wait until it comes out to see what it says about shale. I have the instinct that the IEA is likely to draw attention to oil from shale as being one of the most cost effective ways of getting alternative fuels for the future. But we will wait and we will see about that. The continual repetition by Senator Walsh about my having talked up share prices may be interesting rhetoric for him, but it will again cause me to remind the public, him and the Senate of these facts: The shares in the Rundle partnership have been shown in Hansard to have halved in value between October-November of last year and the time immediately prior to my going to Rundle. In fact it was quite clear that the people who held shares had views that the Rundle shares ought not to be valued at that price. The shares were going down, and halved in value. The effect of my going to Rundle was fractional.

TALK.START.PARA: —The insider traders were getting out of them.

—Senator Walsh fails to understand that the Australian Financial Review ran an article, resulting from a speech by me in this place, saying that I was very cautious, or indeed offering a cautious warning on Rundle. How honourable senators can say that a Minister, who was quoted in the Australian Financial Review as urging caution on Rundle, is talking up shares defeats me. Also the indications were quite otherwise. I am asked why the permanent head did not draw my attention to the error at that time. I take it that he did not do so because he had made the same assumption as I, that is, that in the typing the transposition was of the table from the NEAC report. I must say one fundamental thing when the question is asked why my Department and I took a cautiously more optimistic view than NEAC. The NEAC report had been prepared some four or five months before. In the intervening four or five months, circumstances in terms of available energy changed and we made our assessment on that basis.

—I ask a supplementary question. The Minister in his answer has referred to an Australian Financial Review article, I think on 2 February 1980, which I believe was headed 'Carrick casts doubts on Rundle'. I am not certain of the date. Is it not a fact that the day that article was published the Minister's staff complained to the Australian Financial Review staff in Canberra that that article had misrepresented or misinterpreted his statement and cast a pall of doom on the Rundle prospect?
—I leave the histrionics, the rhetoric and the theatre to--
—Just answer the question. Did your staff complain that you had been misrepresented?
—Order!
—In terms of what I have said, the supplementary question deserves no answer. I will not be shouted at or interjected on just for theatre in this place.
—Nor will you tell the truth.
—Mr President, I ask for that interjection to be withdrawn.
—Order! That is a reflection on the Minister and it must be withdrawn-'telling lies'.

—I am not saying that the Minister is telling lies. I am saying that he will not tell the truth. There is a difference. He will not give an answer to the question. He will not tell the Senate whether his staff visited the Australian Financial Review office and complained that that article, which he now clings to like a life raft, in fact misrepresented or misinterpreted the statement he had made. The Minister will not give an answer, whether it is truthful or otherwise, and therefore he will not tell the truth.
—The inference was that the Minister was lying. Withdraw.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. With respect, I do not see how that inference can be drawn. Senator Carrick was asked a supplementary question and he declined to answer it, for reasons which I concede may be quite legitimate in the cut and thrust of debate in this place. The allegation was 'Nor will you tell the truth' in response to what the Minister said, which was: 'I will not answer that question'. That is not an allegation of lying in any way. It is an allegation that the Minister prefers to remain silent, and that is all it can be said to amount to.
—Mr President, on the point of order: It infers that I would be willing to tell lies.
—That is your guilt. You do that every day.
—With respect, it does not do that.
—I take a point of order on that interjection: 'You do that every day'.
—I am listening. That compounds the situation. Senator Walsh, withdraw. It is too early in the morning to get into this sort of argument.

—If Senator Carrick chooses to interpret my statement as an allegation that he was telling lies, I will withdraw. No such allegation was made, however. The plain fact is that he refuses to answer the question and, therefore, he does refuse to tell the truth. But I withdraw an imputation that he was telling lies. He was not telling lies because he will not give any answer at all.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Any time that Senator Walsh asks me a question and allows an answer, I will give him a courteous and factual answer. It has nothing to do with my unwillingness to state the facts of the matter. It is to do with my reaction to behaviour which I think is extremely unparliamentary and does nothing to add to the decorum of this chamber.
—Order! Let us all bear in mind that the extending of courtesies is necessary in this place for the easy and pleasurable conduct of the proceedings.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: EDUCATION AND TRAINING IN SMALL BUSINESS

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Education. On 5 December 1980 I asked a question concerning education and training in small business. I was subsequently advised that an inquiry into management education had been established. Can the Minister confirm whether the inquiry has begun? If so, when will it be completed? Can the Minister say whether any early or interim conclusions or trends have yet become evident?

—As to the first part of Senator Archer's question, I can confirm that the inquiry has commenced. Indeed, I can confirm that the inquiry has received something like 200 submissions to date. The committee was established under the Tertiary Education Commission Act to examine the availability and effectiveness of courses in management education for middle and top management. The inquiry is also paying attention to the special needs of small businesses in relation to management education. The terms of reference and the membership of the committee of inquiry were announced by the responsible Minister on 22 April 1980. The report of the inquiry is expected to be available by the end of this year and will contain recommendations on ways in which to improve the availability and effectiveness of education for small business. It is a significant inquiry.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Defence aware of controversy in the United Kingdom as to the future of the $400m aircraft carrier Ark Royal, launched this week by the Queen Mother? Although the British Defence Minister says that Ark Royal will be completed as planned, speculation continues about the ship being converted to serve other purposes, mothballed or even scrapped. Does the Minister not foresee a similar controversial destiny for the Australian aircraft carrier now planned, because of the increasingly obsolescent nature of this class of vessel? In what way can a single aircraft carrier adequately protect the Australian coastline while at the same time requiring considerable periods out of duty for maintenance and refit? Why is the Government persisting with plans for this largely useless vessel, at a cost of at least $700m, when that sum could provide a complete flotilla of modern attack craft, such as the United States Pegasus class vessels, which are hydrofoil vessels, which can attack at 60 miles an hour and which have the very considerable strike capability of eight Harpoon missiles to each vessel?

—I did hear of the program to which Senator Mason has referred. I can inform the Senate that an examination is at present continuing in the Department of Defence of the type of seaborne aircraft platform that the Government might decide to acquire in the future for the Royal Australian Navy. That matter is being examined. The Government has believed that a purpose built ship would be better able to carry out tasks envisaged for it than other types of vessel. However, the view it has held will be examined. The matter has not been finalised. I will refer the other matters that Senator Mason has raised to the Minister for Defence and ask him to provide a more detailed reply for Senator Mason.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Attorney-General aware of the advertisement in the Australian Financial Review of 27 May headed 'How to Dodge the New Anti-Dodging Laws ! ! !', authorised by Peter Clyne of Elizabeth Bay Road, Sydney? In part, the advertisement reads:

QUESTION.PARA: While John Howard is working on his poison, I'm working on the antidote and a blueprint on how to get around the new law . . . will be presented at a seminar to be held in about six weeks' time. Only 400 bookings will be accepted, and the blueprint will be made available only to those who attend the seminar.

The cost to each individual will be $500. Would the Minister agree that this advertisement, in soliciting a total of $200,000 as payment for tax avoidance advice, would be in breach of the new Act and also constitute an incitement to others to break the new Act once it becomes law?

TALK.START.PARA: —Opinions may not be sought from Ministers. I call the Attorney.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walters has drawn my attention to the advertisement in the Australian Financial Review on 27 May. It probably would be instructive for all honourable senators to look at it, if they have not already done so because--
—What? Do you want us to contribute?

—No, I do not, but I think it is important to know about the matter because in the near future we will debate some very important laws on this subject. I think it is probably as well for us to understand the sort of people with whom the Government and the Parliament are contending when dealing with this tax avoidance industry that has mushroomed in recent years. I hesitate to put Mr Clyne in the same category as a number of the people who are in the tax avoidance industry because he seems to have embarked upon an altogether more serious and heinous form of campaign. Nevertheless, it is a serious matter that we should bear in mind in the Senate.

ANSWER.PARA: On the wider issue, Senator Young asked me a question about some other statements which Mr Clyne made the other day. Senator Young's question is much the same as the question asked by Senator Walters. The answer that I would give would be much the same as I gave to Senator Young. I pointed out then that although there is a technical legal distinction between artificial schemes of tax avoidance and out and out tax evasion, nevertheless, the distinction, even as a legal distinction, is becoming pretty blurred. Certainly morally it is completely blurred. As I have said, a new word has been coined which represents it much more accurately, namely, tax evoision. Of course this is a problem that the Government has tackled and tackled vigorously. The new laws that have been proposed to the Parliament to deal with it will, we believe, have a very major impact in rectifying this very serious state of affairs which has arisen.

I point out to anybody who is contemplating taking the sort of advice that Mr Clyne or others may give, that he has to bear in mind that if that advice proves to be incorrect and the schemes are struck down under the new laws, there will be some very heavy penalties that the taxpayer will have to face. However, Senator Walters asks a wider question about what can be done in relation to somebody such as Mr Clyne and the sorts of advertisements that he has made. The President has quite rightly pointed out to me that that would be seeking a legal opinion, but more particularly I think it is not an appropriate matter for me-on the basis of an advertisement-to express any opinion without giving the matter further consideration. I propose to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Attorney-General and refer to recent newspaper revelations that Document J of the Petrov royal commission contained allegations that a Minister of the Australian Government had given the Japanese Government three months' notice, shortly before the outbreak of World War II, that its funds in Australia would be frozen. Will the Minister remove the cloud that now hangs over all the wartime members of that Ministry by naming the Minister concerned? Failing that, will he table Document J in the Senate?
—I ask Senator McLaren to put that question on the Notice Paper.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, refers to the upgrading of Adelaide Airport to receive international flights. I ask the Minister whether he is aware that at a meeting of tourism Ministers in Canberra two weeks ago, the Ministers gave complete backing to the Adelaide Airport case and that Mrs Adamson, the South Australian Minister for Tourism, said:

QUESTION.PARA: It is unusual-to say the least-for all States and the Northern Territory to unite in their support for one State in making a case to the Federal Government.

I understand that there is to be a meeting tomorrow between the Commonwealth Minister for Transport and the South Australian Minister for Transport, Mr Michael Wilson; so I ask: Can the Minister now confirm that the urgings that I and other South Australian senators have made over many months will tomorrow be brought to a point of decision and that the detailed plan for upgrading Adelaide Airport will soon be announced?

TALK.START.PARA: —I, like Senator Teague and a number of other South Australian senators, have a particular interest in the Adelaide Airport development. Indeed, discussions are to take place tomorrow, as I understand it. I have no information as to what point the Government has reached in deciding whether a plan is yet firm enough to be put into action, but I understand that the Government is hopeful that this matter will be put into place as rapidly as possible. I cannot indicate to the honourable senator when that might be but I will seek information from the Minister for Transport for him.
—I direct a question to the Minister for Social Security. Is there any truth in the rumours, repeated almost weekly in the ethnic Press, that the Government intends to scrap portable pensions?

—There is no basis in fact for that rumour. The position is, as I think Senator Grimes would be aware, that a number of countries have raised with Australia the matter of reciprocal agreements and the consideration of the various factors which affect people who migrate to this country and who emigrate from this country or who come to this country perhaps on a permanent basis and who return to their country of origin. There are a number of areas which are regarded as unsatisfactory and on which there have been some discussions. The general area of reciprocal agreements is a matter which is under consideration within my Department and, in due course, will be under consideration by the Government. But there is no proposal before the Government to restrict existing rights of portability.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction noted an article in today's Daily Telegraph under the title 'Our Rate of Home Ownership is Rising'? The article states that home ownership in Australia has reached 71.9 per cent compared with 49 per cent in 1949. Can the Minister provide the Senate with the figures of home ownership in other Western countries for the same period?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no immediate information in regard to the details which Senator Lajovic requires in relation to 1949 but I can seek that information from the Minister for Housing and Construction for him. With regard to the figure of almost 72 per cent which he mentioned, I must report that I have not seen the Daily Telegraph today, as I imagine a number of other honourable senators have not seen it, bearing in mind the late hour we sat to last night. However, I can confirm that the figure of 72 per cent is approximately correct.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia continues to maintain a very high level of home ownership, notwithstanding the difficulties of obtaining finance in a period of high interest rates. I can confirm that, relative to the rest of the world, Australia is doing extremely well in this area. This, of course, is a function of the very successful financial and fiscal management of the Fraser Government in relation to inflation and the control of interest rates over a long period. Consequently, this Government's chief concern in the area of housing is to ensure that more and more people have the opportunity to get their own home. It will be the goal of this Government to ensure that that very high level of home ownership which Senator Lajovic mentions, relative to the rest of the world, is maintained.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs aware that in a recent inspection of Fitzroy Crossing school by the Western Australian Health and Medical Services Department it was found that 80 per cent of children had trachoma and four children had eyes so badly scarred that they faced blindness, that 90 per cent of children had some hearing handicap and that 20 per cent were severely handicapped? Is the Minister aware that progressive inspections of the Fitzroy Crossing school, where 97 per cent of pupils are Aborigines, have found that the health of the children has been deteriorating over the past seven years. What action will the Minister take to reverse the appalling deterioration in the health of the Aboriginal children at Fitzroy Crossing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I am not familiar with the figures relating to Fitzroy Crossing school which have been mentioned by the honourable senator, I am aware of many of the features of unsatisfactory health in the north-west. I would be grateful if the honourable senator could make available to me in due course the precise figures, as they will help me. I am aware, as other honourable senators will be aware, that many of the infections-the trachoma and some of the infections in the middle ear-are due to infection by organisms of the chlamydia group. The honourable senator should also be aware from the work of the trachoma study that what is required to overcome some of these problems is not only medical treatment with drugs but also measures to improve public health, including the availability of water supplies, sewage disposal, clean food preparation areas and appropriate sleeping areas for people. I think bedding that is 'elevated, ventilated and separated' is Professor Hollows's formula.

ANSWER.PARA: I am also aware, and I think the honourable senator would know, of the work of Dr Michael Gracey from Western Australia. He had an article recently in the Medical Journal of Australia indicating that Aboriginal health in Western Australia is following two different courses; there has been some improvement in the metropolitan area in Perth and there continues to be unsatisfactory features in the north-west. It is in this context and trying to aim towards an improvement in these figures and in the health of Aboriginal people that we announced last week the funding of a number of public health projects which will be directed specifically to the provision of better water supplies, sewerage works and major works to try to overcome the very features which lead to the unsatisfactory conditions set out by the senator from Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment to the concern being expressed by a number of groups, including the Australian Conservation Foundation, concerning the time being taken by the Australian Government to set up its national strategy since the world conservation strategy was launched 14 months ago. Is it correct that to date the Government has released only one publication, a pamphlet, to explain the strategy and that its national steering committee has yet to meet? Does the Minister agree that the strategy represents the most promising attempt to reconcile development with conservation? If so, what reasons can be given for the Government's delay in setting up its national strategy? When will the strategy be drafted and ready for consideration by interested groups within the community? What say will the public and non-government groups have in the formation of the national strategy?

—Senator Missen would know that the Government has had a continuing concern in a whole range of conservation matters. It would be a matter of some regret if in fact it turned out that there had been unnecessary delay in the implementation of the conservation strategy. Therefore, the matters which the honourable senator brings to my attention are ones which I would want to direct immediately to my colleague. I am not aware that there has been only one publication of the kind that he suggested. I want to check his assertion that the national steering committee is yet to meet. I think I can assure the honourable senator that the Minister whom I represent would want to see appropriate and full consultation of the kind which he anticipated in his question. There are a number of particular matters which I will refer to Mr Wilson for detailed response.

—My question is directed to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle in her capacity as Minister for Finance and also in her capacity as a member of the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee. Has her attention been drawn to a report published in this morning's Bendigo Advertiser headed 'Ordnance Factory: Peacock doubts'? Does the report say that at a meeting early on Wednesday morning the honourable member for Kooyong, Mr Peacock, met members of a deputation from Bendigo and told them that he had grave doubts that the Bendigo ordnance factory would be viable as a private enterprise operation? Does the Minister, as a member of the committee which has recommended the sale of the factory to private enterprise, have any comment to make about the remarks of the honourable member for Kooyong, remembering that the honourable member is a former Minister for the Army, with responsibility for the ordnance factory? What investigations were made by the committee to determine the viability of the factory in the hands of private enterprise?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I regret that I have not seen the report in the Bendigo Advertiser referred to by Senator Button. Nor am I aware of the sentiments of Mr Peacock with regard to the Bendigo ordnance factory. As was implied in the question, the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee recommended that the factory be disposed of to private enterprise. That decision was taken by the Government in the belief that it is an appropriate factory to attract interest from private enterprise. As far as the views of Mr Peacock as a former Minister for the Army are concerned, I am unable to reconcile those with present facts and the decision made by the Government. If I have an opportunity to read the report to which reference has been made and there is any further comment that I can offer, I will see that additional information is provided on this matter.
—I wish to ask a supplementary question. With what present facts is the Minister trying to reconcile Mr Peacock's opinion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I think Senator Button said that Mr Peacock is a former Minister for the Army and, as such, had responsibility for the factory. I believe that at the time Mr Peacock was Minister for the Army the Minister for Supply would have been directly responsible for the ordnance factory. I wondered in what context the former Minister for the Army, the present honourable member for Kooyong, may have reported the sentiments that apparently are reported in the article in the Bendigo Advertiser.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Communications to the Australian Broadcasting Commission's AM program this morning which commented on the report of the Dix Committee on the Australian Broadcasting Commission. Can the Minister tell us whether, as stated on AM, the Minister for Communications has received the report of the Dix Committee? Can he tell the Senate whether that report recommends the provision of a second television channel for the national service, to be used for multicultural television services which currently are operated by the Special Broadcasting Service? Does the report state that a separate multicultural operation would be inefficient and an absurd waste of resources in a developing area of extreme demand on expenditure and communications and, further, that an enlarged SBS could effectively be incorporated in the Commission's network? Do these recommendations mean that the Government has accepted recommendations 2 and 3 of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts on the Independent and Multicultural Broadcasting Commission legislation, which sought to have the matter of multicultural television referred to the Dix Committee for inclusion in its study of the ABC? Finally, can the Minister say when the report will be available to the Parliament and the public?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that all honourable senators will be looking for the report of the Dix Committee and for answers to questions such as those raised this morning by my colleague Senator Davidson. Senator Davidson has had a considerable input on this subject during his time in the Senate and not least through his chairmanship of the Senate standing committee to which he has referred. Since I have not seen the report it is not really appropriate for me to answer some of his questions which seek confirmation that certain things are contained in it. I am simply not in a position at this stage to give him such answers. I will try to obtain further information for him.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I was interested in the reference to multicultural television. I live in the city of Sydney and have had an opportunity, as have many other Sydney people, to see multicultural television actually operating. It has been very welcome to have a new channel and to be able to turn to it for programs of quality and depth. I make the point that multicultural television, certainly as it operates on Channel 0/28, is in fact a way into Australian society for a whole lot of people. Because of its sub-titling, because it can be understood by anyone who speaks English and because it provides communication to certain language groups, it is a means of breaking down the barriers and of increasing communication between ethnic groups. It is one of the ways to make our program of multiculturalism work and to allow more people to enter Australian society. It is the kind of initiative which will break down ghettos, not create them. I will seek information with regard to the particular matters raised by the honourable senator.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have pleasure in drawing to the attention of honourable senators the presence in the gallery to my left of a deputation from Morocco led by the Honourable Mr Ahmed Osman, a former Prime Minister. We tender to you, sir, and to your colleagues a very warm welcome to this place. May your stay in Australia be happy and profitable to you and to us. It is our pleasure to meet you.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In France on Tuesday there was an announcement that that country would go ahead with nuclear tests in the Pacific. The French newspaper France-Soir said that some of the tests may be made in the open air. Has the Government any information on this matter? Will it send a strong protest to France against any tests being carried out in the open air?

—Of course, the Government's position has been made perfectly clear in the past and remains unchanged. The Government is opposed to the testing of nuclear weapons and certainly is significantly opposed to open air testing, wherever the cosmic mix may take whatever fallout there may be throughout the world. I heard a media item-I do not know its substance-indicating something of what Senator Melzer said. The first thing I will do is to check whether it is factual, because there could be some aberration there. I have no doubt, assuming that it is factual, that the Government will repeat in strong terms its opposition to open air testing and its opposition to any kind of nuclear activity which could in any way add to the radioactive fallout in the cosmic mix of this world. I will certainly see that the attention of the responsible Minister is drawn to the matter.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, relates to the recent practice of airline hostesses instructing passengers to place all hand luggage under the seat in front, not under the seat on which they are sitting, allegedly to comply with Department of Transport regulations. What is the relevant air navigation order or air navigation regulation on which this action is based?

—This matter has come to the attention of many honourable senators in recent weeks. Certainly it has come to my attention. I have no direct information from the Minister on it, but I will seek to obtain it. Recently I went to the trouble on one flight to inquire of the hostesses as to the basis of the rule. I was advised that statistics show that to place luggage under the seat in front rather than behind one's legs contributes to safety and that there is a record of broken legs, and so on, as a result of crashes when bags are stowed behind people's legs. I am not sure whether that is accurate, but I will check with the Minister and get a reply from him.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I am interested in the Minister's reply that there may be a statistical base for the requirement. My question related to the allegation that it is a Department of Transport regulation or requirement that it be done. I have been unable to confirm the truth of that.
—As I indicated earlier, I will obtain a reply.

—I ask the Minister for Social Security: Do invalid pensioners who have been informed that their benefit will be removed continue to receive their benefit until any appeals they make to a Social Security Appeals Tribunal are finalised? Are appeals which are made to a Social Security Appeals Tribunal and which relate to invalid pensions dealt with in the order in which they are received or is priority given to appeals which are likely to save Commonwealth funds if those appeals are resolved in the Commonwealth's favour?

—There is a provision whereby invalid pensions can be continued in the circumstances raised by the honourable senator for a period of, I think, three months. I will just verify that that is the period which is allowed. With respect to the way in which appeals are dealt with, my advice is that they are dealt with in the order in which they are received. In fact, I think I signed a letter to the honourable senator to that effect within the last few days, but it may have been a letter to another member of the Parliament. In any event, that is my understanding. No doubt it would be the proper way in which to deal with the appeals in the absence of some unusual circumstances of urgency or difficulty for the appellant. Again I will confirm with the Department that that is the universal practice.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Communications give the Senate any information concerning reports received of a rapid pulse-type radio interference, named the Russian woodpecker, to high frequency radio bands due to an over-the-horizon experiment being conducted by the Soviet Union? If this is the case, is there any possibility of having the interference, which has a considerable nuisance factor, countered as it could also possibly cost lives if at any time it coincided with distress calls in the outback of Australia, where this radio interference is most marked?

—Over recent weeks I have acquainted myself with the kind of radio interference adverted to by the honourable senator. I believe there is some information which I could have available by the end of Question Time and which I might be able to provide then. There has been some interference. I would like to get the honourable senator some exact details. I will come back to the matter at the end of Question Time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. Does the Government approve of political files being kept on individuals registered as unemployed? If not, what justification can it offer for the following annotation appearing, I am informed, in the North Fitzroy Commonwealth Employment Service office file of Mr Mark Dober, following his transfer from the Malvern CES office? The annotation reads:

QUESTION.PARA: This person is the convenor of a local group (Coalition Against Poverty and Unemployment) known to have distributed leaflets in front of CES office in Malvern.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will need to refer that matter to the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs to see what information he is prepared to make available. The confidentiality of his Act-the Social Services Act-does not make it easy for information about individuals to be given publicly. However, as a name has been given in the question, I will see what information the Minister is prepared to release on that matter. If the honourable senator is representing the person concerned, he could make representations and some information may be able to be given on that basis.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister unwilling to answer the first part of the question, which was: Does the Government approve of political files being kept on individuals registered as unemployed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Department of Employment and Youth Affairs and the Department of Social Security do have files kept on people who are claimants under the Social Services Act for payments of unemployment benefit or other pensions and benefits that are available. Information comes to the departments from a variety of sources. The departments have the information provided by the claimant. Sometimes information is provided in other ways. I am not aware of what precise policy the Commonwealth Employment Service would have with regard to information that it believes is required for files that it keeps. The matter referred to about the individual in this case indicates information that may be relevant to his claim for unemployment benefit and identifying him as a person who assists in some of the local work that may be done by groups of people involved with those who are unemployed. Perhaps that information was provided by the person himself. I am not aware of the circumstances surrounding this matter. A lot of information can accumulate in the files of the departments which are dealing with individuals who over a period have different experiences that need to be identified.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. It follows a question by Senator Colston. Now that the report of the Administrative Review Council on social security appeals has been tabled and there has been some media commentary already, would the Minister be able to give us an idea of the intentions of the Government with regard to the implementation of that report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Administrative Review Council was tabled recently. It has given rise to some comments in this place and more particularly in the media. I welcome the report. I think it touches on matters which are of importance to a great number of Australians. It is probably true that matters of administrative review are more significant to the lives of most Australians than are matters of judicial review. So, the matters which are raised by the Administrative Review Council are of very great importance.

ANSWER.PARA: The attention of the media has tended to focus on what are seen as the criticisms of the existing systems of administrative appeals within the Department of Social Security. I acknowledge that there are criticisms which require the careful attention of the Government so that we can ensure that the appeal system operates as well as possible. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that, as I noticed was acknowledged in this morning's leading article in the Sydney Morning Herald, the system is better than it was. In other words, over the last 12 months various steps have been taken which pick up some of the points which were expressed as being of concern to the Administrative Review Council. I ask honourable senators to bear those changes in mind when they are looking at the sorts of recommendations that have been put forward.

One of the important changes which have been made is that the range of departmental decisions which are now appealable matches that which has been recommended by the Council. In addition, recommendation is made by the Council that as far as possible interviewing officers should record facts in the words used by the person concerned-the pensioner or the beneficiary. That has been implemented as a departmental instruction. Other matters are currently undergoing study. For example, there is a recommendation about the operation of a review officer system. That may well be something which could be implemented by the Department.

Probably the most substantial change, however, is that there is now a very broad right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. That is, of course, a central part of the recommendation of the Council, which is concerned to have appeal procedures which are totally independent of the Department itself. Whilst the Department still has in place the Social Security Appeals Tribunals, which are internal mechanisms which simply make recommendations to the Director-General, the fact is that anybody who is not satisfied with the operation of those committees may now proceed to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The view which has been strongly put by the Council is that the whole appeal system should be independent and that the bodies which are set up to hear appeals should be able to make decisions and not merely recommendations. They are matters which I can assure you, Mr President, will receive the very careful attention of the Government.

I would like to say two other things with respect to the matters raised by the honourable senator. The first is that I think it is useful if honourable senators who have a particular interest in this area make known to me and to the Department their views on changes which they think are necessary and any comments they have to make on the Council's report. The second thing is that I think there is something of a dilemma in this area which has to be faced, whatever system of appeals is adopted within the Department. That dilemma is the choice between quick informal procedures, which people want for social security beneficiaries, and procedures which at the same time provide the full protection of independence and strict legal decision-making. The sorts of procedures which are quick and informal very often have the deficiency that they do not always have the strict, legal qualities of a more elaborate tribunal. I think that, whatever final pattern is achieved in appeals in social security matters, it will be important to ensure that there are quick informal mechanisms available to appellants, as well as the more complex legal arrangements in respect of which appellants can be absolutely certain that the rule of law applies and that the entitlements that they receive are a matter of legal determination. I do not think that, even though we have had a very valuable report from the Council, the matter is without difficulty. I undertake that the matter will be given the most careful consideration by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Minister representing the Minister for Education that a couple of days ago I put on notice a request for the College of Advanced Education at Townsville to be kept separate and allowed to continue to operate as an autonomous organisation apart from the Townsville university. Because of the unique situation in which this CAE is situated, I ask the Minister whether any information has yet been obtained on the question. If not, will he obtain it as soon as possible in order to preserve the autonomy of the CAE?

—I am not sure that I fully understand Senator Keeffe's question. He may be able to assist me by way of a supplementary question. Let me make it clear that the structure of the Tertiary Education Commission is such that there are three quite separate councils-the Universities Council, the Advanced Education Council and the Technical and Further Education Council. There exist today three bodies, each of them separate and each of them able to pursue its subjective and special interests and submit its reports separately to the Tertiary Education Commission. Those reports and the views contained in them are matters that come under public knowledge. Frankly, I do not know why the honourable senator asked me a question in that form. Therefore, I seek clarification in the form of further information.

—I will elaborate in a supplementary question, Mr President. As a result of the razor gang's recommendations, the Townsville CAE is to be amalgamated with the Townsville university. In other words, it will not operate as an autonomous organisation. I ask that it be allowed to continue to do so.

—I wonder again whether Senator Keeffe is under a misunderstanding. The Tertiary Education Commission in its report drew attention to the fact that in Australia there are now some 30 individual colleges of advanced education-most of them being single purpose teacher training colleges which were small and which, for various reasons, were moving towards non-viability-and stated that they should be rationalised. This refers to 30 individual institutions. The rationalisation suggestion is that they may be absorbed into administrative groups with, say, three or four colleges coming together in the one group, or in some cases a college and a university coming under an overall umbrella administration. The Commonwealth Government accepted the recommendation of the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee that such a rationalisation, in line with the report of the Tertiary Education Commission, should take place. But it is not my understanding at all that this will affect in any way the structure of the Tertiary Education Commission. If it is specific as to the James Cook University and the CAE in Townsville, I would be happy to obtain an answer in relation to that.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. It concerns the crossing of Bass Strait. I remind the Senate that it is not just Tasmanians who are interested in crossing Bass Strait. I refer to a proposal by a retired Port Phillip pilot, Captain John Noble, that the present costly Bass Strait ferry services be replaced with a no-frills, no-passenger sleeping accommodation, drive-on drive-off freight ferry service between Westernport or Corner Inlet in Victoria and Devonport in Tasmania, along the lines of the now efficient and relatively cheap Cook Strait ferry services between the North and South Islands of New Zealand. Has any consideration been given to this proposal by the Department of Transport or the Australian National Line? Have any estimates been made of the cost savings?

—I have some information from the Minister in regard to this matter. The proposal which was outlined-I think Senator Lewis mentioned Captain Noble-in the Bulletin last week is similar to but not identical with the Westernport-Devonport option considered by the Bureau of Transport Economics in its report 'Demand For Sea Passenger Transport Between Tasmania And The Australian Mainland'. The Bureau concluded that the best option for providing sea passenger services between the mainland and Tasmania was to use two vessels which would each carry 200 passengers and 75 accompanied vehicles between Westernport and Burnie. This service would carry passengers by day and cargo at night. It is conceived as being a low crewing, no frills type of operation. The Minister has obtained the views of ship operators on the Bureau's conclusions, but ANL has advised the Minister that it considers the Westernport-Burnie option not yet commercially viable. Consequently he indicates that the savings, which Senator Lewis implied in his question, would not be available.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services and the Minister for Communications. Has the Government told the Australian Broadcasting Commission that its funds for the next financial year will be reduced by between 10 and 13 per cent in real terms? Will this occur through reductions imposed as a result of the so-called razor gang report, plus a 3 per cent reduction in non-salary allocations? At the same time has the Commission also been told, by the Department of Administrative Services, that it must vacate the offices at 164 William Street, Sydney, which are used as the headquarters of the ABC's news department? Will it cost $600,000 for the ABC to vacate these premises? Will additional allocations be made to the ABC in respect of this cost? Where will the news department be relocated?

—I answered a question, either yesterday or the day before, concerning some alleged cuts to the ABC and I made it quite clear then that, while the Government has made certain general decisions on the need to exercise restraint on overall expenditure across all areas of government, any Budget decisions in relation to the ABC will be taken in the Budget context. I am simply not able to give advance notice, nor would we wish to. At this stage we do not know what these might be. I remind the Senate of what I said in my previous answer. I said that Estimates discussions on ABC funding for 1981-82 are still continuing. The Government has asked the Commission to justify claims for those areas in which additional funding is sought. The matter is not settled. It is not the practice of government to outline specific Budget provisions prior to the presentation of the documents to the Parliament in August. The honourable senator also asked a number of other quite specific questions about particular locations, offices and matters of that kind. It might be more appropriate if those questions were placed on notice so that I can get a detailed response.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Would the Minister, when finding out the detailed answers to those specific questions, also indicate by either affirmation or denial whether the ABC has been advised that the cuts indicated in my question will be made?
—Quite clearly I will have to seek that information as well, as I am unable to say what advice has been given to the ABC at this stage.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday last, 2 June 1981, a number of women, some accompanied by children, demonstrated in King's Hall. Due to their behaviour, the Speaker and I gave instructions for the police to be called into the building in sufficient number to remove the demonstrators.

INTERJECT.PARA: Later that day, Senator Georges and Senator Melzer questioned me concerning the matter. As I have already stated, our decision to order their removal was not taken lightly, but was made after careful consideration of the circumstances, and was only implemented after four requests over approximately one hour for the demonstrators to leave the building and choose a deputation to put their case by seeking interviews with senators and members.

The Security Co-ordinator has reported to me that just prior to the police moving in, the demonstrators, who were seated on the floor, formed themselves into a block. At this stage the majority of the women with children left the building. When the police moved in they attemped to pick up individuals to remove them. Most of those struggled violently. As a result of the struggling, a number of the women could not be picked up and were dragged across King's Hall to the stairs. Some suffered falls on the stairs.

The Security Co-ordinator reports that excessive force was not used by the police. He considers that in the circumstances they were most restrained in the face of some very severe provocation and that they carried out their duties in a manner which reflected great credit upon them.

When the demonstrators were cleared from the front of the House people who had legitimate business in the House were permitted to enter. Included amongst these were a number of school children, and people who had tickets to the galleries. I am informed that the Security Co-ordinator gave instructions that such people were to be admitted, and that demonstrators were to be kept out. Due to the pressure of the occasion or some misunderstanding, some people who sought entry were not admitted to the House. It appears that appropriate contact was not made between the attendants and the office they sought to visit. Inquiries are being made into this matter.

In response to the other question raised later in the day by Senator Georges when speaking on the report of the Australian Federal Police, I advice that the Security Co-ordinator is responsible for othe administration of security in Parliament House and for the development of security policy proposals for submission to the Presiding Officers. He is senior to the Usher of the Black Rod and the Serjeant-at-Arms. However, he is required to consult Black Rod and the Serjeant-at-Arms prior to the submission of policy proposals. I have, of course, kept under review the appropriateness of these arrangements.

In relation to Senator Georges's remarks concerning Black Rod protecting the senator's rights, I am informed that at Senator Georges's request, Black Rod did remind the senior police officer present of the orders of the Presiding Officers to use only such force as was considered necessary to remove the demonstrators. Black Rod formed the impression that Senator Georges was satisfied with that intervention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

I request the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carick) at some subsequent stage to give us an opportunity to consider the statement. Honourable senators may wish to debate it. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that that cut right across my rights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I give that undertaking.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a statement concerning this matter.
—Is leave granted?

—Mr President, could we have some indication of the nature of the reason for the request for leave? With the best of goodwill, the Leader of the Opposition and I are seeking to make arrangements for this Senate to have an orderly discussion on this matter at some future date. There would have to be some special reason why at this moment there would be urgency to make a statement which could not be made subsequently. I would never wish to restrain in granting leave but I think we need to know why it is sought.
—This matter could be debated, Senator Georges.

—Mr President, in speaking to the point that the Leader of the Government in the Senate has made, I have the greatest hesitation in cutting across the request of my own leader. I have not the same sorts of reservations about doing that to the Leader of the Government. I would have thought it pertinent for me to make a few remarks since the statement before us today is relevant to several incidents in which I was involved. I would like an assurance from the Leader of the Government that we can debate this matter this week. I do not see that I should trust to the possibility that this matter might not be discussed until August. There are some very important matters here, especially the relationship between the Security Co-ordinator and the Usher of the Black Rod. I am quite surprised to see that certain decisions have been made which have reduced the authority of Black Rod. That is a matter we can discuss at a later stage. But certain references which have been made to me and my reactions to certain approaches are matters which ought to be debated right now. However, if the Leader can give some indication that we will have the statement before us either tomorrow or next Tuesday, I will be patient until that time; but if it is to be next October I take strong objection.

—The motion moved by the Leader of the Opposition which I suggested gave no indication. I think we deliberately did not because of the very crowded nature of the business before the Senate. Honourable senators will know that we are considerably behind in our program. We may well, with goodwill, overtake that work today and tomorrow. If we overtake in the course of any one day and complete the business of the Senate in sufficient time for such a debate, I would be very happy to bring it on. That, I think, is understood. The business of the Senate is important. Nobody underestimates the importance of the matters concerning the presiding officers. We must run this place with goodwill. It is absolutely necessary to get through the business. If it cannot be brought on within the next three or four sitting days, I will undertake that it will be brought on at the first opportunity in the August session. Implicit in the motion by the Leader of the Opposition is that no time is set down.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to requests by Senator McLaren and Senator Melzer for additional information concerning the matters covered by my statement to the Senate on 28 May 1981, I have been advised by the Secretary of the Joint House Department as follows:

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator McLaren asked '. . . whether any threat was made to the people who attended the meeting when they were informed of this arrangement, that is, if they spoke to their unions or Members of Parliament they might suffer severe consequences'.

No such threat was made. Officers of the Security Section have been informed that if any difficulties arise with their conditions of employment, it is expected that they will be raised and endeavoured to be settled within the Department before being referred to their union. They have also been informed that the raising of problems involving Departmental administration and organisation with individual Members or Senators was not acceptable; and that departures from those procedures would attract disciplinary action.
Senator McLaren stated that he had been informed that [the consultations] '. . . had not been agreed to by all people, and some felt that they had been disadvantaged'.

Consultations took place between management and supervising Attendants Grade 3 who were instructed to advise all subordinate officers of the arrangements effected and the duties required to be performed.
Any officer who considers he has been disadvantaged has the opportunity to raise that grievance through prescribed Departmental procedures.
Mr Jorgensen went on to state:
Senator McLaren also asked that the Senate be acquainted with '. . . the criteria which ordinarily applies to temporary positions exceeding one month'.

The criterion ordinarily applied to the filling of a temporary vacancy exceeding one month in duration comprises the assessment of who is the most efficient available officer to perform the specific functions of the position involved. In the particular circumstances occurring the Attendants Grade 3- who supervise the performance of all security attendants both permanent and temporary-made the selections and their recommendations were approved by the Security Co-ordinator and Permanent Head.
Senator Melzer sought information on whether the permanent officers in the Parliament were given the opportunity to attend the special training courses held in 1980.
All officers in the Security Section were invited to participate in the training courses.
Senator Melzer also sought information on the effectiveness of the courses and of current security measures.

The training courses were arranged to give group instruction by Federal Police, security advisers and professional officers in the proper performance of the functions allocated to the Security Section. Those functions mainly comprise the admission of persons to public areas of the House, the identification of persons entering non-public areas, the scanning of mail, baggage and other equipment and materials brought into the House, and supervision of property in public areas and securing of offices after business hours.
The courses were favourably commented on by the participants.
Federal Police officers are also stationed in and around the House to assist with security functions and for law enforcement purposes.
Those arrangements are considered to be the minimum required to provide a measure of protection for Senators, Members, staff, other users of, and visitors to the Parliament building.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: — by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

I want to make some very brief comments about the statement. I am very cognisant of the fact that your statement, Mr President, is not in your own words; that the information has been given to you by the officers concerned, particularly the Secretary of the Joint House Department. I thank you for that. As I may not get an opportunity again, Mr President-you will be completing your duties in the Parliament next week, so far as sitting here is concerned-I want to place on record the way in which you have always been prepared to listen to grievances that have been brought to you about the staff of this Parliament. As I said to you the other day, I have had many occasions to come to you with problems that have been brought to my attention. I and, I am sure, the staff also have been very pleased with the prompt attention you have given to their problems. You have always been concerned with their interests and to see that they are not disadvantaged in any way. I place on record my appreciation of the way in which you have co-operated with me whenever I have come to you with a complaint. I repeat, I do not attribute to you personally any of the remarks that you have just made.

I am concerned about some of the statements that have been made. In your statement you say that you have been advised by the Secretary of the Joint House Department, in response to my question of the other day as to whether any threat was made to the people who attended the meeting concerning the matter in question, that no such threat was made. You state:

Officers of the Security Section have been informed that if any difficulties arise with their conditions of employment, it is expected that they will be raised and endeavoured to be settled within the Department before being referred to their union. They have also been informed that the raising of problems involving Departmental administration and organisation with individual Members or Senators was not acceptable; and that departures from those procedures would attract disciplinary action.

In the opening words of that paragraph the Secretary of the Joint House Department has said that no such threat was made and that if any member of the Joint House Department approached a member or senator it would not be acceptable and departures from procedures laid down would attract disciplinary action. I ask honourable senators: If that is not a threat, what is? The statement adds:
Any officer who considers he has been disadvantaged has the opportunity to raise that grievance through prescribed Departmental procedures.

I will not dwell on that because now that your statement has been noted, Mr President, it will go on to the Notice Paper and the responsible union will have the opportunity to read it. No doubt some discussions will be held, if not with you with the person who takes over your duties as President, and also with the Secretary of the Joint House Department.

I hope that this problem of the Secretary of the Joint House Department taking it upon himself to say that disciplinary action will be taken against people who work in this place if they approach a senator or a member will be quickly ironed out. In my view, every citizen of Australia has the right to approach a member of parliament if he has a problem. That is what we are paid for by the taxpayers. I think that for any person such as the Secretary of the Joint House Department to take it upon himself to say that any employees of this Parliament will attract disciplinary action if they go to their member of parliament is a matter of grave concern to all of us. I will be having more to say about that in the Budget session. I know that Senator Melzer wants to make some remarks in relation to the matter. As I have said, I hope that when we come back for the Budget session this matter will be brought on for full debate so that we can do all we can, as you have done in the time you have been here, Mr President, to protect the interests of people who work in this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melzer Sen J.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senator McLaren that this statement is very disturbing. I do not know how we can accept a statement which purports to say that no threats have or will be made, but finishes up by pointing out that if attendants in this building take certain steps and speak to a member or a senator then disciplinary action will be taken. If that is not a threat, I do not know what is. The implied threat that matters must be raised with the Department before being referred to the union must, I believe, cut across International Labour Organisation conventions which have been accepted in Australia and other parts of the world for a very long time. I cannot understand how we can be expected to accept that people who work in this place are different from people who work outside in the way they should approach members of parliament. All who sit in this place would have spent a considerable amount of time listening to the complaints and worries of public servants and people in private industry about their place of employment, their conditions of employment and the sort of relationship they have with their employers. Does this statement mean that the attendants who work in this place and who are citizens of the Australian Capital Territory are different in some way and must not approach senators or members from the Australian Capital Territory for assistance or advice? That can certainly be inferred from this statement.

SPEECH.PARA: On the question of whether the permanent attendants in this place were invited to take part in the security training courses, and whether they could then gain promotion, this statement is less than satisfactory. When I asked whether permanent officers were given the opportunity to attend the training courses the answer was given that they were all invited to participate. However, this statement contains no material on how many participated or how they fared with the course. I am not terribly interested in whether the courses were favourably commented upon by the participants, but I am a little concerned about the material in the training course. Part of the statement says that the officers are taught to identify persons entering non-public areas et cetera. One of the extraordinary things about this place since we have had security officers on all the doors is that the only people in this place who do not know the members and senators appear to be the security officers. If ever a member or senator is pulled up and asked where they are going, it is sure to be done by one of the people with grey ties who, I am led to believe, are security officers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or a policeman who pushes you to one side.

—Or a policeman who pushes one to one side. The courses may be favourably commented upon but from my observations I am not so sure that the result is as good as we would be led to believe. I would like to know how many of the permanent attendants in this place were accepted into the courses and so were able to gain some sort of promotion. From my observations there have not been many. Those of us who have been here for even a little time get to know the permanent staff, and none of them appear to have been promoted to those positions. I must say that what worries me about this whole security area, and has done so from the beginning, is that it appears to be quite outside our control and our understanding. We do not appear to be given a great deal of information about it.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know, and have never met, this grey eminence who is the security supervisor. His name is not quite known to me. Yet he appears to have tremendous power. I give as an instance of the sort of thing that I am afraid might be happening in this place that yesterday at the beginning of the lunch break I met a person in the corridor whom I had met in connection with a committee which met last week in this place. He was very agitated. He said that he had a pass to come back and sit in the President's Gallery during the afternoon session of the Senate. He said he had been working in Parliament House with people all morning and that he wanted to go out and change his clothes so that he could come back showing proper respect for the Senate. He had gone to the Senate side door and had been told by the security officer that he could go out but that he would not get back in.

As I have said, he had a pass and an invitation to your Gallery, Mr President. When he asked why he would not be allowed back in he was told: 'Because your sort are not getting back in here'. So I went to the door and asked the attendant why this person would not be allowed back in. He said: 'As long as he has a pass he can come in'. I said: 'Why did you tell him that he could not come back?' He said: 'Because he will come back with other scruffy people'. I said: 'He has a pass; he has an invitation, and I suggest that when he gets back to this door you let him in or you advise me, for instance, that he is there and give me some reason why he should not be allowed in'. If that person had not met someone he knew in the corridor, presumably he would have gone out the door and he would not have come back. Who would have made a decision? It would have been some little attendant standing at the door. It seems to me to be extraordinary that we are getting to the position where these strange grey people in this place, on their say-so, have the sort of power to prevent people coming in. It worries me that this sort of power is presumably being given to people in the Joint House Department or that people in the Joint House Department are taking that sort of power. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
