TALK.START.PARA: —As I mentioned earlier, we have before us an opportunity to take advantage of our earlier public housing program not by increasing rents but by reducing them as a result of the early post-war development of public housing. But what does this Bill do? It does not assist that. It does not enable rents to be stabilised if the Government does not want to reduce them. It in fact requires the States to raise the rents. It will boost them from being market-related as they are now to being par market rents-that is, on a level with current private rents. We know what hardship that will cause to the many hundreds of thousands of people who currently are living in public housing. This is a totally irrational, unfair impost upon the tenants and an imposition-without any consultation with the States-placed upon the States if they are to get the funds that are inherent in this legislation. Undoubtedly the financial situation of tenants will worsen and difficulties will be created for State governments if the Commonwealth Government has its way. But of course, it will satisfy the Government's ideological blood lust for private enterprise and thereby will strike another blow at the whole concept of public enterprise.

SPEECH.PARA: I could make many other points about this Bill. The agreement provides the same amount of funding for each of the five years. It does not take into account the rate of inflation. This means that, under the proposed new agreement, the real value of Commonwealth assistance will decline even further. The Australian Labor Party views this agreement as a disgrace. Despite the fact that it is a 5-year agreement designed to tie the hands of a Labor government that will be elected in 1980, we make the promise that, when we gain office at the next election, one of our highest priorities will be to renegotiate an agreement with the States that will restore public housing to its rightful place as a source of secure and cheap housing. To that extent, the Australian Labor Party proposes the following amendment. I move:
Leave out all words after 'That', insert 'the Senate is of the opinion that-

(1) the Bill should be withdrawn and redrafted because it fails to provide sufficient funds to meet the neglected housing needs of the Australian people and signals a further withdrawal by the Federal Government from its-
(A) Responsibility to ensure, in co-operation with the States, Territories and local Government, security of housing for all Australians, and
(B) Direct responsibility for the housing of Aboriginal people;
(2) the Bill should provide-
(A) Sufficient funds to housing authorities to ensure a significant reduction of the backlog on their waiting lists,
(B) Sufficient funds to ensure a permanent reduction in the number of persons who are homeless or living in sub-standard accomodation,
(C) Sufficient funds to allow the housing authorities to undertake a comprehensive survey of housing needs and the adequacy of the existing housing stock,

(D) Sufficient funds to enable the housing authorities, in co-operation with the Commonwealth, to develop a strategy as part of overall urban and regional policy planning to ensure a social mix in housing estates as well as ensuring that public housing tenants have access to social and cultural amenities and job opportunities,

(E) Sufficient funds to allow the housing authorities to expand and improve the stock of public housing while enabling them to continue an effective program of home ownership assistance for low and middle income earners,
(F) That the interest rates for home purchase account 'on lent' to other lending authorities should rise in line with capacity to pay,
(G) That the rents of public housing tenants be related to capacity to pay and otherwise determined on an averaged cost-rent basis, and
(H) An adequate forward commitment of real funds to enable the States and Territories to properly plan their housing programs; and
(3) The opportunity should be provided for the Commonwealth Parliament to debate annually the appropriation to determine progress made in relation to the objectives of the Agreement'.
Sitting suspended from 1 to 2.15 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even though I have heard Senator Gietzelt make the same speech often I still find it quite novel, especially since obviously he has not read the documents and what he has said really does not relate in any way to the facts set out in the Bill. However, I feel that I must refer to one or two of his comments. The honourable senator has been very critical of the five-year term provided, but apparently does not know that for many years the States have requested such longer period. In short, the five-year provision has been included in the Bill at their request.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, the honourable senator spoke at length of how bad was the delay in granting applications for rental accommodation. The last table that I have on the subject, one which gives the position as at 31 December 1980, shows that there were then about 85,000 on the waiting list. The honourable senator overlooked the fact that as at 30 June 1975 there were 104,000 on the waiting list and since then the number has diminished considerably. Currently it is about 20,000 lower. I need not remind honourable senators of which government was in office at the time. The honourable senator claimed that the Labor Government did a good job in regard to housing but the figures do not really bear that out.

The honourable senator referred also to the amount of money to be provided and the terms of such provision but did not mention that the public sector provides only about 9 or 10 per cent of total housing funds; that in the last year or two, in both money terms and housing numbers, the input of public and private capital has been higher than ever. Indeed, the input of Federal funds represents an almost insignificant part of the total. What is important is that whereas formerly a greater proportion of housing funds was provided by the taxpayers, the private sector now finds that it is capable of operating largely on its own. It has been possible to reduce the input of taxpayers' money for housing simply because the private sector has been able to participate more widely itself.

The honourable senator said that it was terribly difficult for young people to buy houses, but Australia still has a home ownership rate of about 72 per cent. Not many countries could claim anything like so advantageous a rate of home ownership. The honourable senator also went to great trouble to say how terrible it was that people living in government houses should not receive bonuses which reflected rental interest. Although he espoused the fixing of very low rentals he did not read the rest of the story in the legislation, which states that, although there should be a market-oriented rent, in the words of clause 34 (1) of Schedule 1:
Rental rebates are to be granted to tenants who are not able to afford to pay the rent determined in accordance with clause 33.
Clause 34 (2) further provides:
A uniform rental rebate policy shall be developed by the Commonwealth and the States and shall be applied by each State for the calculation of rental rebates.

Clearly, that means that people with the capacity to pay will be asked to pay and that those who are unable to do so will be granted a rebate on an Australia-wide basis, so that it will be fair to everybody. Also, the honourable senator referred repeatedly to ideological posturing. Perhaps even Senator Gietzelt would be happy to admit that, in any debate in which I have taken part in this chamber, he would have to be rated very highly in regard to ideological posturing.

The agreement is a natural extension of the 1978 agreement, which, in itself, represented a major breakthrough and change of attitude between the Commonwealth and the States. The new agreement is generous and progressive. The interest rates of 4 1/2 per cent, by any standard, can be regarded as highly advantageous and the forward commitment of five years will also be of great benefit to the States in regard to forward planning. Senator Geitzelt referred to the reduction of base level funding to $200m. Had he read the information that was available he would have found, as I reminded him last night in respect of the Road Grants Bill, that that amount is preliminary in nature and subject to an annual topping up. That is clearly stated in the documents. To say that the amount is being reduced is in fact totally incorrect.

The importance of rental accommodation is clearly emphasised in the Bill. Part X of Schedule 1 lists many items on which, it is suggested, funds may be expended in an effort to encourage rental development. I shall cite but a few of these: To meet the cost of, and associated with, the acquisition, planning and development of land; to pay for the construction or acquisition of housing; to repay the principal of, and pay interest on, loan assistance; to provide funds to such voluntary, non-profit, charitable bodies as may be necessary; to enable housing to be let to such charitable bodies as is required; to engage in urban renewal activities; to allocate funds to local government bodies; to make payments, or provide bridging finance for open space landscaping; to undertake research and policy development in relation to matters not funded by the Australian Research Council; to undertake and participate in joint ventures, co-operative enterprises and so on; to lease housing; to provide housing advisory services; and to provide rental subsidies. That permits a very wide use of money. State housing departments will find it quite possible to use those and other means to extend the stock of rental houses.

The agreement provides an excellent basis for what is a genuine Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. It provides for matching requirements, and in a joint agreement that is only right. The agreement may be said to come down to a matter of money, but in housing the use of the money provided counts far more. The States which have been well endowed with money have in many cases not used it to best advantage. Some of the States that have been given less money have done better than those that have had more. Lest I seem to be critical of what the States, or even some of them, are doing I say that I respect the rights of all States to do exactly as they wish within the realm of this agreement. If they wish to run their programs efficiently it is up to them. If they wish to run them inefficiently, it is still up to them. If they wish to gain the benefits to be derived from an efficient program they can, but if they do not they can take the consequences. We need to see how Federal money can best be spent. If the States choose to use their money in a way that does not provide the optimum housing stock, they cannot expect the Commonwealth to keep funding inefficency.

This Bill makes that matter even clearer. It provides a whole new range of flexibilities. It means that the States will be given more responsibilities. There will be more State decisions and, as a result, there will be fewer areas in which the States can kick the Government in Canberra. The sorts of things that the Bill provides with regard to home ownership include greater involvement of the private sector in the rental market. It will enable housing departments to buy and rent individual houses. It will allow them to buy instead of building and to provide such things as interest or rental subsidies. That is now up to the States, and they can use the agreement to get the best advantage possible from the funds involved.

With all that in mind, we have to remember that the public sector still provides only about 9 per cent of total housing. Over 90 per cent is provided by the private sector. As a result, the public sector must make sure that its proportion is used as efficiently as possible and that it goes to the people who need it most. At present the various States get varying amounts of money. The amounts vary from as little as $15.19 per capita in Queensland to as much as $37 per capita in Tasmania, which is an average of $19.15 per head. That much difference between the top and bottom States should indicate clearly either that Tasmania should now be in the best position in Australia or that it must have been in by far the worst position and in the greatest need. I think we have to consider whether it really does not do much more than demonstrate that Tasmania has had enough money that it has never really had to be careful about its use-certainly not as careful as some of the other States. I would not like to think that Tasmania fell within the category of what is usually referred to as operating within the limits of maximum inefficiency. Recently I received from the Tasmanian Minister for Housing, Mr Baldock, a letter raising various funding problems. I subsequently answered that letter. I have checked with the Opposition Whip and, in the interests of time, I now seek leave to incorporate a copy of my reply in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
14 May 1981 The Hon. D. J. Baldock, M.H.A.,
Minister for Housing,
Parliament House,
Hobart, Tasmania 7000
Dear Minister,
Thank you for your letter of 30 April and a subsequent amendment of 5th May.

As you are aware I have for many years taken a keen interest in the management and operation of the Tasmanian Housing Department and as your files show I have made many suggestions over a period of years on how you could prepare for such an eventuality as that which you now face.

Firstly, may I say that I totally respect the rights of each and every State to spend their money in the manner they see fit and it is entirely up to them to adopt what ever policies they like and to make their own arrangements as to what is appropriate I think politically or economically as they see fit.
If you check my file I think you will find that from time to time I have commented on several areas but as I don't have my file before me I will have to rely on my memory.
Firstly, market related rent

Tasmania has been slower than other States to bring their Housing Department rental housing in line with the market. This has the result of providing bonuses to many people who are not in the welfare class. It has also resulted in houses being occupied by people who had they been paying a reasonable rental would have moved out into the private sector rental housing or would have bought one of your houses or bought a house on the open market and owned, any of those contingencies would have provided additional housing for people who needed it.
Secondly, land supply

By any standards the stocks of land held by your Department in various parts of Tasmania are grossly excessive for any reasonable needs and while I respect the rights of the State to put their money into land instead of housing if it is their wish, they cannot complain about not having money simply because they tie it up in ways that fail to provide houses.
Thirdly, increased house sales

There has been no real effort by the Tasmanian Housing Department to instigate an increase in sales of permanently occupied houses to the occupants as a means of giving the transference of money to new people.

It is very clear to me that the only way we can increase the number of new houses is by selling off some of the old ones to the occupants. For myself I can see no difference in the housing stock of selling a house on the one hand and having it occupied by a life-time tenant on the other. I believe that it is the throughput that is important and the present policy does nothing to assist that.
Fourthly, old persons and other welfare housing

It is my opinion that far greater use should be made of co-operation with local welfare and welfare groups and other organisations who are prepared to participate in housing the aged on the basis that a proportion of Government funding and a proportion of donations and owner/donor situations does very much more to house people than having 100 per cent Government funds.
In the area of maintenance and so forth, costs of handling by your Departmental officers is also of great consequence when the money could be better used if it were allowed to be handled by groups.
Fifthly

The most economical use of money in Australia today is through the co-operative building societies. If more money were passed through them and they are extremely low management rates, more use could be made by people who could make some contribution in their own right; many more people would be housed. This is an irrefutable fact in every State and I would suggest that it is another area where you have failed to get the best use of money available.
Interest subsidies

Some States have found that the most economical use of limited funds is in providing subsidies on interest rates to augment existing housing financing bodies. A little amount by way of interest subsidy will house a lot of people. The scheme in Western Australia and Victoria is well-known and operating very satisfactory. I can only comment that if you are concerned about the number of people being housed that you consider this scheme as one of the ways to make your money go further.

I have been very conscious for many years that Tasmania's allocation which currently runs at $37 per capita against say Queensland at $15.19 an Australian average of $19.15 would be brought into question by those States which have made very substantial efforts to obtain maximum utilisation of their funds in conversion into housing.

Although you probably have this table I enclose a copy so that various difficulties can be seen. As you are aware from previous correspondence I am also greatly concerned about the outstanding applications for rental accommodation existing in Tasmania as compared with the other States. From the attached table it is clear that Tasmania is virtually at the highest it has ever been while apart from New South Wales several other States have made very significant reductions.

Victoria for instance from a high of 23,000 has now 13,000. Queensland from a high of 8,000 is now 5,500. South Australia from nearly 24,000 is now 19,000 and Western Australia from a high 16,000 is now just over 5,000. The policies of all those States has made it possible to have these numbers reduced where the policies of your department, I believe, need looking into very seriously to see why they have not achieved a similar result. Certainly it is not a shortage of money.

The table of stocks of lettable dwellings bears this out even more where it can be seen that each State has now more rental housing than it had in 1976 but where Tasmania now has in excess of 50 per cent more but still a greater waiting list.

My investigation of the actual amount going into housing indicated that the total of the last five years has probably been higher than at any previous time and this of course is due to greater participation by the private sector and this cannot be overlooked as a dominant source and although there may have been some reductions in the public sector the total has been extremely high.

Very naturally you may expect that I would wish to see Tasmania get every dollar to which they are entitled and I believe I have watched these things close enough to assure you that I do just that but I do find it difficult to be able to suggest going to the Treasurer for extra funds at a time when I am not convinced myself that the money we are already getting is performing the best possible function.

As I said in my opening paragraph I do accept that it is within the rights of the Government to spend their money in any way in which they feel inclined but if they choose to do so in a manner so patently disadvantageous to the system I certainly believe that they have to consider this and that they cannot expect to be funded for inefficiencies and you will concede that I have drawn these things to your attention over and over again because I could see that sooner or later this situation was going to arise and that we have to face it.

I would be very happy to assist you in any way to ensure that we could suggest schemes that would ensure better use of the money and I believe that we can overcome the disadvantages that you so adequately expound if you are able to look at it in an overall manner and take into account subsequently the matters that I have raised.
Thank you for drawing it to my attention.
Yours sincerely, BRIAN R. ARCHER Senator for Tasmania

TALK.START.PARA: —From the comments I made to Mr Baldock it was apparent that Tasmania has the highest per capita rate of federal funding, the highest ever rental stock and the longest ever waiting list. No other State had the same ratio. That clearly demonstrates to me that Tasmania has made insufficient progress towards market related rents. Far too much money is tied up in land. Not enough effort is made to sell government houses that are tied up on long term rentals when they could be sold to the tenants. Not enough has been done to try to get greater co-operation from outside bodies, particularly with regard to aged persons and such matters. Tasmania has not used the terrifically efficient co-operative building society movement nearly enough to get money to people who want housing and it has not been nearly sufficiently innovative in its approach to housing generally. The system that has pervaded has meant that it did not need to be. At no stage has it ever needed to be, because it had enough money to carry on in a way in which had been predetermined. I do not mind the State carrying on in that way provided it does not say to Canberra: 'We want more money to continue to do the things we have done in the past'.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure that this Bill will allow considerably more houses to be provided. It will provide the more needy people with houses. As we all know, the need of the needy is growing and should be considered more than ever. In April 1975 Professor Henderson put down his report 'Poverty in Australia'. It is quite amazing to look back at what he said then. On page 164 of the report, when speaking with respect to the numbers of dwellings, he said:
. . . (72 per cent) were occupied by people with incomes more than 120 per cent of the poverty line.
He was speaking about public authority housing. He continued:
At the same time, 86,000 families and individuals below the poverty line, and a total of 146,000 with incomes less than 120 per cent of the poverty line, were renting privately.
We knew all that in 1975. On page 166 the report stated:
We wish to see a competitive situation in the supply of rental housing with housing authorities gradually raising all rents to market levels as improved income maintenance enables tenants to pay.

It has been only six years since that report came out, and we have moved very slowly. Many of the problems that we now see have undoubtedly been compounded by the fact that we have been too slow to act on some of the recommendations that were made. It is unfortunate that clause 33 had to be included in the agreement. That clause states:

The State will in respect of the rent for its rental dwellings apply a policy directed to the progressive movement during the term of this agreement of the rent for each dwelling to charging market rent and will review rents at least annually.

But that clause is necessary. The whole basis of the Government's housing policy, I believe, is built around charging market rental for the houses involved. If we do not charge market rental, we automatically build up a waiting list of people who are looking for a bonus. But if we charge market rental we will find immediately that one of about three or four things will happen: Tenants will buy the houses they are in if there is no advantage in being a subsidised renter, or they will move out of the house and rent a private sector house, or they will move out and buy a public sector house. Whichever happens, an extra housing unit will be created. To allow people who do not need help to clutter up houses for people who do need them is certainly counterproductive in the extreme. Provided we take that clause in conjunction with clause 34, which I referred to earlier and in which a uniform rental rebate policy is included, we will ensure that the people who can afford to pay do so and that the people who cannot afford to pay do not do so. I believe that is the fairest way we can possibly have it.

I believe the Bill can and will tidy up many of the areas that have been in the production line since 1978. It will certainly put the States in a position in which they will be able to demonstrate their willingness and their capacity. It will certainly provide the private sector with new avenues of producing innovative means of participation in what until now has not been part of its general sphere. Accordingly, I support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage in this debate I would like to ask the Government whether it might not now well consider legislation to introduce into Australia, especially in the cities, a system of residential public poor houses modelled on those used in Victorian England to house the poor and homeless. I say that not with any spirit of flippancy but because of my awareness of the difficulties and the wretched conditions under which pensioners and disadvantaged people generally in their thousands are living in my home city of Sydney. Certainly as a result of this Bill and its appalling provisions I can foresee circumstances in Sydney in which that degree of support and help for people who may well become homeless or be forced literally onto the streets may become necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: It is terrible that a society such as ours, which pretends to be an enlightened and modern one in the second half of the twentieth century, should be contemplating a situation in which it lets down the total community to the extent that it cannot provide decent housing. We are placing ourselves on the level of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics which, indeed, cannot provide its people with decent housing. It is in that position for exactly the same reasons this Government is-because it sees its priorities elsewhere. I suggest that for the Fraser Government the wheel is coming full circle in this and other respects. We are beginning to approach some of the worst aspects of the world's older and more conservative communist states.

The increase in rents is bound to continue and to be exacerbated in the cities as a result of the fall-off in the provision of public and welfare housing as a result of this legislation. With chronically increasing unemployment, I suggest that over the next five years housing will become the greatest national social problem and the root problem in our society. It is well on the way to becoming that already. In the first place, this Bill represents a substantial abdication by the Federal Government of its responsibility in an area which the Australian Democrats believe should be a major responsibility of any national government in any modern civilised society. It should be a responsibility to see that society is organised in such a way as to provide reasonable housing for all of its people. We believe-I agree with Senator Archer on one point-that there is no reason private enterprise should not be involved in this matter. We believe it should be involved. But it should be an enlightened private enterprise which sees an obligation to provide a service as well as making a profit and which should be encouraged, led and guided by government in such a way that it can meet the requirement for housing.

In other words, if we are going to say that private enterprise can do this we have to demonstrate that it can. In all the cities of Australia there is obviously the gaping, yawning fact that it cannot or has not. Therefore, I think the only answer is to try to do something that will improve that whole area of housing. If we have fallen so low as not to be able to guarantee reasonable housing for all our people at this time in our history, it is time we had a very basic moral and practical reassessment of our objectives in this society and of what we are trying to do. I am encouraged by Senator Archer's assurance that the Government will look at this matter annually and provide an adequate topping up of these funds each year.

If that happens, the Australian Democrats will be the first to be delighted. We can see-to use Senator Archer's words-the beginnings of an enlightened, advanced Liberal Party policy towards public housing in this country when the problems are genuinely recognised and when the Government comes forward not only with extra money each year to add to this pitiful $1,000m over a period of five years-it will be eroded by inflation, anyway-but also with ideas and an enlightened approach to private enterprise. That may take the form of subsidy tax relief but it must be some way of dealing better with the terrible problem of land and its costs in Australia. The Government must give a lead to private enterprise which, I believe, it would be only too glad to follow.

While the Government continues to give those present signals to private enterprise that nothing is to be done-that the whole purpose of housing and land in Australia is to rip people off as much as possible and think that this is a tremendous area of potential profit-the problem will tend to be exacerbated. The Australian Democrats believe that it is irresponsible for the Government to allow that situation to continue. We believe too that there would be that kind of flexibility if private enterprise entered into this area reasonably. There has been a deplorable lack at all levels of government in this country of any sort of intelligent response to this problem. In Sydney one can see in street after street rows of standard three-storey, nine unit blocks of home units stuck on small pieces of land. An enlightened approach would be for the original developers or builders of those units to come together as a co-operative group and get a larger piece of land on which to build a high rise building with a swimming pool, tennis courts and to provide some sort of area around it where children could play. That would have made all the difference. What do we have instead? We have these dismal rows of buildings which will be the slums of the future and which are already the slums of the present. They present intolerable burdens to the people who live in them. I suggest that if we built houses such as that we are building something that will last for a long time. We are condemning society for a generation or more in advance to the conditions that have been inflicted on them. I imagine that this sort of thought would be the duty of government. It appals me that apparently the Liberal Government sees no responsibility for it to act on these sorts of ideas.

The second effect of the Bill, having shifted the responsibility for housing on to the States, is to cut the amount of money being made available for them. I return to this point about topping up. In future the Australian Democrats will be watching the Government to see the extent of its sincerity. It can show its sincerity by grappling this problem of topping up the funds provided annually. We hope that that happens. It is the situation in Sydney at present that pensioners and other disadvantaged people are being required to pay $40 to $50 a week for a slum room with shared facilities. I appeal to honourable senators from other States who may not understand how much Sydney is the apex of this problem, to realise how much more difficult things are in Sydney than in some of the smaller cities of Australia which are much more fortunate.

I have recently had representations from pensioner constituents and pensioner associations in Sydney about this matter. In fact, I made submissions to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) asking for higher subsidies for pensioner rents in Sydney. I have not been able to telephone my office in Sydney where my files are because of the problem with telephones. But I recall that he basically felt that subsidies in this area ought to be the same throughout Australia. I hope I am not misrepresenting the Minister. If I am, I apologise to him in advance. The point is that I ask the Government again to consider as an urgent palliative measure to increase those subsidies for pensioner housing in Sydney because they are desperately needed. Why Sydney? The problem is, of course, at its worst there. For a variety of reasons rents are much higher in Sydney than anywhere else in Australia.

I have not raised this idea of instituting poor houses lightly or flippantly because I am aware of the dreadful accommodation into which so many of these pensioners and other disadvantaged people are being forced. Because of the actual shortage of even this dreadful accommodation, they have a fear of being evicted and actually being forced on to the streets. Thousands of people are living in dirty, inconvenient slum properties with primitive, shared facilities. Often there are no means at all for cooking meals, rooms leak regularly and windows are broken and let in the wind. This is quite common. It is not unusual. It is having a very serious and deleterious affect on the elderly people who are being compelled to live in this sort of accommodation because they find that on the pension, even with the subsidy, they cannot afford anything better.

They are rapidly reaching the stage at which they cannot even afford that and where the thought of trying to find something else is looming in their minds as the most important thing in their lives. They have a terror in their old age of being forced into an even more demeaning, undignified and humiliating situation in housing. I feel quite sure that those people would definitely be more comfortable, in fact, in a Victorian-style poor house if it were reasonably well built and had reasonable facilities in it. It is a cruel irony that we have allowed our society to get to the stage where we can actually say that about our own cities in Australia.

Unemployed youth, disabled pensioners and widows with families are all part of this growing army of people now crowded into bad accommodation. Increasing numbers of people have no accommodation at all and the picture for the future can only become much worse. In Sydney most new, reasonable accommodation being built is very much up market. It is not at all uncommon for a new two-bedroom unit in Sydney to be selling readily at $100,000. Precious little of this new accommodation is for rental and where it is the rents are often very high. Again a rent of $100 a week is not uncommon for a two-bedroom unit in Sydney. Some rents are even higher. I think it goes without saying that the average family is quite unable to think of buying or even renting one of those units.

Private enterprise is certainly building those units and they are being sold or rented to the people who can afford them. I do not see any evidence in Sydney, nor can the people with whom I have been dealing-the Australian Council of Social Service, pensioner associations and so on-who are looking around desperately for something better find any evidence that private enterprise has done anything whatsoever to meet the kind of requirement that really exists for the disadvantaged people in our society.

I turn briefly to consider the people on merely average incomes. Workers on the average wage or a little less are in very bad positions. The Government, which is now exacerbating this situation, is making it a crime in this society to have a family, a crime for which both man and wife must be punished. Also, those children they elect to have must also be punished. The punishment often enough is to be forced to bring up children in a temporary home, in many thousands of cases, in caravans in a caravan park or in small home units with no places for children to play or even to make the slightest noise for fear of disturbing the neighbours. From time to time in this place I hear a lot of pious noise about the difficulties of child abuse and how terrible all this is. It is no wonder to me that we get that kind of situation. The only thing that astonishes me is that the problem is not worse when we consider the plight of a young mother with two or three small children. She has to bring up those children from babies in a tiny home unit or, worse still, in a caravan. Whether the Government likes this comment or not, it is a fact that it is these conditions that this Bill not only seeks to perpetuate but also seeks to exacerbate. The conditions will become worse.

It is small wonder that the Government has saved up this Bill for today, right at the end of the session. It is another one of these nasty surprises for the Australian community, one of those unpleasant things which the Government has saved up to try to force through today in a hurry. When I was reading the debate on this matter in the House of Representatives, I noticed that it was only given an hour to be debated. This is a matter of enormous importance and I think that only being given an hour to debate it is a great disgrace. Last night I spoke on the general philosophy and view of the Government of its responsibilities to allow legislation to be carried through in an even and regular way. I repeat that indictment of the Government now. In bringing all this legislation through in a rush at the end of the session, the Government is demonstrably cheating. It is seen by the Opposition, by the Australian Democrats and by the Australian community as cheating. The Government is doing this because it has things that it wants to cover up. It does not really want to discuss them properly because it has no real answer to them. This is the Government's way of forcing those things through.

The Australian Democrats condemn the Bill. Even more, they condemn the mental attitude that lies behind this legislation. The Government says that private enterprise will solve all of these problems. Senator Archer says that it can be done that way, with free market forces. But will it? As I said before, of course, yes, an enlightened private enterprise, with a strong government lead, could do so along lines which Australian Democrats policy has already devised. That was devised by people thinking and working together, by ordinary Australians saying what they want and then voting on it. The tragedy of this Bill is that it signals that that is not to happen; there is not to be any enlightened general leadership or encouragement for a better public housing policy in Australia, but merely a grudging handing out of the smallest possible amount that could be decently set down and a shuffling off to the States to deal with as best they can what should be an important national responsibility.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melzer Sen J.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say, having listened to Senator Mason, that I agree with most of what he said. It is a great disappointment to find a government that purported to believe in housing for the Australian people doing such a miserable job when it really comes to putting some impetus into the area. I was interested to note that the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh), at the conclusion of his speech in the other place, said:

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill represents an important step forward in the implementation of the Government's housing policy.
It was rather worrying to read that, taking the Bill into account. He went on to spell it out when he said:
This policy is to: Ensure that every househodl in Australia is able to obtain adequate housing within its capacity to pay;

We all know that the capacity of a very large proportion and a very growing proportion of households in Australia to pay is getting less and less. One wonders whether that really means that a large proportion of Australians will be living in tents or bark humpies or maybe just camping on the beach, because the income they receive will only provide that sort of shelter for them. Taking that statement into account, we have more than 80,000 families around Australia on waiting lists for houses. More than 150,000 people are homeless. More than a quarter of a million people live in caravans or makeshift accommodation. This is happening in what one of our new senators claimed yesterday is the land of milk and honey, a country where people live in much better circumstances than almost any other place in the world. Yet we have thousands of people who do not have any hope of living in anything like decent accommodation.

Resource development is a great plank of this Government's policy. The Government says that it is going to be the panacea for Australia, that it will provide us with a great, rich and beautiful life. Resource development will solve all of our problems. Yet in the very areas of Australia where resources are being developed, there are appalling shortages of that very basic commodity, housing. There is no move from this Federal Government, which put so much of our effort and resources into those areas, to get on with and provide immediately the housing that is necessary. In Gladstone, Queensland, a quarter of the population is living in caravans, without taking into account the new population growth. In the Latrobe Valley in Victoria, without taking into account any of the new proposals that the Liberal Government in that State has come up with, there is not a room, a caravan or a condemned chook house to rent. Here we are talking about people who are working on the project renting some sort of accommodation. Of course in those areas, if one talks about the aged, single parents, the unemployed and other disadvantaged people in our community, there is no hope whatsoever of getting them any sort of accommodation. Nor is there any move from this Government to provide anything like the amount of finance needed for accommodation.

We talk glibly about giving people clean water and a place to live. This Government does nothing about it. In Portland in Victoria, with the encouragement of this Government, we have extraordinary development in the aluminium industry. One cannot buy accommodation for love or money. Perhaps I should rephrase that. One cannot get accommodation for money. One might be able to get it for some other reasons! The Liberal Government in Victoria estimates conservatively-it is a conservative Government and the Minister is even more conservative-that there are at least 100,000 households in need of bare accommodation. What is this Bill going to do for them? It will do nothing. On the basis of 1974-75 data, the housing Minister in Victoria estimated that the public housing stock can cater for only 34 per cent of the apparent need. In 1974-75 we were still a comparatively buoyant community. But when one looks at the enormous increases in unemployment and in the number of homeless people since 1974-75, what must the current rate in Victoria be, if only 34 per cent could be catered for in 1974-75? Honourable senators can double that figure for 1980-81 and 1981-82. What will this Bill do for that problem? The second point of the Government's housing policy states:
Encourage home ownership across the widest possible range of income groups concentrating Federal assistance in the areas of greatest need.

On 7 April this year, there was an article in the Melbourne Herald. It referred to statements made by the Managing Director of Jennings Industries Ltd, Mr J. J. Wood. Jennings Industries would be the the firm which would know a great deal about housing activity and housing policies in Australia. At a Conference of the Australian Association of Permanent Building Societies, Mr Woods said:
Housing activity would slow down substantially in Australia if mortgage interest remained above 12 per cent.
He went on to say:
Continued satisfactory growth in private sector housing in Australia depended on the Government effectively managing inflationary pressures arising from the resources boom.
As we know very well, the Government has been less than successful in doing that. He went on to say:
. . . the Governments strategy was to control inflation by monetary measures.
Competition for funds is sending interest rates spiralling to levels well above the recorded inflation rates.
Home finance lending rates are a critical factor and care must be taken to ensure that housing does not receive more than its share of constraints.

This is because the effects on housing will be more immediate than on other industries where higher rates customer finance may be more affordable. What has this Government done about housing interest rates? What were its election promises about the rate of interest that would be charged on housing loans? What is the point of even talking about ensuring that every household in Australia is able to obtain adequate housing within its capacity to pay if the Government is not doing anything about the rates that people have to pay on the loans that they have to take out? The article continued:
Mr Wood said housing supply could not withstand high interest rates on long term mortgages because first home buyers made up 50 per cent of the market.
He said industry and commerce could withstand higher interest rates because they enjoyed the benefit of tax deductibility on mortgage payments and much shorter repayment terms.

What has this Government done about that in relation to housing? Which area of industry and commerce in this country has it favoured? Yet it talks about providing every household in Australia with adequate housing. The article went on:
Mr Wood said that in looking at what was an affordable interest rate on mortgages a number of key factors had to be kept in mind.
Half of all employees in Australia earn less than $200 a week.

Let me apply that to those areas of resource development where people are competing desperately with each other for housing, where people are desperate for loans so that they can provide some sort of accommodation for their families. What are those people earning less than $200 a week going to do in the light of the high rate of interest that is being charged and the piddling amount of money and the lack of direction that this Federal Government has given in that area? What encouragement is there for them to work, to produce, to bring up families, to contribute to Australia? They get nothing from this Federal Government. The article continued:
Building regulations are strictly controlled in Australia so that home buyers cannot reduce the size of their home below a minimum standard to suit their budget.
God help us! In some ways I am glad, because if some of them had to reduce their home standards to suit their budget they would be living in a chook house. The article continued:
The normal maximum term of housing loans in Australia is 30 years.
An increase of 1 per cent in interest rates reduces borrowing power by around $2500 for a family which can afford mortgage payments of $100 a week.
That, evidently, went right over the head of this Federal Government. The article continued:
It is impractical to price the cost of finance into a house to match a loan affordable.
Mr Wood said to sustain a weekly repayment of around $100 on a $50,000 house and land package purchased on a 10 per cent deposit a young couple would require a gross weekly income of around $350.

We know that there are hundreds and hundreds of young couples in Australia who both go out to work and who do not receive that kind of income. To what are we condemning them? We have all noticed in the newspapers in the last six months stories about the aging population and the lowering birth rate in Australia. Who in the name of fortune would bring children into the world when wages, conditions and the hope of providing even a basic, simple house is so low in Australia today? Mr Wood said:
Anyone who doubts that housing activity will slow substantially if mortgages stay above 12 per cent should look at overseas experience.

Mr Wood suggested that the Prime Minister of this country (Mr Malcolm Fraser) should look to Mrs Thatcher. After all, the Prime Minister of this country appears to have a great regard for Mrs Thatcher and her methods. Mr Wood pointed out:
Mrs Thatcher's move to drop housing rates in the British budget from 14 to 12 per cent is designed to stimulate housing demand.
We can only hope that our dear Prime Minister might listen more closely to what his esteemed colleague is doing in other places. Mr Wood went on to say:
Similarly the American housing market is not expected to reflect its large pent-up demand until rates drop to 12 per cent-and this with tax deductibility.

This gentleman is the Managing Director of Jennings Industries Ltd, a leading housing firm that provides an enormous amount of housing, not only in Victoria but also across Australia. He is a man who ought to know what he is talking about. He was speaking at a conference of the Australian Association of Permanent Building Societies to people who ought to have some appreciation of the situation in the community. That leads me to the third plank of the Government's housing policy platform, namely:
Ensure stable economic conditions within the building industry.

Does it sound as though the Government's policies are stabilising conditions within the building industry? Because of the high interest rates and the lack of bridging finance, thousands of houses in Australia at this time are being sold up by mortgagors because the mortgagees cannot keep up the payments. They are losing their jobs, their wages are being reduced, their wives can no longer get work and they can no longer maintain the payments on houses that in the first instance were priced well above their value anyway. There is evidence that many of these houses are being sold for less than their value.

It would be interesting if somebody were to inquire into who is buying these houses at less than their value. Mortgagees are being left with the difference between the debt they took on in the first place and the amount of money that comes in from the sale of their house. They are being left with that difference as a continuing and crippling debt. In some instances they are being asked to pay 60 per cent interest on default payments. All of this goes over the head of this Federal Government. How can one talk about stable economic conditions in the building industry when there is overwhelming evidence that building societies are going broke, building firms are going broke, builders are going out of the industry and suppliers of building materials are going out of business? An article in the Age of 26 May stated:
Societies lose ground in home lending market.
Building societies' share of the home-lending market has fallen dramatically during the first three months of 1981.
It went on to say:

Since December, building societies have seen their share of the market slip in the face of increased competition from the banks and from other non-government and government borrowers, which, in the face of tight monetary policy, have been more willing than the building societies to compete for funds by offering higher interest rates.

The market for finance is drying up. The building societies now have to compete for funds by offering higher interest rates. If they do that, of course, they then have to raise the rates that they charge to the ordinary people of this country who have learned that the building societies are the only organisations to which they can turn for assistance in buying a house. Funds are drying up because this Government's policy is to direct all sorts of investment funds into other areas. Its attitude is: Never mind about housing for the ordinary Australian people. The investment funds are going into other areas. Housing is low on the list of people who want to invest funds. Who suffers? The ordinary people who work this country and produce its wealth suffer. But this Government does not see the necessity to assist.

Fewer and fewer people can afford to buy houses, so fewer and fewer houses are being bought. It is not by chance that in those circumstances the Victorian Minister for Housing has switched his policy from building welfare houses to buying houses from private enterprise for welfare purposes. If he did not do that more builders would be going broke because no houses at all would be built and those that had been built on the spec market would not be bought. So the industry's friend, the Victorian Minister for Housing, is stepping in to help it.

But will the Government really stretch out that dollar for welfare housing? The Minister and the Government have told us that there is $x to be spent on what we call welfare housing. How a Government that says that every household in Australia should have adequate housing can talk about welfare housing is beyond me. It seems to me that all Australians are entitled to decent housing. Nonetheless, what I want to know is how we can expect to have that welfare dollar stretched out to its maximum if we are to use that money to buy houses on the market. Will more housing be available for people who cannot afford to build their own homes? Will more housing be available for people who at the moment cannot afford to rent on the open market? Of course as people move out of houses which they hoped to buy, they are also in the market competing for any houses that may be for rent. In this free enterprise world in which we live that pushes up the price of rent. If those people ask for a better wage so that they can cope, they will be told that they are causing inflation. Will this use of the welfare dollar that this Federal Government has given the States for housing mean that perhaps more money goes into the pockets of private builders? Already we have reports that fewer houses are for sale. The Age of 8 April states:

House prices in many parts of Melbourne are likely to rise steadily because of an increasing shortage of residential properties for sale, according to a survey of real estate agents published by the State Bank.

The survey, conducted in January, shows that more than 80 per cent of agents who participated had insufficient listings of houses for sale. The majority view was that units and flats were in short supply, too.

The strongest indication of a shortage of houses for sale came from the north, where all agents surveyed said there was inadequate supply. In the north-east, 92.3 per cent gave the same answer and units and flats appeared to be in shortest supply in that area.

So the money that this Federal Government is giving to the States for housing is being used by the Minister of Housing in Victoria to buy houses in the market place rather than to build houses. We are told that at the moment there is a great shortage of houses to be bought, especially houses where one would expect government assistance might be highest, that is, in the northern and western parts of Melbourne where generally people's incomes are less than those of people who live in the southern and eastern parts. There is a shortage of houses, so now we have the Minister in the market. What will that do to the price of houses? It will send them sky-high because here they have a buyer with cash in his pocket. Will the Minister persist and buy a few houses in those areas at a reasonable price or will he move out to the southern and eastern suburbs of Melbourne where prices usually are higher than in the other areas, but where the need for welfare housing is not so great. In a Press release the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh) said:

The initiatives outlined by Mr Kennett should result in better services to low income families with a housing need, a great involvement by the private sector, and more efficient use of taxpayers' funds.

For the life of me I cannot see how this will provide a better service for low income families with a housing need because in many instances the houses will not be in areas where people need them. They will be in the outer parts of Melbourne. These days it costs people who live in these areas a tremendous amount of money to get to work. So why will people want to go there? What sort of rent will the Minister ask because he will have to pay a great deal of money to buy the houses. We will certainly need a greater involvement by the private sector. When it comes to receiving the profits, that is exactly how the private sector will be involved. The private sector in the building industry has not shown any initiative when it comes to welfare housing. Where are the houses that private enterprise has built for people to rent? Where is any involvement from the private sector in the area of houses for people who do not have and will not have-while this Federal Government is in existence-the sort of income that will enable them to ever buy their own houses?

In the last two weeks in this Parliament we have had an indication of how some women feel about housing and government involvement in their lives. Some honourable senators on both sides of this Parliament were scandalised that women, of all people, should make a nuisance of themselves, should sit in King's Hall and should make noise to try to draw attention to the fact that they are on the very lowest scale when it comes to government involvement in assisting them to live better lives. In part those women have been involved in this question of refuges for women. Some women, who for many reasons which we do not have to go into now, have to leave home and find somewhere else to live. Often they have children. They go to a refuge. Refuges are supposed to be what they sound-a place where a person can go for refuge while she draws a breath and then gets on with her life. The refuges are stuffed up because women cannot move out as there is nowhere for them to go. How can there be anywhere for them to live when we have been shown that there is a tremendous shortage of housing for people who can pay and these women do not have any sort of income that enables them to pay? What they need is to be able to remove themselves from the refuge to some decent accommodation which is in the price bracket that they can afford so that they can go on living their lives. That is what the women were trying to say in the hall. They were saying 'Look at us. There is not anywhere for us to go.' This Bill gives them no joy whatsoever. It hands money over to the States which in the main have shown that they do not give two hoots about that sort of housing.

In Victoria-the Minister of Social Welfare has made kindly noises about refuges-we have a Minister for Housing who is not prepared to take up that challenge, who is not prepared to provide the sort of decent housing that these women can afford to pay out of their incomes. What he will do with that money is involve the private sector but he is involving the private sector by buying spec houses off the market at inflated rates in areas where people cannot use them. How many houses will the Minister be able to afford on this amount of money? That is the $64 question. We know, as I have said, that the Government is showing no concern about giving any sort of direction.

We also know that money for Aboriginal housing is involved in the Housing Assistance Bill. Again that money is handed to the States to do with as they see fit. We have seen how they see fit. Victoria has never been looked upon as an area that has an extraordinary Aboriginal problem in the sense that people talk about the Northern Territory, Western Australia or Queensland having an Aboriginal problem. But Victoria has thousands of Aboriginal people living there. They live there in squalor, without jobs and without hope. In this place, some three years ago, I raised the fact that money was given directly for Aboriginal housing to the Government of Victoria. Instead of being used in that way it was used to build carports. Houses that already had established garages had the garages pulled down and carports built. Houses that did not have a car had carports built. Houses that did not have a person in the house who could drive a car had carports built. Yet we had hundreds of Aboriginal families desperate for good housing. I raised the matter here, a periphery concern was expressed but nothing was done.

Recently money that was given to the Victorian Government for Aboriginal housing was given back to the Federal Government without being spent. If that is the attitude that the Victorian Government has taken up to this time when grants have been tied to Aboriginal housing, what sort of result will we get today when grants are not tied to Aboriginal housing? Still we have thousands of Aboriginal families who are desperate for some sort of decent accommodation. I ask the Federal Government to look closely at those two areas of desperate need-Aboriginal housing and housing for women who need somewhere to live which they can afford out of the pension or low income that so many of them earn and where they can bring up their children with decency.

The Federal Government has made big play in setting out this housing policy. It looks fine written on paper. I ask the Government to put some real teeth into it and to see that federal governments in this big, rich country provide that basic of decent living-decent housing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Housing Assistance Bill 1981. The first thing I would like to do is to congratulate the new Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh) on a very good Bill which recognises the philosophies of our Government parties in economics, in welfare and in Federal-State relations. The Commonwealth provides taxpayers' funds for welfare housing purposes; for defence and eligible ex-service personnel in the erection and purchase of homes; assistance to young married couples under the Homes Savings Grant Act; the operations of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation-for some time now; for assistance in the provision of accommodation for the aged; homes for public servants on transfer to the Territories; and separate provisions for Aboriginal housing.

SPEECH.PARA: Funds for these purposes have not been insignificant. For example, funds provided to the States for defence service homes between 1972 and 1980 amounted to $662,450,000. In addition to welfare housing there is also a legitimate and very substantial provision by both Federal and State governments to house itinerant government employees, such as members of the Armed Forces, public works, electricity, forestry and Telecom Australia employees and teachers and police. This list is by no means complete.

In the welfare field, the Commonwealth has provided funds for home ownership assistance and for rental housing assistance by a series of agreements and special grants and advances. I deal first with the agreements. Since 1945 the Commonwealth Government has provided the States with funds for welfare housing by a series of agreements made in 1945, 1956, 1961, 1966, 1973 and 1978. These funds have been provided partly by way of grants and partly by way of loans repayable over long terms and at low rates of interest. With regard to the special grants and advances, the States Grants (Housing) Act 1971 made provision for a housing grant to the States of $5.5m every year and the Housing Assistance Act 1973 authorised special advances to the States for rental housing. The 1978 housing agreement-made by my Government-between the Commonwealth and the six States, excluding the Northern Territory, expires on 30 June this year; so it is now necessary for a new agreement, and that is the purpose of this legislation.

If we look at the history of funds provided for these purposes since 1945, we find that the staggering total figure provided in actual money terms is $4,697.960m. That is not the amount in 1980-81 values but in itself it is a staggering sum which is difficult to conceive. If we convert that amount into 1979-80 dollar values we find that it works out at $11,214.532m of taxpayers' funds provided since 1945 for welfare housing. That staggering sum of money, as I say, is difficult to conceive but it would be the equivalent of about 350,000 dwellings in today's money. It would be equal to 15 fully equipped nuclear aircraft carriers with all the aircraft on board. If we were to stack $1m in $50 notes on the Senate table, the pile would be 9 feet high. If we tried to stack $11,214.532m in $50 bills we would have a staggering pile 102,000 feet high. That is an incredible amount of money which has been poured into welfare housing since 1945.

One would think that if the taxpayers of Australia provided funds for the equivalent of 350,000 dwellings since 1945 that would be the end of the problem. But let us look at the facts. Under these agreements, my State of Victoria has received, in actual funds, $1,275.133m. The Victorian Housing Commission has encouraged home ownership and of the 88,695 dwellings completed by the Commission to 30 June 1979, the Commission had sold 48,386 of these dwellings. According to the Victorian State Housing Commission, there were 13,861 applicants for rental accommodation as at 31 December 1980 compared with 14,336 at 31 December 1973. So in seven years we have managed the magnificent reduction of 1,475 applicants. What about the rest of Australia? The total number of applicants with all State housing authorities at 31 December 1973 was 85,537. In the five years, 1973-1978, $1,733.650m in actual funds was provided by the Commonwealth. Between 1978 and 1981 a further estimated $877 billion of taxpayers' funds was poured into welfare housing. In actual money terms, that is a total of $2,610.650m. With an average dwelling cost calculated at $28,000 between 1973 and 1978 and $29,500 between 1978 and 1981 that is the equivalent of 91,644 additional dwellings. Yet having spent all that taxpayers' money-$2.6 billion-and provided the equivalent of over 91,000 dwellings, what has happened to the demand? The demand was reduced by the magnificent number of 146 applicants-from 85,537 in 1973 to 85,391 in 1980. This is a bottomless pit.

In a 1980 survey the Australian Bureau of Statistics showed that housing costs as a proportion of income vary with the nature of occupancy from 13 per cent for households in the process of purchasing their own accommodation and 12.6 per cent-almost the same-for those households renting a furnished dwelling from a private landlord. But where the dwelling is rented from a government housing authority the statistics show the rental costs as only 7.1 per cent of income. So there is a demand for this sort of accommodation. Of course, there is a continuing waiting list, and the reason is that the accommodation is cheap.

I do not doubt that the taxpayers of Australia would be prepared to provide some cheap accommodation for the poor and the disadvantaged in our community. But is this happening? It is not so easy to determine the number of disadvantaged actually in government-provided dwellings but the Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty found that many people living in subsidised welfare housing were not poor and that many poor were not in subsidised housing. Available Bureau of Statistics figures which I have been able to look at indicate that the number of needy living in government rentals may very well be as low as one-third of the total accommodated in government rental housing. That means that approximately two-thirds of those still living in government-owned premises are not the needy. They are being subsidised by this low-level rental accommodation. What is happening here? What is wrong? Why are we able to spend this massive amount of money-the equivalent of $11 billion-and not solve this problem? Let us have a look at what happened in Sweden which, of course, is the laboratory of social democracy now being embraced by the former socialists opposite. (Quorum formed). When Senator Coleman drew attention to the state of the House, I was saying that, since 1945, the equivalent of over $11 billion of taxpayers' funds has been poured into welfare housing in Australia, and we still have a problem. I was about to ask: Why have we a problem? Let us look at what happened in the laboratory of social democracy, Sweden.

In 1942, Sweden had a housing shortage which was thought to have been brought about by the war. So in that year it introduced rent control to ensure that investors did not exploit the shortage-the sort of thing that one would expect Opposition senators to embrace. What happened? By 1944, the situation was worse so Sweden took the next big government step-the sort of social democratic step that one would expect from members of the Australian Labor Party if they ever get back into government-and created a bureaucracy to fix this problem. In 1944, Sweden's leading official expert on housing policy said that the liquidation of the housing market shortage was a once-for-all business which ought to be accomplished in a relatively short time, but he did not think he would be able to do it in a year. In 1942, the waiting time for dwellings in Stockholm was one month; by 1950, it was nine months; by 1953, it was 24 months; by 1956, it was 30 months; and, by 1958, it was a magnificent 40 months. This occurred under the bureaucracy introduced in Sweden to overcome its housing shortage problem. That was notwithstanding massive injections of taxpayers' funds into government-provided accommodation.

What happened? There is a simple answer if only it is faced up to by people who are realistic in this field. What happened was that the investors were kept out by the rent control provisions and more and more people wanted to live in the subsidised government-provided low rental accommodation. As I said before, people like to live in cheap accommodation if it is provided for them. Australia, with an expenditure of the equivalent of over $11 billion on welfare housing since 1945, has not progressively reduced demands for this welfare housing, nor has it liquidated waiting lists. In fact in Tasmania, where the largest per capita advances and grants have been made, there has been the greatest growth in waiting lists in Australia. In Sweden, and likewise in Australia, there has been an upsurge in demand by single persons for private dwellings and a drift from hostel and boarding house accommodation, a change of lifestyle and an increase, if you like, in expectations. Swedish figures indicate that the number of those in the unmarried group seeking private dwellings increased from 23 per cent in 1940 to 55 per cent in 1975, and the demand was by no means satisfied. What was happening was that teenagers were seeking to get away from their parents and to live in their own private accommodation provided by the taxpayers of Sweden who enabled these people to live away from their parents.

A similar phenomenon is apparent in Australia. Boarding colleges at universities, government hostels, youth hostels and similar types of accommodation are either closing or experiencing low occupancy rates. But the issue must be this: Is it reasonable to impose this massive demand on the taxpayers of Australia when the shift in accommodation preference in most cases is a matter of choice and not of necessity. Of course there is a need for welfare rental housing for those in actual need; but, while the Government subsidises housing in a way which keeps rentals below an economic return, private enterprise will not be encouraged to invest in that area. At the same time, more people will demand access to the subsidised rental premises. There will be growing demand for fewer premises and a greater demand on taxpayers' funds will be created. That is the simple truth, no matter how unpalatable it is to people such as Opposition senators, including muddled thinkers such as Senator Mason who had some words to say shortly before I rose.

The problem simply will not be solved by throwing money at it. I have tried to explain that fact to Senator Melzer in this chamber before. All she ever proposes is that we throw money at the problems, and the problems will not be solved in that way. My Government showed the way in the 1978 agreement. This agreement continues that course. However, in accordance with our policy of federalism, this Bill recognises that provision of welfare housing is the responsibility of the States. I hope that the other States follow the lead of my own State, Victoria, which, under its new Minister of Housing, the Honourable Jeff Kennett, has adopted most worthwhile policies.

I turn now to the details of the Bill and the problems of Victoria which once again is disadvantaged in comparison with other States. The present method of allocation of funds based on the 1973-74 arrangements is no longer relevant and has led to widespread iniquities. Queensland, with 15.6 per cent of the population of the States and the Northern Territory, is receiving 9.7 per cent of advances. New South Wales and Victoria are receiving less than the average per capita allocations while South Australia and, of course, Tasmania are receiving excessive allocations. The 1980-81 advances and grants in per capita terms were: New South Wales, $17.75; Victoria, $17.22; Queensland, $15.19; South Australia, $28.79; Western Australia, $21.80; and Tasmania, $37. Any analysis of the need for welfare housing recognises that the larger and the older a city the greater the need. One would think that New South Wales and Victoria, with Sydney and Melbourne, would get the largest per capita grants, but, no, that honour goes to Tasmania with a total population of 400,000. Next is South Australia, with Adelaide which has a population of only 930,000--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I believe the honourable senator is reading from a prepared speech. As you well know, that is contrary to the relevant Standing Order.
—The honourable senator is speaking from copious notes in the usual way. I call Senator Lewis.

—Compare that with Sydney, which has a population of 3.15 million, and Melbourne, which has a population of 2.71 million. There are other inequalities, as demonstrated by the difference in capital costs between States, and, regrettably, demonstrated efficiencies in Victoria as compared with New South Wales are not rewarded.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to replace the States Grants (Housing) Act 1971, which I mentioned earlier, the Housing Assistance Act 1973 and the Housing Assistance Act 1978 with an agreement that will operate for five years instead of three years and which will facilitate home ownership for those able to afford it but not able to gain it through the private market. It will provide sufficient rental housing for those members of the community who are deemed to be in need of governmental assistance at a price which is within their capacity to pay. It will also provide assistance for home ownership and assistance with rental accommodation in the most efficient way. It is proposed to exclude from eligibility those not in need, to minimise continued availability of assistance to those no longer in need and to accord benefits which are designed so that the assistance being provided is related to the particular family's or individual's current economic and social circumstances.

The Commonwealth, under the Bill, will provide a base level of $200m per annum for the five years of the agreement with additional funding to be determined each year in the Budget context. Of this base level, $54m will be earmarked for rental housing assistance to disadvantaged groups, such as pensioners and Aboriginals, and will be in the form-I use the Minister's words, not mine-of 'non-repayable interest free grants'. I suspect that that phrase is slightly tautologous. I would have thought that any grant would be non-repayable and interest free. These earmarked funds will be allocated between States on a population needs basis, as at present. The balance of the base of $200m-in other words, the other $146m-will be in the form of advances repayable over 53 years at an interest rate of 4 1/4 per cent per annum. That is not bad money; I would not mind some of it myself. In the first year of the agreement these advances, plus any additional non-earmarked funds, will be allocated on an historical basis and thereafter will be gradually adjusted to an equal per capita basis over a nine-year period with a condition that no State receives less than 5 per cent of the united base amount of $146m. That seems to me to be far too long a period. The implementation of an equal per capita allocation will take 10 years, and that must surely be to the disadvantage of New South Wales and Victoria. I would have thought that the Government could look at the implementation of that over a period of five years without drastically disadvantaging the other States.

The package of welfare housing policies announced on 27 May this year by the Victorian Housing Minister, Mr Kennett, directs assistance to where there is a genuine need among low income families. The greater involvement by the private sector and the move to have the Housing Commission act as a provider of housing assistance rather than a land and housing developer in competition with the private sector is particularly welcome and should free significant funds for a worthwhile attack on the Commission's waiting lists. The spot buying of existing houses will avoid the need for large housing estates with their attendant social problems. I was fascinated when Senator Melzer said that it was a terrible thing for the Victorian Government to be buying houses in suburbs instead of building complexes.

TALK.START.PARA: —She didn't say that at all.

—She did. Anyone driving into Melbourne from the airport who looks at the ghastly buildings which are many storeys high in the North Melbourne area could not suggest that the Housing Commission of Victoria has not made a wise decision in deciding not to enter into the land development and building area but to try to buy houses which are available on the market at spot prices in order to try to solve its problems. I fail to understand Senator Melzer's logic in suggesting that that is not the wisest policy for Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: The initiatives taken by the Victorian Government are most refreshing and come at a time when the Commonwealth has been urging the States to shrug off traditional welfare housing policies which are nonsense in favour of more innovative and cost effective programs directed at the genuinely disadvantaged. Victoria has properly addressed these problems and in due course Victoria will progressively reap the rewards. In the meantime, Victoria continues to suffer inequity in the distribution of the funds. All funds, apart from those earmarked for disadvantaged groups, will be distributed in 1981-82 in the same proportion as advances were allocated in 1980-81. Over the remaining years of the agreement there will be a progressive advancement towards a per capita allocation. As I said before, it is my view that it would be far better for the States if that progressive allocation were made over a five-year period instead of a 10-year period.
