Finally, I say that the legislation demonstrates this Government's belief that State governments are best placed to know the needs of the needy in their States and allows the States to tailor their programs to meet those needs. It also attempts to ensure that the vast majority of Australians who are owners or owner-purchasers of their own homes will not be burdened for evermore with taxes to provide housing for those who may very well be able to afford to accommodate themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment briefly on the matter brought forward by Senator Lewis. I shall be brief because of the time constraints and because the general thrust of the opposition to the Government's stringent or stingy housing assistance policies have been outlined previously in the Senate and in the House of Representatives. However, let me make it perfectly clear that the figures show that, compared to other areas of Federal expenditure, housing has fared badly indeed. Let me deal with the actual outlays in various areas by the Federal Government over the last 14 years. The rate of growth for housing over the period is 130 per cent. That should be compared with the figure of 850 per cent for social security and welfare, 910 per cent for health, 1,570 per cent for education and 233 per cent for defence. In fact, in a period when more and more people have needed government assistance for either home purchase or rental, Commonwealth outlays for housing have shown very little increases. The facts show that in real terms public housing is the only category to have fallen over this period.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to challenge certain statements by Senator Lewis, for whom I have the utmost respect. I wish to challenge his rather parochial view on this matter when he suggested as I understand him, that we ought to be moving to a distribution of funds solely on a per capita basis. In fact, he even went further and suggested that housing finance ought to be provided to the older cities. I cannot follow the honourable senator's logic at all. I would have thought--

TALK.START.PARA: —There must be a greater need in Melbourne than in Launceston.

—There are more hills in Launceston that there are in Melbourne. I would have thought that funding, and disbursement of funds for welfare housing would surely be determined on the basis of the recipients--
—On the basis of need.

—Yes, on the need. I appreciate the interjection of the honourable senator. I propose to refer to the comparative needs of our two States. The basis should be the need of families for welfare housing, those which are disadvantaged in particular. I propose to give some statistics in order to compare the situation in Victoria with that in Tasmania. Firstly, Tasmania has more large families than has Victoria. It has more families that are relatively poor. When the last Commonwealth Census was taken 53.7 per cent of Tasmanian families were described as relatively poor. For Victoria the percentage was 48.6. In terms of recipients of pensions, and/or social security benefits, expressed as a percentage of the population aged 15 years or older, the figure for Tasmania is 24.4 per cent, compared with 20.7 per cent for Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard a great deal about the need for housing for the single parent group. In Tasmania it represents 4.1 per cent of total families and in Victoria 3.3 per cent. The percentage of the labour force which is unemployed is also higher in my State than it is in Victoria. Again, in Tasmania 5.1 per cent of the population are handicapped, against 4.6 per cent in Victoria. In respect of each of those criteria the situation in Tasmania demands far greater attention than does that in Victoria.

I did not set out to engage in a dog fight between the States over this important matter-fighting, as it were, over the division of the cake rather than over its size. It would have done us all good to join in fighting over the size of the cake rather than the way in which it was divided to point out the way in which, in the last 14 years, its size in real terms has diminised. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) might also consider the need for part of the total sum available to be provided by way of grants rather than as has been suggested. At present, the States cannot meet a number of very deserving situations because the sum made available for welfare housing by the Commonwealth is too greatly tied down. I propose to quote from a letter which I have received from Mr Darrel Baldock, the Minister for Housing in Tasmania, a gentleman who would be well known to Senator Lewis. In the letter, which I understand has been sent to all Tasmanian senators, Mr Baldock states:

The Agreement will not make provision for guaranteed annual grants for innovative housing schemes. This is a major blow because the scope to engage in new less capital intensive rental housing measures has been limited which will result in lengthening waiting periods.

In that respect he makes a suggestion which I pass on to the Minister for his consideration. Its acceptance would not alter the total amount of money to be provided to the States, if the Government is firmly committed to that course. He states:
This could be remedied by simply making a proportion of the untied base funds of $200m grants available for innovative purposes.

Mr Baldock suggests that the provision of an amount of $30m would be reasonable. As I understand the situation, none of the other States objects to that particular course being followed. If I am wrong, I hope that the Minister will correct me. If not, the Minister ought to take that suggestion on board. I shall raise it at the Committee stage.

For the benefit of Senator Lewis and of Victorians generally I point out that over the years the Tasmanian Government has regularly committed, in its budget, a hefty sum for welfare housing. For example, in 1980-81, 8.35 per cent of its capital funds and 1.23 per cent of its revenue funds were devoted to housing. In addition, I remind the Senate of a statement made by the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh) on 17 May 1981 in a news release entitled, 'Victoria belly-aching over housing funds'. It stated that Mr McVeigh said that in 1979-80 the Victorian Government's contribution to welfare housing, from its own funds, was approximately $6 per head of population compared with a national average of about $16. The figure for South Australia was $47. The Tasmanian figure was second highest, at $27. In Western Australia it was $23, in Queensland $17 and in New South Wales $13. They are not my words; they are those of the Minister for Housing and Construction. I am pleased to note, as Senator Lewis has pointed out, that apparently there is in Victoria a new broom which will sweep clean. Mr Kennett has indeed made some forward-looking statements on this subject. I congratulate Senator Lewis for that. But I urge him and other honourable senators to argue not so much about the division of the cake but about the inadequacy of the cake. I believe it would be in our best long term interests and in the best long term interest of those people who need welfare housing for a combined effort to be made by the States and in this States House to achieve a better result in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the debate on this Bill a variety of views has come forward, particularly from the Opposition. I think one central theme comes through clearly; that is, there is a fundamental difference in philosophy and approach between the Opposition and the Government on this matter. Certainly that came through in respect of other legislation with which we were dealing yesterday and in respect of which the States are in agreement with the Commonwealth. In this matter there are perhaps three areas that demonstrate that fundamental difference. The first is that the Government believes in providing the States with as much untied finance as possible for them to determine their own sets of priorities as they see them within their own borders. That clearly came through in the very real point which Senator Harradine was seeking to make in respect of innovative housing in that a substantial amount of money is to be made available to Tasmania to enable it to provide housing which it sees as necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: But, of course, the Commonwealth has put a definite embargo on a certain proportion-roughly one-quarter-of the funds and has said that those funds must be made available to provide housing for disadvantaged groups, particularly Aborigines and pensioners. That maintains the Federal Government's interest in those areas in which it has a great deal of interest and to which it is required by the Constitution to take a particular approach.

Another fundamental difference between the Government and the Opposition is the user-pays principle. That spills over into how we can best deliver the maximum quality and quantity of housing for those who need it most. It is that which the Opposition will not accept. The amendment moved by Senator Gietzelt touches on the areas which we are discussing and draws attention to what the Opposition considers to be the deficiencies of the Federal Government's approach. In fact they are the strengths of the approach in that the Government sees a need for the States to amplify and develop their own systems by which they can get the maximum value out of their present stock of housing and so that they can provide the maximum quantity of housing for the disadvantaged and for those in greatest need.

I think Senator Archer earlier put his finger on the point when he indicated that 72 per cent of people occupying the State government's stock of welfare housing earn incomes which are more than 120 per cent of the poverty level, as determined by the Henderson inquiry in 1975. That highlights the fact that those people are occupying housing to the disadvantage of those who are below the poverty line, and it is that which we are seeking to redress by the approach contained in this legislation. Senator Archer also did us a service by drawing our attention to the Schedule to the Bill which sets out the agreement with the States. Clause 33 of the agreement touches on rents charged for dwellings in the States and the movement of those rents towards market values. Clause 34, which is the converse, demonstrates this Government's real desire to help those in the greatest need, as determined by the States, by providing them with rental rebates. In those areas we clearly show our concern for the disadvantaged and for those in greatest need. This legislation was designed to provide a service to those who need it most within the given framework of the limited resources.

Other speakers have talked about the base level of funding which is set at an annual rate of $200m. Most have tended to ignore the fact that the second reading speech stated that there will be a reappraisal of that amount of money each year and that the amount will be topped up each year. Of course, in each case that will be a Budget decision to be taken by the Federal Government at the time. Furthermore, it seemed that Senator Mason missed the point that this is part of a five-year agreement, a long term agreement, which provides the States with the opportunity of planning their housing programs properly. I believe that is precisely the objective they seek and consequently is the sort of program which has their full support.

I believe only one other matter of relevance emerged in the debate; that is, the continuing commitment of this Government to providing the highest level of housing for the population. When we take into account the fact that there is a level of 72 per cent of home ownership in this country and that that is higher than in most other countries, we can acknowledge that both public and private enterprise have done a sterling job in providing the stock of housing in Australia, which on its own, is improving in quality as years go by. It is interesting to note, as Senator Archer brought out during his remarks, that only 9 per cent of the total stock of housing is public housing-defined as houses provided by governments. That indicates a rising level of affluence. It indicates that housing policies in this country in the last 35 to 40 years have been tremendously successful and that this Government is dedicated to a continuing improvement. The Government will not support the Opposition's amendment. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 3 June, on motion by Senator Chaney:
That the Bill be now read a first time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill provides for the validation until 31 December 1981 of duties collected in pursuance of Customs Tariff Proposals No. 6 (1981) introduced into the Parliament on 14 May and proposals No. 7 (1981) introduced on 26 May. Under section 226 of the Customs Act the collection of duties in pursuance of Customs Tariff Proposals is protected against legal challenge for six months or until the close of the session of Parliament, whichever occurs first. The introduction and passage of a validation Bill is therefore a necessary machinery measure which takes over from section 226 pending the introduction of a Customs Tariff Amendment Bill, anticipated for the Budget sittings, to enact the changes contained in the proposals.

The tariff changes contained in the proposals validated by this Bill arise, in the main, from decisions of the Government on recommendations made by the Industries Assistance Commission in their reports entitled 'Certain Monomers, Prepolymers and Goods of the Silicone Type' and 'Wheel chairs'. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Customs Tariff Validation Bill is to validate the collection of customs duties imposed on imports of silicone products and wheelchairs. Both of the industries being thus protected are quite significant but, in fact, very small employing only 110 employees and 55 employees respectively. The Opposition has no objection to that part of the Bill which deals with silicone products but we have very profound concern with that part of it which deals with wheelchairs. We express that concern in the form of an amendment to the motion for the second reading which has been circulated. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of Motion, add ', but the Senate-
(1) expresses its concern that the Customs Duties validated by the Bill in relation to wheelchairs will maintain the high cost of these necessary aids for the disabled;

(2) calls upon the Government immediately to review its decision in relation to wheelchairs with a view to replacing the tariff arrangements provided in the Bill with a bounty scheme for local producers; and
(3) condemns the Government for its failure to implement its promise for a programme of aids for disabled people including the free provision of wheelchairs'.

The concern that the Opposition has thus articulated does not, regrettably, appear to be shared by the Government. The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr Moore, when this Bill was debated in the other place two nights ago-admittedly it was debated between 1.45 and 2.20 in the morning, so I guess there may conceivably be some other explanation for his terseness-found himself able to do no more than sneer at what he described as the Australian Labor Party's bleeding heart on this issue and to say that he had no sympathy for the contributions made to that debate by the Labor Party spokespersons, the shadow Minister, Mr Hurford, Mrs Child and Mrs Kelly. I hope that contribution will be remembered when the community-and, in particular, those disabled members of it who are extremley interested in measures of this kind-comes to assess the contribution of this Government to the International Year of Disabled Persons.

The essence of the argument is simply that-and I hope my brevity on the subject will not be taken in any way as a reflection of the degree of importance with which the Opposition regards this matter-prior to 1 January 1980 there was a tariff on the importation of wheelchairs of 15 per cent which was, of course, bad enough for those obliged to purchase this indispensible item of non-luxury equipment. On that date-1 January 1980-following the removal of United Kingdom preferences in this area as, indeed, in others, that duty escalated to 34 per cent in the case of mechanically propelled wheelchairs and 36 per cent in the case of manually propelled wheelchairs. This, in fact, produced a purchase price for, say, electrically propelled wheelchairs of which something like $1,000 was represented by the import duty tax slug which the purchaser had to pay. This represents-without my needing to labour the point-a fantastic imposition for people who in all sorts of other ways have not only physical and psychological constraints upon them but also very large financial constraints.

Now, after innumerable representations on the matter and consideration by the Industries Assistance Commission which, in fact, reported to the Government some time ago-December 1980-the Government has decided to reduce the duties from that high of 34 per cent and 36 per cent to 30 per cent in the first year, 25 per cent in the second year and 20 per cent thereafter. Of course, that is better than what it had been and that is why we do not oppose this legislation outright. What the Government seems to be quite failing to appreciate is that any duty on equipment of this kind is just too much to pay for these indispensible pieces of equipment. It represents a very unfair additional imposition on those who are already bearing more than their fair share of life's handicaps.

In the 1980 Budget the Government did, in fact-as perhaps the Minister will remind us if he gives us the courtesy of any reply at all on this Bill-make an allocation of $700,000 to a program of aids for the disabled, including assistance with respect to the purchase of wheelchairs. That was to commence from 1 April this year. However, the Opposition understands that that scheme is not yet in operation. Like so much else in the International Year of Disabled Persons it is a matter of cosmetic huffing and puffing rather than any commitment to hard, real assistance. Perhaps even more significantly, even when this scheme is set in operation and even if in a full year something over $2m is spent under this head and the expenditure commitment is maintained in the future, that still will not be enough to cover anything like the total cost of purchases of wheelchairs in this community which rank, I believe, at something over $4m per annum.

The situation is that the Government's commitment to assistance in this area is very shaky, very superficial and totally inadequate. The answer in this area as in so many other areas of industry assistance and protection, which we debate from time to time in this place, is that if the industry in question is incapable of surviving without public assistance in some form or another, the way to provide that assistance is through the mechanism of bounties which will ensure that the consumers in question, who in this case are clearly more deserving than most, will not have to bear selectively the cost of outlays which ought to be shared across the community as a whole. The Opposition's amendment which I have read summarises these various concerns. I hope that it will, in fact, be supported on all sides of the Senate.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be added (Senator Evans's amendment) be added.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) do the chamber the courtesy of responding now to some of the points made on this important Bill at the second reading stage, which he apparently found himself unable to do at that stage?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall respond briefly to Senator Evans's remarks. The point needs to be made that this is a matter of industry protection and it is under that head that this is handled. It is being handled by the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs. The tariff is the usual form of industry assistance that is provided in these circumstances. Indeed, the companies were those producers of wheelchairs in Australia. I think Senator Evans would acknowledge that it is important to have a local wheelchair industry and not to rely totally on imports, given that there could be a cut-off in supplies and so on.
—Why not a bounty?

—I have answered that. I have said that this is a matter of industry protection. This is the more ordinary way of providing that kind of care. The industry was strongly in favour of a tariff rather than bounties. Accordingly, the Government took that decision on the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without requests; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Messner) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 29 May, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bill be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak on the matter of Aboriginal affairs in the first reading debate on the Supply Bill (No. 1) 1981-82. I am sorry that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) is not here, but I did advise him that I would be speaking. The opportunity for discussion of Aboriginal affairs has not arisen frequently in this session and consequently we have to take the opportunity of speaking on it at the first reading stage of other Bills. I reiterate that, as far as Aborigines are concerned, this Government, from 13 December 1975, has continually gone backwards with the program initiated by the Labor Government. The program is being continuously and considerably reduced in real terms by this Government. The words of the then shadow Minister, now a judge of the Federal Court of Australia, in November and December 1975 must often haunt and mock him. He distributed a program, particularly in the north-west reserves, among the Pitjantjatjara people and in the Walpiri people's area, saying that things would be better, not worse, under a Liberal-Country Party government. Things have continued to get worse.

SPEECH.PARA: A long time ago a document was exchanged between the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Chaney. It set up a program effectiveness review, now commonly known as the PER report, which is still a classified document. I see no reason why it should not be made public in view of the fact that the Prime Minister asked for it to be on his desk by April 1980 so that the recommendations could be implemented immediately. I think that the report became available about May 1980; a year ago. I am not going to quote all of the recommendations but I am going to refer to specific parts. The PER report identified as a major task:
Increasing effective Aboriginal involvement in development, implementation, and evaluation of health and health related programs . . .

Instead, we see these programs being annihilated in some areas and handed over to the States in other areas. But for the very brave action of Professor Hollows in resigning and drawing public attention to what was about to happen to the trachoma campaign, it also would have gone down the drain. The report went on to summarise the points as:

Clarifying policy and administrative responsibilities; increasing effective Aboriginal utilisation of general health care; especially primary care, services; channelling finance to services which are more acceptable to Aboriginals and more effective in improving Aboriginal health status; tackling the environmental factors adversely affecting Aboriginal health; and establishing continuous oversight of implementation.
The report of the Program Effectiveness Review went on to state in more detail:
Aboriginal communities and organisations being involved in implementing action upon which the Government might decide;
Establishing a small national all-Aboriginal body (and, where practicable, related State/Territory bodies) to be involved effectively in programs affecting Aboriginal health.

There is a whole number of recommendations. As much of the contents of this report have already appeared in the Press, although other sections have not, I hope that the Government will see fit to release the document. Another recommendation reads:
Greater priority being given to matters closely related to health, such as housing, water supply, sanitation and electricity for which responsibility largely lies with State and local government.

It is true that the responsibility does lie with State and local government in some of these fields. But the Federal Government has done nothing to ensure that the States supply the services which they ought to be supplying. In fact, in some States, particularly Western Australia and Queensland, money allocated for the affairs of the Aboriginal communities are diverted into other areas. About training and employment the report states:
Greater employment of Aboriginals in all health delivery systems;
recognised Aboriginal health worker qualifications being developed by the States and integrated in the existing health professional and sub-professional structure.
There is then a reference to specific health needs. The report recommends:

Consideration of areas where special measures might be needed or existing programs strengthened such as dental care, ear diseases, nutrition, mental health and alcohol-related problems; continuation of the National Trachoma and Eye Health program;
It also suggests:
Development of a national system of Aboriginal health statistics.

This was the subject of a question which I asked the Minister yesterday or the day before. He is not sure who in fact is to compile those statistics. I hope that he will come up with that information before the end of this session. In relation to the same project, paragraph 1.22 on page 17 of the report states:

The PER, like the Ruddock Committee and a number of other inquiries, faced major difficulties with data. There is no routine identification of Aboriginals in statistical collections. In the general health field, statistical information is not complete. In the field of Aboriginal health, statistics are often not collected in an integrated way. There is still a refusal or reluctance to include separate identification of Aboriginals in statistics on the part of some authorities involved in the collection of data.

That reluctance is easily understandable in Queensland and Western Australia and, until quite recently, of course, also in the Northern Territory, it has become embarrassing to include some of these figures under the ethnic groupings. They are much worse than the figures for the average population. Paragraph 1.23 reads:

Insufficient progress has been made in tackling the administrative tasks involved in routine collections of vital statistics on Aboriginals. This definitely remains so even in the ACT despite 10 years of effort.

It is an indictment on the Government that it has not been able to get its act together-I think that is now the popular 'in' term-so that this data could be collected. It is at least six or seven years-probably, almost 10 years-since it was spelled out very clearly in political reports presented in this chamber and in another place that this was vital if a properly programmed health scheme was to be put into operation. On page 44 of the report a reference is made to the availability of medical services delivered to Aboriginals. It states:

Access is good for hospitals, moderate and variable for GPs and poor in relation to specialists. Lack of access to GPs increases use of hospital facilities. There are major socio-cultural and financial barriers to access (including lack of information) and significant geographical variations, e.g. between urban, rural, rural town, (fringe) and remote;

Quality of care, when received and at the levels available, is technically satisfactory, but there can be significant problems in relation to such factors as attitudes, and also socio-cultural differences and lack of income;
Program organisation is generally centralised and gives little opportunity for Aboriginal input, resulting in the fitting of Aboriginals to the general programs rather than vice versa;
Impact on health status-given the large volume of health resources available to be utilised by Aboriginals and the technical competence of health personnel, the results achieved are disappointing.
I think those are very significant words. The report continues:
Aboriginal involvement is negligible.
On page 48 of the report, paragraph 3.15, another significant paragraph, reads:
The PER believes that transport is a major problem in some areas. The heavy incidence of unemployment among Aboriginals-varying from 37 per cent nationwide-
That is somewhere around five times the national level of unemployment-

To nearly 100 per cent in some communities-their low average income and high ratio of dependence to income-recipients (many of whom are welfare beneficiaries) . . . makes it more difficult for them to travel at their own expense to seek medical advice or treatment.
Paragraph 3.16 reads:

The PER considers that the disproportionately high Aboriginal hospital utilisation rates 2 to 3 times that of non-Aboriginals, even higher for children, but with a rate of surgery 2 to 3 times lower . . .
The latter point is remarkable. The report lists the conditions for which patients are admitted. It sets out a series of illnesses. Pneumonia and gastroenteritis are two major causes. It reads:
. . . indicate inadequacies in the provision of primary health care to Aboriginals and the generally poor environmental conditions in which they live.
Paragraph 3.17 on page 49 reads:

Aboriginals receive little benefit, despite great need, from existing rehabilitation services; also there has been little effort to modify these services so as to render them more effective for Aboriginal clients in their environment; there is a serious lack of provision of mental health services for Aboriginals both in areas where Aboriginal communities are most numerous and within the communities themselves.
On page 50 of the report-this is the last paragraph that I wish to quote-it is stated:

Aboriginal dental health is extremely poor, and access to private care is difficult and costly. The result is poor dental care, ill health and considerable avoidable suffering. Government schemes cover segments of the school population, means-tested assistance for adults (normally available only in metropolitan areas), and limited provisions through some AMSs and States Grants programs . . .

Aboriginal dental health services, with the exception of one State where some 30 per cent to 40 per cent of the people are able to receive treatment through the school dental service, are deplorably weak. I suggest that that report ought to be widely distributed. It ought to be made available to medical organisations, Aboriginal communities and others to give them an opportunity to comment on it and to suggest the strong points which should be implemented. Of course, the Aboriginal people themselves ought to have the first call on that.

I turn now to the almost tragic situation which is being faced in Queensland where a great wall of silence has again been thrown up about what is likely to happen to Aboriginal communities on the lands they now occupy under the existing Aborigines Act of 1971 and amendments and the Torres Strait Islanders Act 1971 and amendments. There has been a change of Minister because the former Minister, Mr Charles Porter, did not contest his seat in the 1980 State election. He has now been replaced by Mr Tomkins who has the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs tagged on to his other ministerial responsibilities. I was disappointed when my colleague, Senator Ryan, asked a question in this chamber on 27 May 1981 about what the Commonwealth Government proposed to do. To put the matter in its proper context, I will read the question together with the Minister's response. Senator Ryan said:

I ask the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs whether he is aware of reports that the Queensland Government intends in August of this year to abolish the Aboriginal reserves in Queensland, to incorporate reserve lands in local government areas and to rescind the notorious Queensland Aborigines Act and Torres Strait Islanders Act? Does the Minister acknowledge that these steps would leave Queensland Aboriginals without any rights to the land that they have been occupying for generations? What steps has the Federal Government taken to ensure the bringing down of legislation that will provide for secure, permanent tenure to Queensland's Reserves by Aboriginals who are currently living on them? Will the Government take steps to ensure that such legislation is prepared concurrently with the expected action of the Queensland Government?
The Minister gave one of those normal replies that both he and his predecessors have been inclined to give. In other words, all he did was evade the issue. The Minister said:
I am not sure that Senator Ryan does Aboriginals in Queensland a service by assuming that certain events will occur.

If that sort of comment were not made by Senator Ryan and other honourable senators on this side and by people of good will outside the Parliament, the change in policy in Queensland would probably be even more drastic. We have maintained that for a start if these two Acts were to be abolished then at least the reserve lands now occupied in the various communities ought to be given over to the Aboriginal communities and there should be proper land rights legislation so that they may retain them in perpetuity and that under other legislation dealing with land rights they be given time to look at other areas to which they have some traditional attachment or to which traditional attachment can be proved. The Minister went on to say:

I have been following, as has she and other honourable senators, the Press comments on what might be happening in relation to Queensland's Aboriginal reserves. She will be aware, as I was, of the statement made by the Premier of Queensland during the last election campaign. She will also be aware of his promise to consult widely.

That statement is a fabrication. I am not saying that it was the Minister's fabrication because he was told, not by the official spokesman for Aboriginal Affairs in Queensland, but by the Premier of Queensland, that there are wide consultations. With the exception of some people on most councils, most people on nearly all of the councils have very little say on what goes on. The council at Yarrabah is probably one of the most outspoken and decisions which come from that council would not coincide with what the Minister in this place has said. The memberships of other councils are virtually hand picked, by devious means, by the Department of Aboriginal and Islander Advancement which has no authority at all. However, it is still the DAIA officers in many communities who make the decisions and hand them down to black community councils which are virtually only allowed to act as a figurehead. So the promise to consult widely is a non-event. That sort of consultation is not going on, has not gone on and will not go on in relation to any changes in the ownership of land. Senator Peter Baume's answer continued:

Unlike Senator Ryan, I have been able to make contact with the new Minister for Water Resources and Aboriginal and Island Affairs in Queensland, Mr Tomkins. I have been able, in fact, to visit some communities with him and to discuss some of these problems. I was very heartened by a Press release, dated 15 May, by Mr Tonkims, who after all is the responsible Minister in the Queensland Government, in which he gave assurances that no one would be evicted from his home or from a reserve as a result of any move to repeal the Aborigines Act and Torres Strait Islanders Act.
The Minister also stated:

. . . no matter what happens to the relevant Acts the reserves would retain their status under the Queensland Lands Act . . . I would hope that Senator Ryan would welcome that statement as much as would anybody else. She may indicate by interjection that she welcomes it.

That was a very feeble attempt on behalf of the Minister to see whether he could intimidate or compromise the spokesman on Aboriginal Affairs on our side of the House. None of us welcome that statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would welcome the sentiment expressed in the Press release, would you not?

—No one welcomes sentiments that are phoney. This is an entirely phoney sentiment. It is a wonder that Senator Baume, with his fairly high degree of intelligence, is not able to pick this up. The Ministers in the Queensland Government, over a long periods, have not been the spokesmen for the department. Instead the spokesman has been the permanent head of the Department, the well-known Mr Paddy Killoran in consultation with the Premier of the day. This situation has applied particularly over the last ten years with the current Premier. In fact, the Aborigines are not given the right to make their decisions. I remember an occasion on Palm Island when a very good council took the right to make a statement. A ballot was held to have the council removed. That ballot was a phoney. The Department obtained the services-its officers were in it up to their elbows-of a tame Aborigine from Cherbourg. He was the Chairman of a committee that compiled a report. When he was asked at a Catholic land council meeting in Toowoomba why he put certain sections into the report he admitted that he had not seen it. That is how involved he was in the affairs of his own people. In response to further question he stated who wrote the report and it was a white man who was unsympathetic to Aborigines. The end result was that the ballot that was taken on Palm Island worked because of the intimidation and bullying that went on. When the lists were analysed, it was found that people who had been dead for two years had signed the petition. So much for the so-called democracy that operates in Aboriginal areas in Queensland! The Minister went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Tomkins has said that no matter what happens to the relevant Acts the reserves would retain their status under the Queensland Lands Act . . .

What precisely does that mean? I do not think that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs knows what it means. Mr Tomkins does not know what it means. The Aborigines certainly do not know what it means and we do not know what it means. It is a case of those who draft new legislation pulling the wool over people's eyes so that too many questions will not be asked. Probably the Minister will not recall, because it was in the time when Senator Chaney was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, when leases were given at Yarrabah after a near riotous situation developed because of rebellion against what was happening. Aborigines were to be given little plots of land. The leases were to be given under the Queensland Land Act. They were not assured of any permanency. A crop of beans may take three to four months to grow. The lease could be cancelled before that crop matured. A crop of bananas may take 18 months to two years to grow and the lease could have been taken out just before those plants produced bunches of bananas. That sort of hokey pokey is not suitable to the Aborigines of Queensland or to people in any other part of Australia. But unfortunately it appears that the Aborigines in Queensland are the very people who will now have to accept that problem in the very near future. The Minister went on to say:
. . . because it is under that Act that the land is set aside as Aboriginal reserve land. I am sure that we are all delighted by that particular assurance.
The Minister might be delighted with that particular assurance because it enables him to push the problem under the rug where nobody can see it. The Minister continued:

Mr Tomkins also stated in his Press release that moves to repeal the Acts were being carried out in a spirit of full co-operation with the elected representatives of the Aboriginal people. I am sure that all honourable senators would want to know that the Queensland Government is acting in co-operation with the Aboriginal people and taking into account their views. Mr Tomkins said that Aboriginal views would be taken into full account when decisions were made about the relevant legislation. I have with me a copy of the Press statement . . .
He then presented it as though it was the first prize he had ever got at school.
Senator Ryan asked further questions on this matter. I will quote part of one:
My question is: What assurances do we have from the Federal Government that steps will be taken to ensure that Aboriginals living on reserves will have secure title to that land?
Senator Peter Baume replied:

The Federal Government would want all Aboriginals in Queensland to enjoy secure tenure of the land on which they live. We would be concerned that they should not lose that secure tenure. Apart from that, the question is hypothetical and I do not propose to deal with it further.
He then moved his foot around and pushed that matter under the carpet too.

In this city at the moment-there has been for the last two days-is a delegation of Aborigines, all of whom come from Queensland. I was impressed by what was said by one of the delegates, Rachael Wilson, from Palm Island, who, together with some of her people met a number of us yesterday. She said that her people were not interested in the sorts of land rights they are likely to get under the Queensland Government. What they want is for this Government to act in accordance with the recommendations of the report submitted by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. That report stated in quite clear terms that there appears to be quite strong proof that the 1967 referendum and the subsequent legislation do in fact give to the national government the right to implement land rights in any State or Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —It certainly does.

—I thank Senator Evans for his comment. Since the publication of that report, I have talked with many legal people and they agree with the Committee's findings. But, again, this Government is not game to front up to any likely political clash that it will have. I now warn Senator Peter Baume, as the responsible Minister, that he is bringing down a very great battle on his head by not being more positive and doing something that can be seen to be done and which can be done with some sort of permanency. This Government is going to be fooled by the Queensland Government saying it will hand over leases in six months, 12 months or two years, or whatever shocking agreement this Government has entered into. This is in spite of the fact that we on this side of the chamber warned the Government what would happen in relation to Mornington Island and Aurukun. The Government should not tell us that they are satisfactory agreements because they are not. They are merely a stop gap measure and they will not have permanent value so far as the Aboriginal people are concerned. There is a general ground swell throughout the Aboriginal and island communities. In particular, I nominate Yarrabah which is well organised. The Aboriginals there are not going to sit and cop it for much longer. They have had a stomach full of everything that goes on so far as the Queensland Government is concerned and they are rapidly getting to the stage where they do not think the Minister has enough political intestinal fortitude to stand up and do battle for them. So, if the Minister is not careful, he also will be run over in the political rebellion that takes place. Palm Island is another piece of tinder which needs only a match to light it. At the moment it is unfortunate that the Queensland Government has supplied the box of matches and it looks as though this Government will strike the match. At Kowenyama another land rights movement is gaining credibility and it will spread through Cape York. It is all very well for the Government to say: 'We have them wrapped up in fences. They are not going to hurt us. Nothing will go wrong'. We will do exactly as Mr Bjelke-Petersen tells us to do-we will accept some sort of funny leases. But all this will do is increase the psychological disturbance of 60,000-plus Aborigines and islanders in Queensland. The Government is not going to overcome the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: The Courier-Mail of early this week reported a statement by Dr 'Nugget' Coombs. He was one of the original trinity installed in office after the 1967 referendum to set up a ground plan and lay down guidelines as to how that legislation could best by implemented at the national government level. The newspaper article states:
The Federal Government should compulsorily acquire the Queensland Government's aboriginal reserves if there were state moves to abolish them, Dr H. C. Coombs said yesterday.
Dr Coombs, Aboriginal Treaty Committee chairman, said this in an open letter to the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser. The letter was published in a weekend newspaper.
Dr Coombs said the committee was deeply concerned at Queensland Government's plans to abolishing existing reserves and incorporate them into local government areas.

He said the Queensland Government also hoped, by formally ending the discriminatory Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders Act, to remove the justification for a boycott of the 1982 Brisbane Commonwealth Games.
'The abolition of the reserves would end all prospect of aboriginal rights to land being recognised in Queensland and deprive the communities of the last vestiges of self management', he said.
'The Commonwealth Government clearly has the constitutional power to act.'

Of course if this is done for political window dressing it will only be the thin edge of the wedge so far as the State Government of Queensland is concerned. It will want to do so in the hope that the Commonwealth Games to be held in Brisbane will not be boycotted. Of course we have that great international group of leaders to whom the Prime Minister is now sending out his gold embossed invitations who also might boycott the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. One does not know. A couple of people are bending over backwards to try to get on side with the African nations, but they are doing nothing at all for our indigenous people who are in a worse situation now than when this Government took over five years ago.
Let us hear the remarks of the Queensland Premier. They are very succinct. The newspaper article states:
But the Premier, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, said last night from Kingaroy, 'The present state legislation specifically covering the development and protection of our indigenous people will be removed.'
He said aboriginal and island policy was directed at placing the people in the mainstream of society 'where they can exercise the same rights and responsibilities as all other people.'
'He said aboriginal and islander policy wanted to become part of the whole Queensland community, and not to be cut off from it, or forced to develop 'apart from their neighbours.'
Meantime, a group of Queensland aboriginals is planning a trip to Africa to gather support for an African boycott of the 1982 Commonwealth Games in Brisbane.

There is a fear in the heart of the Premier and in the hearts of some of the more stubborn Ministers in his Cabinet that the Games will be boycotted. It will be a great tragedy if they are. But if the Aborigines of Queensland have to suffer as the result of any white-washing legislation brought down to prevent them from owning their own land or to turn them out of their own communities, I for one, as a parliamentarian, will assist the Aborigines with that boycott. This is the only sort of language that those very conservative governments in Queensland, in the Northern Territory and in Western Australia know. Unless there are public demonstrations and well organised publicity campaigns and unless political fear is instilled into the hearts of the conservative people in the three areas I have mentioned, black people will never get any justice at all.

A number of those politicians-none of them is a parliamentarian, but just the ordinary, cheap, garden variety type politician with a lot of native cunning-who are prepared to hope for and, if necessary, to help the so-called black problems to go away. But it is not a black problem; it is a white problem in each of those three administrations. I am now calling on the Commonwealth Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, his colleagues in Cabinet and the Prime Minister to take positive action so far as Queensland-is concerned in particular at this moment because it will be the area that will suffer most in the political turnabout by the Premier to curry favour with some people.

None of us wants to see the Acts retained, but we do want to see in all instances these people remaining in control of the land which they have occupied, in many cases for generations and, in the case of some of those to whom their land is a traditional area, particularly those in the Cape York and Gulf country, for tens of thousands of years. Those people are entitled to that land. Only about 7 million acres are involved. A deal made with good will between this Government and the State Government could hand over those properties in perpetuity. Land rights legislation that would give everyone a fair go could be developed after that. Even if it were planned on the basis of the rather bobtailed land rights legislation of the Northern Territory, it would be better than the implementation of the so-called local government Act or a worse kind of lease. I warn the Minister that if this is not done he will buy himself a big fight with all people of good will in the community but, worst of all for himself, he will buy a fight with the Aboriginal races and the Torres Strait Island people of this nation.
Debate interrupted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hearn Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall take a short time to draw attention to the insecurity faced by many people in our country at this time. Today I talked with people from the Main Roads Department in Tasmania who, for many months, have been facing the anxiety and insecurity of losing their jobs. Among them were young men and apprentices who have just started their career. There were younger men who have families and who are buying homes. There were other people who are educating their children. There were older people. They all know that when they lose their jobs very shortly there will not be any jobs for them. As a woman, I can understand the concern of the wives in those families. I understand the insecurity that it will bring to those families and, perhaps, the destruction of those family units, the importance of which is consistently mouthed by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Not very long ago we celebrated Anzac Day and remembered those who died to protect democracy in this country, to protect the rights and freedoms of our people. I remind honourable senators that the majority of the people who fought in those wars were working men. They were trade unionists. They fought-many died-to ensure that the standard of living which they had achieved by struggle and strike was preserved. Those people who are today attacking the trade union movement should remember that one of the freedoms they fought for was the right to strike. That right won for the people of this country the standard of living which the Government is reducing for more and more Australians every day. No government gave that standard of living but this Government, by its economic mismanagement and by abdicating its responsibilities, is reducing it. It is a government which supports foreign corporations in the economy at the expense of the underprivileged and the working people of this country. Economic growth is pushed at the expense of people. That growth is also bringing about an increase in poverty, unemployment, anxiety, injustice and the insecurity that threatens the stability of our families. Working people are being thrown on the scrap heap for the sake of the so-called economy. The Government already admits that there are three million disadvantaged people in our country. At present there is great inequality of wealth, and a strike must be seen as a non-violent protest against the injustice in the division of that wealth. Life without poverty should be possible in Australia if right use could be made of our rich natural resources and if people had first priority. Peter Norre, a visiting expert on energy and resources, recently addressed a gathering of Australian politicians. He stated:
In terms of ownership, royalties, tax and marketing of your energy and minerals, I know of only one country in the world which gets a worse deal; that's Gabon in West Africa! Why do you allow it?

That is a question which many Australians are asking at present. The first priority of government is to protect the rights of its people. Article 25 of the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights states:

Everyone has the right to a standard of living adequate for the health and well-being of himself and of his family, including food, clothing, housing and medical care and necessary social services, and the right to security in the event of unemployment, sickness, disability, widowhood, old age or other lack of livelihood in circumstances beyond his control.

I believe that it is the responsibility of the Federal Government to ensure those rights for every person in this country. If one denies people their rights one also takes away one's expectation of their responsibility. This was demonstrated in King's Hall the other day. The rights of those women and the people they represent to proper services, housing and other facilities have been denied them; yet the government is so foolish as to expect responsibility from them. In agreeing to that declaration the Australian Government assumed the responsibility for providing health care equally for all Australians. After five alterations to the original Medibank scheme, public health in Australia is seriously at risk. One section of our society is to be labelled disabled or disadvantaged, and the pittance for it entitles it to free health care. The members of another section have to choose whether they have the food and necessities of life or health insurance, and they risk insecurity and debt. Those on higher incomes can take out insurance and choose either private or public health care. The Government should be promoting the health of the people by increasing preventive and community health services. Not to do so is to incur a huge cost of serious social problems as well as the insecurity and the human suffering which is involved.

In the area of housing, again we find the Government avoiding its responsibility. Adequate housing is essential for the security and the well-being of the family, the aged, the handicapped and the young, yet we have an increasing demand for housing and decreasing funding. The unsatisfied demand in Tasmania is 7,100. Tasmanian funding has decreased from $28.5m in 1975-76 to $11.9m in 1980-81. It is evident that the people in most need of help are of little concern to the Government. The fact that we have homeless people, homeless youth and even homeless children in this country brings shame on our nation. In answer to a question on 28 May regarding the cost of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, the Minister for Finance, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, stated:
It is the Government's intention to see that it is a conference of the standard that would be expected by those who participated in it . . .

I believe that the Government should show the same concern for the standard of living of the people of our own country who are now living far below the standards enunciated in that declaration of human rights. Mr Fraser may believe that life was not meant to be easy, but I do not agree. I believe that life is for living to the full, for happiness, hope and joy for our people. People have a right to live free from fear and insecurity.

I do not agree with Mr Fraser's assumption that taxpayers begrudge paying taxes and that they are selfish and self-centred. I do not believe that the average Australian people are uncaring of their fellow men or that they begrudge the taxes that are required to provide for the needs and services of their communities and the health services and standard of living of elderly citizens and those who are less fortunate in our society. They object to paying taxes for unnecessary things such as military academies and pomp and privilege and subsidising so-called private enterprise and foreign corporations when wealthy tax avoiders rob the Government of millions of dollars. I think the people have their priorities right but that the Government does not.

Tax revenue should ensure the services to people necessary to live life of a standard to which the article refers. Only when that priority has been filled should other things be considered. Commissioner Isaac said on 13 May that the source of acceleration of inflation in the last two years has been mainly international and government policy induced price increases. These price increases are felt most by people on low incomes. We must ask why there is poverty in our country and why the quality of life and the standard of living are being lowered. Why is there unemployment, misery and insecurity? Why are profits increasing and wages decreasing? It is time that the Government realised that behind the label of disadvantaged people-Aborigines, pensioners, the unemployed and unionists-there is a human person with human needs and human feelings. I believe there are many such people in this country. I have a feeling that they know why these conditions exist. I think the conditions bring shame to our country. I hope that the Government does something about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been endeavouring over the last three or four weeks to raise the matter I now intend to raise. Having regard to the promise made by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) that we would have ample oportunity to discuss the Review of Commonwealth Functions, on several occasions I have forgone my right to speak. Just because the Senate has a timetable problem it is not my intention to forgo that right, so I will make some comments on the review and on the way in which the Opposition and I perceive the current problems that beset the Federal Government. The last six weeks have been very crucial ones in the history of federal governments. I do not think it is too dramatic to say that the events of the last weeks have momentous signficance for our country. The Government has not only introduced a series of events and incidents that show a degree of instability in government but also it has taken steps to alter the basis of government in a way that has not recurred since Federation. In fact it has rejected and repudiated all the more moderate policies performed by Liberal governments in the post-war years.

SPEECH.PARA: I take as my starting point what I believe to be the relevant sentence in the resignation of Mr Andrew Peacock, the former Minister for Industrial Relations. He said in his resignation speech at the end of April that when he joined the Liberal Party he joined a Liberal party and not a conservative party. That brings to the surface the obvious disagreements, conflicts and differences in philosophy and ideology that exist within the Liberal Party. What have we seen in the years since the Fraser administration came to office? We have seen the development of the most ideological government which has taken the most ideological decisions since Australia made the infamous decision at the Executive level to become involved in the Vietnam war. We have seen a number of issues being dealt with by the Government which reflects that instability, that indecision and that confusion.

One has to look only at the problems that have occurred, for example, in the area of social security to see the chopping and changing and the difficulties that have existed in this area as the Government tries to maintain a semblance that it is somehow or other intersted in the rights of disadvantaged people and at the same time follow its ideological direction of cutting back on public sector spending. We have seen this very week the difficulties the Government has got into concerning the film industry. We have seen the Government's own appointees challenging its decisions to alter drastically the whole makeup and financing of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. We know what that means to the Australian people. We have seen the fifth attempt to dismember Medibank and the confusion that now exists in the whole area of health administration in this country. We have seen the activities of the so-called razor gang and the reaction that the report has brought throughout our community. We have seen the difficulties connected with the trachoma problems of Aborigines and the resignation and reinstatement of the outstanding people connected with the trachoma program that forced the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to seek special discussions with them in order to get the program back on the rails. The Government has sought to transfer federal responsibility back to the States, many of which we know have racist and inadequate policies and attitudes in respect of Aboriginal health. We have seen the conflicts amongst Government members in this place in connection with the Freedom of Information Act. Perhaps the most infamous thing of all has been what has been taking place in the public interest area and the obvious lobbying that has been conducted by Ansett Transport Industries in respect of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal and the matters involved thereto.

We can only come to the conclusion that we have now reached a stage where we have a corrupt and dishonest government, which is trying to represent itself as being concerned with the interests of the Australian people. The reality is that the corporate sector, as epitomised by such people as the Murdochs, the Abeles and others, has bought the Liberal Party lock, stock and barrel. Consequently we have seen all the machinations in that area. We witnessed the unbelievable behaviour of the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) who, while the Tribunal was sitting, put forward government policy on the matter and then, because of the failure of the Government to get support in its own ranks-the episode was off-key and disgraceful; the Government was rejecting the principles upon which the Parliament had had a certain amount of agreement over many years-had to withdraw the advising to the government's representative before that Tribunal and replace it by additional advisings to Justice Morling. What sort of state of affairs have we reached? We see a constant changing of policy. Decisions are made one day and changed the next.

Of course we are aware of the difficulties the Government has been in over these last few days in respect of the airlines agreement and the failure of the grouping within the Liberal Party to effect some dramatic change in those areas. The Liberal Party is clearly going through a forced realignment. The consequence is that since the Peacock resignation we have had the razor gang experiences and all that I have referred to. This has all flowed down through the Liberal Party. We have seen the dismissal of two State leaders, one in New South Wales and another in Victoria. It all flows from the struggle for ideas, the struggle for philosophy, in the Liberal Party itself. Yet this is a government that talks about the need to create a stable environment, to have a state of economic management which will encourage business to invest. We have a ludicrous position in which the manager of the Australian Mutual Provident Society can make a decision which brings about the dismissal of the Victorian Premier, Mr Hamer. He stated publicly that, because of the way in which the Government operates in that State, AMP, which is one of the big corporations which dictates private investment in this country, had decided for its own private and selfish reasons not to invest in Victoria. The upshot was quite disastrous for the Liberal Party Government of that State. Consequently, the power struggle within the Liberal Party is leading this country to ruin. It will have disastrous consequences for any attempt to obtain stability in the Australian economy.

Another problem is presented by the disastrous course that is being pursued by the Fraser-Anthony Administration. It is the course of Thatcherism-of plain, unadulterated monetarism -in the United Kingdom. Similar policies are being followed in the United States. We are aware that in the United Kingdom, because of the nature of its economy, those policies are having a tremendously adverse effect upon the living standards of the people. We know of the misery and suffering that have resulted from the actions of a lady who says in a contemptuous way 'I'm not for turning' when addressing the problems of the millions of unemployed and ignoring the advice of even the captains of industry in that country.

It is interesting to note that Rupert Murdoch, a man who is in a position to dictate to this Government, has tremendous influence in the media in the United Kingdom, and, indeed, in the United States. He decided that President Carter was not the sort of person who ought to be leading that big country and set about bringing ruin to his electoral chances, with the result that his administration was replaced by the Reagan Administration. These ideological struggles in the Liberal Party clearly will have a definite reaction on the Australian economic community as well as the community generally. Therefore, it is small wonder that a recent editorial in Retail World which reflects the opinions of the small business sector should state:

In one memorable week, we saw in Canberra a debate on whether TAA should be sold to private enterprise; we got the Medibank changes; we saw Andrew Peacock's remarkable (and some would say completely justified) attack on Malcolm Fraser's style of government-then we got the report of the 'Razor Gang'.
The editorial goes on to speak of the effects of the razor gang's decisions upon the organisation of government in this country, adding:
First, there's a disturbing air of 'She'll be right, mate' about the Razor Gang's recommendations.
It's all very well to slash and change-but you need to be reasonably positive about the outcome.
And that's something the Razor Gang rather disturbingly were not.
Who is going to fill the huge number of functions the Federal Government is vacating?
What happens to them if private enterprise doesn't want to step in. After all, many of them are loss-making, anyway.

It is right that many of the services were lossmaking. As we have seen, as a result of the airline agreement, the Government will allow Trans-Australia Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia to withdraw from the non-profitmaking section of airline traffic. The editorial continues:
How does the government plan to ensure that the chances to fill those vacancies will be spread around?
You won't find the answers in Mr Fraser's statement on the cuts . . .
There is a disturbing sense of isolationism in the Razor Gang's recommendations-a suggestion that they were put together without due and careful regard for the consequences . . .
Mr Fraser may have opened the way for his concept of federalism.
He may also have opened up a Pandora's box of problems for the state governments.

And he may well have put us on the road to being not one great country, but five quasi-countries, with the small and poor losing out, and the big, rich and powerful getting bigger, richer and more powerful.

That is exactly the postion in which we now find ourselves. We find the powerful organisations and corporations, such as the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Australian Industries Development Association, making suggestions which this Government is prepared to pick up, seeking to establish for themselves higher profit aggregates for the purpose of capital investment, and putting themselves in a position in which they are able to influence this Government and affect the rights not only of people but also of State and local governments. In an article which dealt with the question of conflict between private and public sectors, the Age stated:
For all the Commonwealth's criticism of public sector borrowing by the States, the borrowing is relatively small by comparison to the cause of the problem-the Commonwealth's refinancing requirements.
It is pointed out that Mr Howard said:

It is the total size of the public sector borrowing requirement which is of paramount importance. Whether it is a semi-government authority or the Commonwealth Government financing its activities it constitutes the same competition for funds with a growing private sector, and results in the same pressure of interest rates. He said that present interest rate levels were a direct result of keen competition for funds between an expanding private sector and the public sector's call for funds.

Therefore, is it any wonder that the Chancellor of West Germany has criticised the United States of America for having interest rates, with their effect on market forces, of 20 per cent. In today's Press he is quoted as having suggested that that may well bring about a world-wide recession and create tremendous problems of unemployment and capital restriction in Europe and other parts of the world.

One can say that, as a result of the direct actions of this Government, over the last five years the provision of public services has declined dramatically. Why is this so? The answer is rather simple. It has resulted from the approval of the investment allowance for business, of double depreciation for mining companies, of trading stock valuation methods which assist the big retailers and of increased retention allowances. All of these measures have resulted in a transfer of funds away from the poor and to the rich to the tune of $4 billion. There has been a re-allocation of funds from ordinary people to big business-all in the forlorn hope and belief that big business will invest the proceeds of such capital appreciation and aggregation, and that that will bring about some revival in the domestic economy. But what has happened? Has unemployment fallen as a result of the decisions taken over the last five years? Has the rate of inflation fallen? Have ordinary people prospered under this so-called new direction policy? Of course not. What has happened is that we are now witnessing, as a result of the decisions taken by this Government, a series of policies to alter the whole structure of the Australian political economy and the Australian system of government.

Even though it could be argued that some of the cuts suggested by the razor gang may have only minor financial consequences, they are proceeding in the direction of altering drastically the structure and processes which have been with us for a considerable number of years. Nevertheless, the Government is being urged on by businesses which want a quick kill, which want to be able to impose their views successfully. Indeed, everything that has happened reveals that they are achieving precisely that. Where is the guiding vision upon which this Government, when it placed its platform before the Australian people in 1975, 1977 and 1980, claimed it would rely? Where is the careful guidance of this country's future? What are we left with? As a result of decisions taken by the Government following pressure from the big business sector, we are left in its place with a concept of small government, with no interest in small business. Rather, we have small government and big business. One only has to look at the legislation that has been rammed through this Parliament in the last few days to see where that will lead us finally. It will lead us to the privation of profits and the socialisation of losses. It will lead to the poor suffering even more than they have in the past.

These matters will not be put into the category of responsible or efficient decisions. They are not what the Australian people want. They are not acceptable to the Opposition and I am sure that they are not acceptable to the Australian people. They represent a plain abdication of national responsibility in a whole range of areas. To that extent we take up the challenge thrown to us by the Fraser-Anthony Government. We will be campaigning during the next few months to acquaint the Australian people of the sorts of policies being developed by this Government to show the links that the big business sector has with this Government and to show where those policies will lead this country in the long run. They will lead it along the same disastrous way that Mrs Thatcher has led the British Conservative Party. To that extent we have no doubt at all that the policies will be rejected by the Australian people at the most appropriate time. We have no doubt at all that the policies pursued by this Government will be seen by the overwhelming majority of people to be against their interests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again I find myself having to raise a domestic issue which has occurred within the walls of this Parliament. It was brought about by the unscheduled very late sitting of the Parliament last night and it highlights again the lack of liaison between Government Ministers and the people who have to service the Parliament. As we all know, we had to sit here until 3 o'clock this morning. Members of Parliament, particularly Ministers, have facilities in their offices to make a cup of tea or some refreshments. They can do that until the time we leave the Parliament. But when the drivers and attendants who had to stay here until that ungodly hour-some of the drivers and Hansard staff would not have got to bed, I suppose, until daylight this morning-went to get a cup of tea at 1 o'clock this morning, they found that the canteen was closed. That is not good enough. If the Government is going to sit the Parliament past the normal adjournment time, arrangements should be made with the catering people who service this Parliament to ensure that facilities are available at all times for the people who have to stay back away from their homes at that ungodly hour of the morning.

SPEECH.PARA: There are facilities for members of Parliament. I understand that there is a regulation that the bar and the catering facilities in the dining room have to remain available until 30 minutes after the last House rises. But apparently that is not the case for the facilities and services provided for the staff of this Parliament. There were quite a few very unhappy people here last night, quite apart from we members of Parliament, as I mentioned earlier today. I make a plea to the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) who is at the table, to consult with her leader so that some arrangements can be made when a decision is made in future to keep the Parliament sitting beyond the normal adjournment time. We know the adjournment time from looking at the business sheet. Last night it was to be 11 o'clock.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was 11.30.
—It was 11.30, was it? That was not on the red business sheet.
—That was the agreement.

—There was some agreement. I make a plea for the powers-that-be, when such an agreement is reached, to consult with the manager of the Refreshment Rooms and to ask him to keep those facilities available for the staff. They are the people who have to service this place. As I said, some of them probably did not get to bed until daylight this morning because of the long distances they had to carry members of Parliament after the Parliament adjourned. I will not say any more. I have brought the matter to the attention of the Government. Let us hope that the situation does not occur again.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to raise one other matter and I will not take too much of the Senate's time. On 9 April, I asked Senator Carrick a question without notice in relation to a resource development project in Australia. Today I received a reply by letter from him. In the event that that letter may not find its way into Hansard-usually such answers are given at the end of Question Time-and because it is a very important answer, I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
MINISTER FOR NATIONAL DEVELOPMENT AND ENERGY
Leader of the Government in the Senate Parliament House, Canberra, ACT 2600 3 June 1981 Senator G. T. McLaren,
Senator for South Australia,
Parliament House,
Canberra, ACT 2600
Dear Senator McLaren,
Resource Development Projects
During Question Time on 9 April 1981 you asked a question without notice in relation to resource development projects in Australia.

In my response to your question I undertook to ascertain from the Bureau of Mineral Resources its present assessment of the Roxby Downs project. The Bureau has provided the following details of the project:

The Olympic Dam copper deposit on Roxby Downs, South Australia, is large by world standards although it is not high grade. The mineralisation has been shown to extend over an area 6 km long and 3 km wide but its true limits have not yet been defined. The two companies exploring the deposit have begun a program costing $50 million to continue exploration, metallurgical testing, and other work necessary to complete a feasibility study within two to three years. Eleven diamond drilling rigs are being employed in this project and over the past 15 months 75 holes have been drilled, most of which have intersected mineralisation. Apart from the copper, there is a substantial uranium content and low gold and rare earth values. A minimum figure of 500 million tonnes of copper, uranium, gold and rare earth ore was estimated for the deposit by Dr D. W. Haynes, Copper Consultant, Western Mining Corporation in October 1979.
Based on published information, the bureau believes that the deposit has the potential of being a major orebody by world standards.
Yours sincerely, J. L. CARRICK

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity presented by the first reading of the Supply Bill (No.1) to speak on a matter of concern to me and to many Australians, that is, the conference on the Indian Ocean as a zone of peace which is-perhaps I should say, 'was'-to be held later this year.
