Since the decision to stage B52 bombers through Darwin and the decision of the Government to grant similar facilities in Western Australia, there has been increasing concern about the growing threat to peace throughout the world. People are stirring, individually and in numbers, to counter in some way that growing trend and to endeavour to have people talk in terms of peace rather than in terms of war. In that context it becomes even more important that we should look at any conference held anywhere in the world that concerns itself with peace. In particular, I think it important for Australia to be concerned with the conference on the Indian Ocean as a zone of peace.

SPEECH.PARA: On the initiative of the Sri Lankan Government, the United Nations General Assembly designated the Indian Ocean as a zone of peace in 1971. That was 10 years ago. In those 10 years we have seen the Indian Ocean become not increasingly a zone of peace but actually a zone of preparation for war and confrontation. It is regrettable that that should have occurred. Of course, the concept of the Indian Ocean as a zone of peace, if it succeeded, would isolate a substantial area close to our shores from the increasing dominance of the military powers. It seems that that is not the case now. Despite subsequent United Nations endorsements of the zone of peace concept, we seem to be no nearer peace in that region. The latest obstacle to achieving a peaceful Indian Ocean has been the move to postpone a conference which was to be held in Colombo later this year. It is around that postponement that I make these remarks. For that reason I think the Government must take account of what I have to say now and what others will say concerning the attitude of the Government.

In January this year, the United Nations General Assembly instructed its Ad Hoc Committee on the Indian Ocean to 'convene a conference on the Indian Ocean during 1981 at Colombo, taking into consideration the exchange of views thereon'. The Ad Hoc Committee, which is made up of 45 nations, met once in March of this year. It intends to meet again this month. At the March meeting it became obvious that there was opposition to this year's conference and that, I repeat, should be a matter of concern. The chairperson of the Ad Hoc Committee is reported in the Far Eastern Economic Review as saying:

The failure of the Committee to take a decision on the dates for the proposed Colombo conference frustrated the desire shared by virtually all the littoral and hinterland states which had worked so hard for nearly 10 years in the pursuit of their goal . . .
The article goes on to state:

The ''vast majority'' of the delegations favoured convening the Colombo conference next August but that a powerful minority consisting of western countries and Japan were reluctant to commit themselves to a date.

So begins the opposition to and the delay of a very important matter. The United States of America, since the election of President Reagan, has taken a hard line on the conference. To support this I refer to the same article. It states:

Washington's delegate Philip Wilcox administered what many consider to be the coup de grace to the 1981 conference when he accused the Soviets, through their occupation of Afghanistan, of shattering the basis for trust necessary for a meaningful zone of peace agreement.
Until Moscow restores good faith by withdrawing its troops, . . . Wilcox suggested, an Indian Ocean conference would be pointless.

He said other things but basically that is what he said. I would have thought that the contrary would be the case; that the Afghanistan intervention and the pressure for escalation of armaments in that area and in the Indian Ocean would have given an increased priority to the conference. It seems to me that the United States, by its attitude, is determined to take the view that while the Afghanistan intervention proceeds there should be no conference on the Indian Ocean. The Australian delegation to the Committee has taken a somewhat similar line, as can be seen from its submission to the Ad Hoc Committee of November last year. I say that now because the Australian delegation's attitude, which reflects the government position, is taking an opposite view to that which it took originally. More's the pity. I quote:

. . . alarming events have occurred which directly affect the probability of convening a successful conference in 1981. I refer primarily to the invasion of Afghanistan, a hinterland state of the region. This disturbing development has affected not only our desire to create a zone of peace in the Indian Ocean but also the stability and security of the world as a whole.

Whilst I might agree with that sentiment, I cannot agree with the conclusion. The conclusion, of course, ought to be that the conference should be held and reinforced. It should be noted that this view was not shared by the United Nations. In January of this year the United Nations General Assembly passed a resolution calling for a peace conference-I think I have already referred to this-and instructed its Ad Hoc Committee on the Indian Ocean to convene a conference. The view of the United States and now of Australia is not shared by the United Nations. The fallacy of using the invasion of Afghanistan as a reason for stopping the conference was best summarised by the chairperson of the Ad Hoc Committee when he said:
Postponing action is like waiting until the flames die down before calling the fire brigade to a burning house.

That quotation comes from the Far Eastern Economic Review of March 1981. The situation as it now stands is that the Committee will meet again this month to decide the future of the conference. As I have stated, the conference is not just a simple diplomatic luxury. It is a political necessity. It is more than that. It is a very human necessity in order to spread the growth of militancy and to increase the influence of peace. The last 10 years have seen the growth in the military hardware in the Indian Ocean and that has increased the potential for war throughout the world. The extent of this development towards war is in part summarised in an article appearing in the New York Times of 19 April. As there is some shortage of time, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard that article from the New York Times of 19 April headed 'Supremacy at Sea: The Race in the Indian Ocean'.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

As a result of the most ambitious naval deployment since the Vietnam War, the United States has become a major naval power in the Indian Ocean, challenging the advances of Soviet sea and ground forces in Africa and Asia. The buildup has continued steadily and dramatically over the last 16 months, countering the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan and earlier Soviet involvement in Angola and Ethiopia.

According to the Navy in Washington, the United States had 32 combat and support vessels in the area recently. In the 1970s, when the Persian Gulf Squadron was the only permanent American presence in the area, there were only three destroyers. Now France, a North Atlantic Treaty Organisation ally, had 12 ships in the Indian Ocean.

The Soviet Union recently had 21 ships there, most of them noncombatants and not comparable to the two aircraft carrier groups the United States stations permanently in the area. While the Soviet Union has reduced its presence slightly in the last few months, United States power is dramatically in evidence throughout the area . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Although incorporating the article instead of reading it does break the thread of the argument I think it is far better for me to have the whole of it included in the record before the suspension of the sitting at 6 p.m. than to go beyond that time as I believe other important legislation has to be dealt with. The American buildup in the Indian Ocean has continued with greater fervour now that Reagan has become President. An article appearing in the Australian Financial Review entitled 'Reagan's 5-year Plan to Militarise the Indian Ocean' states that the Reagan Administration will extend even further the increases that were outlined by former President Carter. For example, in 1982 Reagan is expected to spend $472.6m, an increase of $100m on that intended to be spent by Carter. Honourable senators can see that the position is now the reverse and that the Indian Ocean as a zone of peace appears to be now something of the past because of the tremendous expenditure to be undertaken by the United States. This expenditure increase, together with agreements made with some governments, will allow the United States to have periodic access to a string of bases through which it can protect its economic interests in the Middle East as well as the Indian Ocean region.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia, despite statements to the contrary, is assisting in making the Indian Ocean a zone of war and not one of peace. Yet the original intention of the Government was to support that aim. I have mentioned that the Australian support has been reinforced by allowing the staging of the B52s through Darwin. The agreements on American bases in Australia and, in particular, the use of Australian ports for recreational leave for American forces which have been deployed in the Indian Ocean indicate that the Australian Government is helping to prepare the Indian Ocean region for war and not for peace. It has been said that the conference, if held, will not be productive. It has been said that the Soviet Union would in some way, through its friends who would participate in the conference, frustrate the conference. It is interesting to see that the Soviet Union's attitude has been somewhat restrained. In fact the Soviet Union has agreed that at the conference it would not in any way frustrate the discussion of that country's intervention in Afghanistan. I would have though that that was a reasonable approach and an invitation that should be accepted.

It seems to me that we must recommence the discussions at all levels, whether they be on the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks agreement, the agreement in discussions on detente, discussions on the Indian Ocean as a zone of peace or discussions on the Pacific region as a zone of peace. All those discussions should be recommenced if they have ceased. If they are about to take place then they should take place. The conference on the Indian Ocean to be held at Colombo, Sri Lanka, should be held. The activities of, and agreements made by, the Australian Government are not only my concern in the changing relationships of the Indian Ocean region. Many observers feel that the United States of America, to secure greater military advantage in the region, will take up the tentative offer which the South African Govenrment has made for military links which, if established, will further entrench that racist Government. A further danger that we face is the increased interest of the United States in that area and its determination to escalate its military presence. If that presence is not in some way stamped out, it will lead to an escalation of the Soviet presence in the Indian Ocean. We have that familiar situation of: 'I escalate because you escalate'. So we get a situation which is familiar, and we now find ourselves with sufficient nuclear weapons to destroy the world. We could not just destroy the world 31 times over, as was once said, but some 50 times over. It is a ridiculous, highly dangerous and incredible situation. What should be done? What should be done is explained in an answer by Sentor Carrick to a question from Senator Sibraa on 1 April 1980. Senator Carrick stated:

I am able to confirm that Australia voted in favour of resolution 34/80 at the 1979 session of the United Nations General Assembly concerning the declaration of the Indian Ocean as a zone of peace. I am also able to confirm that the resolution did draw attention to the dangers of competitive escalation between the great powers in the Indian Ocean. While the resolution did not specifically call upon the great powers to refrain from any further escalation and expansion of their military presence, it did call upon the Soviet Union and the United States to 'refrain from any activity prejudicial to the implementation of resolution 2032 . . . which was the original 1971 resolution on the Declaration of the Indian Ocean as a zone of peace.

That was the Government's petition. That is exactly the petition I am putting. It could not have been placed more clearly, more sensibly, more reasonably and more responsibly. Unfortunately, matters have changed, I believe because of an overreaction to the invasion of Afghanistan and because of increased pressure put by the United States upon its allies. In the light of this situation, combined with the buildup of American activity in the region, it is more important now that the proposed conference should go ahead and to re-state the position of the Government, given in answer to Senator Sibraa. We also ought to re-state the word of the chairperson of the ad hoc committee, who said:
Postponing action until peace and stability returns to the area is like waiting until the flames die down before you call the fire brigade.

I have quoted that before and I quote it again. It is important that the Australian Government should support a conference on the Indian Ocean and endeavour to hold it this year. It should not encourage some of our friends in the area to postpone it. Nothing is lost by an exchange of views. Nothing is lost by discussing peace. Nothing is lost by discussing peace even while we are engaged in armament. At least we are discussing an alternative. It seems to me that the American attitude under Reagan is: 'We proceed to war. It is only a matter of time. Let us have the edge. Let us have the means to destroy. If we do not have the means to destroy then let us have the means to retaliate and make certain the other person does not win.' That is an extremely horrific position to be taking.

My view is that this conference on a peaceful Indian Ocean should take place. There are very few places in the world today where one of us can go to talk in terms of peace. I would have thought that this conference would give us such an opportunity. It is important that the Australian Government supports the conference on the Indian Ocean as a peace zone. The threat to peace in the region has never been greater. To wait for the right political climate to occur, whatever that means-that is the view of the United States and others-is to delay activity which could decrease the threat of war. To delay also means that given Australia's agreement with the United States, the Australian people are exposed to what I believe are needless military dangers. Finally, to delay means that we no doubt will cause undue strained relationships with those nations in the region which support the conference and the concept of a peaceful zone in the Indian Ocean.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lajovic Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In joining the debate on Supply Bill (No. 1) 1981, I take this opportunity to say a few things about the media. I mean the media in the general sense, not only the media in Australia but also in Western democracies. I intend to cover Press, radio and television areas. I strongly emphasise that this is not intended to be an exercise of 'bash the media' but rather a plea to the media for a better, more responsible and, if at all possible, restrained presentation of the news and reports of events in Australia and the world. In the column 'On the Other Hand', recently written by Mr Guy Harriott, a prominent journalist, who unfortunately passed away only a few days ago, under the heading 'Press made the scapegoat for bungling politicians', he wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: Without an independent and vigorous press, abuses, follies and tyrannies of government are not exposed to the public, are not effectively criticised and are not corrected.
I have no objection to that statement. I fully agree also with the last paragraph, which reads:

May I suggest to my readers that, next time they complain about the inadequacies of the press, they pause to consider a situation in which the only printed record of government activities was a government gazette.

There is nothing that I would like to emphasise more than that statement. I fully agree with him. I believe in a free Press, but as I said at the beginning of my speech, I believe in a responsible Press and responsible radio and television reporting. In that article he also wrote:
The manner in which it performs this function can be the subject of legitimate criticism; . . .

He was referring to the Press. That is what I wish to speak about tonight. I shall give an example of reporting which is completely untrue and which has no connection whatever with what I said recently in a Senate debate. The only truth in the short report to which I refer is that it stated that I spoke. All the rest is a complete falsification. On 13 May 1981, as recorded on page 196 of Hansard, in a debate on the Census and Statistics Amendment Bill, I said:

I wish to raise two points only. Firstly, I would like from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) information as to the way in which 'knowingly' filling in a census form is to be interpreted. I can imagine that some of those who have come to this country as I have, will have difficulty in understanding properly the forms or the questions. Some of them, I am sure, will put down a wrong answer, although not knowingly or intentionally. I wonder what the attitude of the court will be to someone who has done that because he has not understood a question. Some of the questions that I have seen in the census forms are not worded in a way that some of us would describe as proper. It is necessary that the Minister explain the situation and give us an assurance that it will not be merely a matter of hoping that the court will decide that a migrant did not understand a question or did not interpret it in the way in which the court or the collector of the forms might interpret it. What is meant by 'knowingly' should be more clearly defined.

That is what I said and that is what was reported in the Hansard. It will be a strange coincidence if anybody can find any similarity between that speech and a report by Stephen Mills in the Age of 14 May under the heading: 'Three disputes add to Government's troubles'. This is how he understood my contribution to the debate. Under the heading 'Census Bill' it is stated:

Senator Lajovic (Liberal, New South Wales) asked for an explanation of why the provision was necessary. He recalled that he came from a country with a Communist regime (Yugoslavia) and did not want to see anything similar here.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I suspend the sitting of the Senate for dinner, I wish to say a few words which I am sure will be of interest to honourable senators. Yesterday, in order to ascertain the extent of wishes of honourable senators to change the current sitting hours of the Senate, I invited honourable senators to participate in a ballot on the subject. I now inform the Senate of the result of that ballot. Fifty-nine honourable senators participated in the ballot. Forty-six senators were in favour of change in the sitting hours, 12 senators were not in favour of change and there was one informal vote. Mr Speaker conducted a similar ballot of members of the House of Representatives and I understand that the result there was in line with the vote of honourable senators.

INTERJECT.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lajovic Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before Senator Gietzelt opens the debate, I suggest that we have a cognate debate covering this Bill, the Independent Air Fares Committee Bill, the Airlines Equipment Amendment Bill and the Australian National Airlines Repeal Bill.
—Is it the wish of the Senate to follow the procedure suggested by the Attorney-General? There being no objection, I will permit that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Twenty hours ago, which is not so very long ago, the House of Representatives after a long and difficult debate considered this legislation to which the Senate is now asked to give its assent in the space of a short time, perhaps several hours. This is despite the fact that for the past two years there has been broad discussion by the Government parties, a public inquiry, a great deal of discussion in our Press, comment in the Parliament and a great deal of general concern expressed about the changes which were mooted prior to the last elections. Consequently it seems rather improper and unsatisfactory that the Senate should be put in a position to restrict its capacity properly to debate these Bills which have a profound effect upon the airline industry in our country. After all, the purpose of any airline legislation is to improve our airline services, improve competition and generally serve the public's interests. It must be said that none of those objectives will be reached as a result of these four Bills currently before the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the Opposition has noted the very, very heavy lobbying by Sir Peter Abeles, who was acting on behalf of Ansett Transport Industries Ltd, in the party room, to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcom Fraser) and to other leading members of the Government. It causes us a great deal of concern that such pressure can be brought to bear by a person who has a direct pecuniary interest in the legislation. It has even been suggested in some quarters that his influence was such that the legislation has been designed to meet the interests solely of Ansett Transport Industries. The Bills that we are asked to consider deal with various aspects of the airline industry. Consequently it would be impossible for the Opposition to deal with them adequately in the time that has been allocated for them in the debate. We know that the Government has a temporary majority in this place to do whatever it likes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not be so sure on that.

—I have always been called an optimist. I hope that common sense will prevail in these matters. Generally speaking, we have been subjected to a practice which shows that it is very difficult to have an impact on the Government once it has set its legislation in action. We are placed in a difficult position. Yesterday's Hansard was not available until a few hours ago. That Hansard enables us to examine properly the debate that took place in the House of Representatives. But it is interesting to note that some eight members of the Government parties felt sufficiently strongly about this legislation to cross the floor. The Government narrowly, by one vote, failed to achieve its objectives. The Bills in this package contain some advances-the Opposition concedes that-on existing arrangements for the provision of airline services in Australia. But the Opposition does not believe that the legislation is satisfactory and that the two-airline agreement should run for more than eight years which is what this legislation surreptitiously attempts to bring about. Nor does the Opposition, as it has said during the brief debate that we had on the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares, believe that the profits of Ansett and Trans-Australia Airlines came under sufficient scrutiny by either that inquiry or the Parliament. Yet those are obviously very relevant factors in respect of what this legislation seeks to do. Therefore, we will move amendments to the Airlines Agreement Bill which are designed to correct these deficiencies. We will also move amendments in the Committee stages to the subsequent Bill-the Independent Air Fares Committee Bill. Of course we will be interested in the circulated amendment that will be moved by a Government senator and also the projected amendment by the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Chipp.

SPEECH.PARA: We see the major intent of these Bills as being to ensure the profitability of Ansett Airlines for at least the next eight years. In other words, the legislation is giving a licence to print money indefinitely. Yesterday we witnessed in the House of Representatives debate a major and critical rebellion of the Government parties-the Liberal and National Country Parties-over what they consider the undesirable aspects of the preference and protection being afforded to the Ansett company, which will be the principal beneficiary as a result of this legislation. Therefore, we are entitled again, as we have several times this week, to challenge the ideological position on which the Fraser ministry has attempted unrelentingly to foist upon Australians in every aspect of their lives the sort of legislation which seems to have at least struck some reaction from the Government benches. We have seen the conservative factionalism develop as well as the personal ambition of some of those people who have taken what they consider to be a position of principle. Surely we can now ask the question: Are we watching the death throes of this Government? In recent times we have seen so many of the major differences within the Government concerned about the philosophical position which it occupies. How ironic it is that profound difficulties should occur over this legislation which attempts to entrench further the rights of those very favoured people-multimillionaires-who have been responsible through their control of the nation's media for the Fraser Government's hold on power. Of course they are exacting this legislation which will help them further to improve profitability in the airline industry. Any benefits to the public that may arise from this legislation will be quite incidental to the purposes that I have mentioned. The Australian Labor Party's policy objectives in the airline industry are to ensure maximum access to safe, convenient, competitive airline services at a minimum cost to the user. To add emphasis to that, I will quote from the Sydney Morning Herald editorial on 29 May last. Indeed, one could quote from a number of newspapers which have expressed concern about the ideological position that the Government has taken. The Sydney Morning Herald editorial states:

It is also obvious that the most important consideration in determining the duration of the proposed new agreement was the profitability of the airlines as they embarked on their investment in new wide-bodied aircraft. The interests of companies that would like to compete with Ansett and TAA and, more important, the interests of the public were at best given secondary consideration.
The editorial also stated:
. . . the Federal Government, acting in its capacity as guardian of the public interest, proved a very poor negotiator with the airlines.

In other words, what the editorial is saying is that the Government succumbed to the pressure, to the lobbying. We could well ask why, particularly in regard to Ansett, because the very inquiry which the Government itself established, comprising three very respectable businessmen, men who are held in high regard in the community-the Holcroft Committee of Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares-has made the point very strongly that there is no justification in the provision of air services for the operators, Ansett and TAA, to earn profits commensurate with trading operations in the general commercial environment. The fact is that the public transport system of which the airline service is a major part is there to provide a service to the community, not just to provide profits to the investing group that now has control of that organisation. It is not there to earn massive rewards for multimillionaires who, after all, are not prepared to take very much of a risk on their investments. Of course, there is no risk in this business because the system operates on a cost-plus basis. Only the profits have not been spelt out in specific terms, which is a point made by the Holcroft inquiry and by the Opposition when these matters were debated recently.

Let me quickly relate the origins of the two-airline policy. Honourable senators will recall that it was introduced by the Menzies Government in the early 1950s to prop up the failing private enterprise operator, Australian National Airways. It is interesting to read what the then Prime Minister said about the need for competition between the government airline and the private operator. Many of us have said many times in debates on these matters in the past how much we regret the fact that there is no actual competition in the Australian airline industry. That early legislation was amended in 1975 to meet the desires of the successors of ANA, namely Ansett Airlines of Australia. That policy subsequently has entrenched a rigid regulatory control of domestic airline services and has been supported by successive conservative governments. Of course, the hands of the Labor Government were tied in the years from 1972 to 1975 because the agreement had been signed on the eve of the general election in 1972.

A great contradiction in the behaviour of honourable senators opposite is that despite their constant statements and claims about the efficiency and efficacy of free enterprise and how things can best be done by the private sector, the two-airline policy is, by its very nature, the antithesis of free enterprise. It provides two private multi-millionaire operators with guaranteeed protected access to half the capacity of the major airline services in this country. We do not have to probe very deeply to appreciate the other benefits that accrue to Ansett because of the preferential treatment it is given. The fact that TAA, a public company, operates is a considerable disadvantage to the private operator. Given the basis on which the private operator is protected from any competition, there can be no danger of a competitor pushing it out of its share of the traffic or of endangering its commercial position. As I mentioned, the private operator is protected and this legislation will give added emphasis to that protection by a cost-plus pricing system.

As honourable senators may recall, the present proprietors of Ansett Airlines seized control of Ansett Transport Industries Ltd in a gigantic stock exchange coup in late 1979. We all recall the pleas which were made at that time by Sir Reginald Ansett to the Government for assistance, for protection regarding what was happening on the stock exchange. But, of course, the Government took no steps at all to protect the interests of an intrepid and enterprising businessman who, whilst he had taken control of ANA some 20-odd years earlier, found himself squeezed out as a result of the activities of two new entrepreneurs, Rupert Murdoch and Peter Abeles. They paid a heavily inflated price for ATI. The new proprietors then had to find some way of increasing the financial yield from Ansett Airlines. They did not have much difficulty because they had a very compliant government. They had a captive, corrupt government then and they have a captive, corrupt government now; a government prepared to do their bidding, prepared to listen to the pleadings and the lobbying of the captains of our airline industry.

The two-airline agreement was to be renegotiated and changed to assist further the multi-millionaire proprietors of Ansett Airlines. The new agreement makes no reference to a limitation on profits, despite the exclusive right of the parties to provide major domestic airline services. So they can do literally what they like. This legislation is designed to help to achieve that higher financial yield now required by Ansett Transport Industries to fund the inflated prices and to help to pay for the tax-free profits gained by Mr Robert Holmes a'Court from the sale of his shares to the present proprietors. As I have pointed out, because the fare structure is based upon a cost-plus system and because the agreement requires the operation of only two operators over the entire domestic trunk route network, Ansett cannot fail. It is on a sure thing. There is no risk or danger from competitive forces over the entire trunk route network. No risk capital is involved. It is a proposition which cannot lose. That guarantee is, of course, given to them as a result of this legislation. Again, this is a point which was made by the Holcroft inquiry and which was so quickly put aside by this Government because the inquiry dared to challenge the fundamentals upon which the two-airline agreement operated in this country.

One is entitled, therefore, to repeat what has been said time and time again: The two-airline policy is a licence to print money, as, indeed, is the Government's policy in respect of the television industry. That is a point which has been made time and time again by editorial writers around this country. What did the editorial writer of the Australian Financial Review say on 7 December 1979, at the time when the coup was in progress, when a man identified with the industry was making a plea for assistance from the Fraser Government? He said:
The major asset of ATI is the entrenched rights and privileges it possesses under the two-airline policy.
Television licences are public property which may not be freely bought and sold. So is the position of ATI within the two-airline policy.
Government policy does not have to remain unchanged on either.

It certainly has not been changed. The present multimillionaires of ATI who bought into that company and who organised that stock exchange coup on their own initiative now want to have it guaranteed by legislation of the national parliament. Let their risks be on their heads; let their risks not be an imposition upon the air travellers of this country is what the Opposition says. They are masquerading as the providers of a better public transport service. They would not have entered into contracts to purchase new aircraft if they did not have knowledge of the new airline agreement which was negotiated, and which was not made available to the Parliament, on the eve of the 1980 election. The travelling public is not being protected and its interests are not being recognised. The travelling public has no obligation to ensure an inflated rate of return on the investment which the proprietors of Ansett have made in their own airline. The incredible subservience of the Government to the Ansett proprietors is shown by the surrender of its sovereign power to determine airline policy. We know how it pushed aside those eminent gentlemen who were associated with the Holcroft inquiry. It is an incredible, unacceptable and disgraceful performance. I know of nothing in parliamentary history which shows a sovereign goverment handing over its power to determine policy to a private organisation which, in this case, is the two multimillionaires.

The granting in clause 2 of the agreement of a 90 day power of veto to Ansett and TAA over Qantas Airways Ltd flying domestic routes is without precedent in parliamentary history but it also indicates the level of distrust. This is very important because this legislation has come before the Parliament after several months of public dissention, disarray, backroom brawling and attempts to overthrow the leadership of the Government, and correctly so. We hope that the Senate might exercise, as it so often does not, its opportunity to do just that. Out of all of that disarray has come this second version of a two-airline agreement within 12 months. The distrust indicated in clause 2 of the new agreement is the distrust between the Australian National Airlines Commission, Ansett Airlines and the Government. In effect Ansett has said to the Government: 'We do not trust you to legislate in the manner you have indicated in this agreement. We do not trust you to legislate in the terms you indicated in respect of the Independent Air Fares Committee. We do not believe that you can trust your own back benchers'. That seems to be a fair comment, having regard to the attempts made within the Government parties to have some rationality and some control over the airline industry. That is the climate in which this legislation has been brought before the Parliament. It was rushed, there was inadequate time to debate and there was a determination by the Executive to push it through the Parliament, regardless of all the consequences, the views and the public disquiet that obviously exists.

The removal of freight from the agreement is supported by the Opposition. The introduction of wide-bodied aircraft and specialised cargo aircraft should result in a higher level of efficiency in the industry, together with improved services to air freight users. Accordingly, we do not oppose the Airlines Equipment Amendment Bill. However, it must be understood that the continued restrictive definition of trunk routes will give Ansett and TAA exclusive right to those routes, thus severely limiting opportunities for the development of regional operators such as East-West Airlines Ltd and other future developments as population and market patterns grow-not only grow but possibly change. We are witnessing in Australia a change in our population modes and patterns. East-West has rightly expressed its concern at the dangers which it sees arising from the limitations being placed upon operators in the new agreement. It has circularised members of the Senate and, as a small operator, it has complained bitterly about what the airline agreement does to it. It pointed out that the Government, in pressing forward with this legislation, is pandering to the big at the expense of the small.

The purpose of the amendment that we will be moving is to limit the life of the agreement to five years, which is the minimum life under the existing agreement. In the view of the Opposition the Government has no mandate to extend the life of the agreement whether it be from one year to six years, three years to eight years, or from five years to 10 years. It has been revealed in recent times that a secret deal was made and concluded between the proprietors of Ansett, Sir Peter Abeles, and the Government, to double the life of the agreement to 10 years. That has become obvious in the public debate that has ensued as a result of some concern expressed by the Government's own back bench. That deal was made prior to 17 March last year, the date on which Ansett, with a great deal of fanfare at the National Press Club conference, announced its decision to purchase its new Boeing fleet.

It is interesting that there is not a word about the new airline agreement, except the setting out of certain basic philosophical positions of the Government in the Prime Minister's election program. The Government does not have a mandate to take the extraordinary steps that this legislation seeks to do. The doubling of the life of the agreement to 10 years was carefully concealed from the Parliament, the public and from the Government's own parties by Ansett and by Sir Peter Abeles, despite the expensive fanfare associated with the announcement of the purchase of the new Boeing fleet. I refer specifically to the speech of the Minister for Transport, Mr Hunt, in the other place on the last night of the last Parliament. He said:
We have now reached a stage where discussions on principles with the airlines have been finalised and drafting of the new agreement is nearly adopted.

He failed to tell the Parliament that months previously an arrangement satisfactory to Ansett had already been concluded. That was on the evening of 18 September last year. Some 16 hours later it was announced that the Minister, Ansett Airlines and the Australian National Airlines Commission had signed a new agreement. But it was carefully concealed that the new agreement provided for a doubling of its life to 10 years, thus taking away from future governments the right to have some say in the way in which the airline industry operates in this country. I also quote from the Minister's Press release of 19 September last year recording that event. Paragraph 3, in reference to the new airlines agreement states:

The terms of the new agreement are along the lines of the principles outlined in the second reading speech of the Australian National Airlines Act introduced into the House of Representatives on 18 September 1980.

The Minister was careful to make no reference in his speech or in that Press statement to the doubling of the life of the airline agreement or to the veto power being provided to Ansett to prevent the use of Qantas Airways Ltd capacity in the provision of direct domestic services. There was a conspiracy of silence to delude the Parliament, the Australian electorate, the Government's own party and, certainly, the Opposition, because the Government was going out on an election campaign and it did not want the discontent that exists in the Australian community over the lack of competition in our airline industry to become an issue in the 1980 Federal elections. Not one word was uttered except for a report that appeared in the Australian Financial Review of 19 September last. That report, a very small report, referred to a 10 year agreement. It states:
It is reported that the Minister refused to confirm the accuracy or otherwise of that 10-year agreement.

He knew questions were raised about it but he refused to deny or confirm them. He denied that information to Parliament, as did the airline. I assert that Sir Peter Abeles, his colleagues and the Government thus have engaged in a conspiracy of silence to deny essential information to the Parliament and to the Australian community. The reasons for this would be clear to honourable senators. If the Government had proceeded to announce the terms of a new airline agreement along the lines that subsequently came forth, there was every probability that the rebel Liberals, in Western Australia for example, may have taken certain steps in respect of an independent Senate team on a platform of fair internal air fares. After all, Western Australia has shown that it has a degree of independence in these matters and might conceivably have changed the balance of power in the Senate if that had happened. The Government would have been in a worse position than it will be as from 1 July next.

The Government will therefore be operating in the Senate from July under what we believe to be false pretences. It has acted corruptly and reprehensibly. In collusion with Sir Peter Abeles it has pre-empted the decision-making authority of the Senate. What of the term of 10 years? I shall quote from no less a personage than the secretary of the Department of Transport, the Minister's own senior adviser in the Department. A few weeks after this deal was done on 15 April 1980, in an address to the Committee of Economic Development of Australia, that gentleman said:
In listening to me, you might bear in mind that in a fast changing world a span of 10 years is a long period over which to make predictions.

In other words, he was saying that it was difficult in planning the transport scene and in developing transport policy to make any kind of firm prediction based on that time scale. A five-year period, as proposed in the amendment the Opposition will ask honourable senators to consider, will enable reviews of the agreement to be carried out in, say, the third year or the fourth year so that we can establish whether the travelling public benefits from the agreement. The amendment will enable the effectiveness of the new arrangements to be assessed and an assessment made of the market changes. It will enable Parliament and the government of the day to appraise the features of the new generation short haul aircraft which, after all, is relevant because the Government gives guarantees for the purchase of such aircraft. The amendment will enable the Government, the Department of Transport and the Parliament to evaluate changes in the tourist industry, including changes in demand. It will enable the Government and the Parliament to determine any desirable changes to the agreement, with public interest being the prime consideration. The appropriateness of any further extensions of the airline agreement beyond that date or amendment to the agreement could be made in the light of experience, public interest, public concern and other information.

The Minister and Ansett Airlines have chosen by their actions to deny the electorate, the people of Australia and the Parliament. In a general election campaign, a secret deal had been done to restrict the provision of air services in this country for a period of 10 years to the detriment of what the Opposition and the Australian community believes to be the Australian people. Why was the matter kept secret? Perhaps the Minister can inform us. It was kept secret because the Fair Internal Air Fares organisation in Western Australia had proposed to mount a candidate at the Senate election in 1980. This deal, of course, was made in March 1980. On 27 May, having engaged in an exercise to conceal critical information from this Parliament and from the electorate, Sir Peter Abeles had the temerity to make a statement to the Australian Financial Review. The newspaper reported:
Sir Peter Abeles said that he viewed the five year idea very dimly and that Ansett would not have committed itself to its big re-equipment program if it had known it was not to have a 10 year term.

The Ansett company knew; the Parliament, including Government back benchers, did not. The Minister for Transport and the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) had done a deal on behalf of the Government. Sir Peter Abeles, in an attempt to pre-empt this Parliament and to bludgeon the honest men and women of integrity on the other side of the chamber who know that this proposal is not right from the point of view of the Australian people, had the temerity to claim the company would not have gone ahead with its re-equipment plans if the agreement was not to be for a 10 year term.

In this proposal Sir Peter Abeles and the Government engaged in that conspiracy to pre-empt the decisions of the Parliament and to conceal from the public what they were about. If the amendment is carried, and we invite support from the men and women of integrity on the other side of the chamber-the people who are prepared to put the public interest first-it is the Opposition's intention to have a review in year three and year four of the five year term in which the Senate would carry out its correct and proper role as a House of review. It would carry out the kind of analysis and assessment that I have indicated. If immediate changes cannot be made to the existing arrangements because of their complexity, these changes could be discussed and debated and means established to determine how new equipment could be brought in, how air fare structures could be changed if necessary and how greater flexibility and better service could be provided to the Australian people. I foreshadow moving the following amendment:
Page 3, after clause 8, add the following new clause:
Cessation of operation of Act
'9. (1) This Act, unless sooner repealed, shall cease to be in force at the expiration of 5 years after the date of commencement of this Act.

(2) For the purposes of section 8 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, when this Act ceases to be in force by virtue of sub-section (1), it shall thereupon be deemed to have been repealed by an Act other than this Act.'.

The alterations to the Airlines Agreement Bill have been very cleverly drafted to preclude any possible amendments. It is all or nothing as far as this Government is concerned. It has tried to put its rebels into place. The expert legal advice received by the Australian Labor Party is that the form of the amendment which I have foreshadowed, given the context of the Bill and the manner in which the agreement has been drafted and placed in the Schedule, would be effective if carried. The Opposition asks honourable senators opposite to give consideration to this amendment as indeed the Opposition will be considering the amendments to be moved both by Government members and the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret that Senator Gietzelt lapsed at times into using rather intemperate language. I will leave it to the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) to correct those points when he replies at the end of the debate. Australian civil aviation is at an historical point. It is a time of probably the greatest legislative change and probably the most imaginative and most creative move that we have seen in this Parliament. The consequences of these changes simply cannot be foreseen by us tonight. It is a truism, I suppose, that transport is very important to Australia. Australia is a big country with a low density population. While we do not have to move so many people, we have to move some big bulky supplies around. We need the most efficient form of transportation in all fields-surface and air. I sometimes think that interest in aviation as a transport medium is over-emphasised with respect to the great importance of all the surface forms of transport. I am not arguing for less emphasis to be placed on air movements but rather for more emphasis to be placed on road, rail and sea borne trade around Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank the Minister for allowing the chamber to debate these Bills cognately. This leads to an economic use of time. It is a much more efficient way to deal with the legislation than the course followed in the House of Representatives last night. There are so many interesting and important points in the four Bills before us that one must set priorities for discussion in the short period we have to debate them. The first Airlines Agreement Act was passed in 1952. Since that time progressively tighter controls on the industry have been passed by the Parliament. The first significant tightening in the level of control took place roughly 20 years ago. The time of the death of Ivan Holyman presaged the end of the second Australian National Airways Pty Ltd.

ANA at that time was in trouble as a result of its own bad commercial judgment and not as a result of the regulatory policies of the government at the time. It misinterpreted the trend in equipment and the passenger appeal that would come from it. Having started with DC3s, it progressed to DC4s and for a short time was one of the few airlines to operate the rare DC5. The company then bought DC6As and DC6Bs. To the public at the time that type of aircraft was just another propeller driven aircraft and was indistinguishable from the DC4s. Trans-Australia Airlines, a young company in the early 1950s which was managed much more aggressively than in later years, moved into new equipment with the Convairs and then the turboprop Viscounts. It cornered the passenger market. The combination of poor equipment with poor management led ANA into considerable commercial difficulties.

In the circumstances of the 1950s, there was a great belief that governments could do everything: They could heal the sick, cure poverty, educate everyone and make everyone wealthy. So it really was not surprising that the Government felt it could move in and, by legislative means, develop an effective airline industry. In the last 30 years, we have seen the inappropriateness of governments being in the market place. It has become very clear to all of us who take any interest in the economy that the further a government is removed from a market place the healthier is that market place, the lower is the inflation rate, the more people there are employed and the greater is the increase in standards of living.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where can you prove that anywhere in the world?

—I can prove it. Most governments have gone so far down the path of socialisation that it is very hard to find an example. But, if one looks at countries such as Japan, Taiwan, and Singapore, one will find examples of freer economies which have been successful.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome these Bills because they represent a positive sign of a turning point in the philosophy of this Government, back towards a freer market economy. They mark a significant change in the attitude of the Government towards its place in the market. Although the changes themselves do not take us very far down the path, one can go back to that old Chinese statement that a journey of a thousand miles begins with but a single step. I believe that here we have taken two or three.

The agreement before us replaces that contained in the two-airline legislation. The Airlines Agreement Act, under which the two major airlines are operating, although it has preserved the place of those airlines as majors on the Australian trunk routes, has resulted in both airlines having the same fares, the same equipment, flying the same routes and competing against one another in an eternal race around Australia using parallel timetables. The public is sick of that and, last year, the Government, recognising the fact, encouraged Ansett to buy equipment which was different from that ordered by TAA. Without being unduly critical of the two-airline agreement, all that it has produced in the way of competition has been competition of a very phoney kind-to see who can give away the most food and drink. That move has only added to the costs of travel to the Australian public. The cost of the free drinks, the free sandwiches and all the other gimmicks involved inevitably is passed on to the Australian community.

In fairness to the airlines, it must be said that even if they had wanted to operate in a different way they simply could not have competed because under the present agreement they have been tied in respect of so many issues that initiative and room to move have been denied them. The consequence has been that both airlines have become, relatively speaking, inefficient. The result of that inefficiency has been the imposition of higher air fares than should be paid by the Australian traveller. I have heard it said in this chamber, and have read in the Press, that really Australian air fares are not high at all. That is an incorrect assumption. The case is put that air fares in the United States are comparable to those in Australia; that when one takes account of the exchange rate, and looks at the whole route structure there is not much in it. It is also said that our fares are significantly lower than are air fares in Europe.

In Europe, air transport is not a means of mass travel at all. If you want to go anywhere you hop on one of the excellent trains which run between the capitals of Europe and arrive much sooner than you would if you flew. In considering the position in the United States, one must emphasise that an air traveller has access to a far wider range of fares than is provided by the standard fare structure that is available in Australia. I recall a time in January of this year when I wanted to fly from Boston to Los Angeles on my way home. If I had flown at four in the afternoon I could have done so in a 747, using a regular public transport service, for about $US140. I wanted to be in Los Angeles by about four in the afternoon so I flew with a different airline at a cost of somewhere around $US450. Both flights were regular public transport services. Such considerations are not taken into account in statistics. I am not referring to discount fares, advance purchase excursion fares or anything like that. The range of fares available to travellers in the United States is far wider than is the range of fares available to travellers in Australia. So one can fly more cheaply in that country. A secondary factor is that salaries in the United States are a bit higher so that the number of hours to be worked to pay for an air fare is slightly lower than would be the case here.
One of the causes of inefficiency in the Australian airlines is having too many employees. Paragraph 6.63 of the Holcroft report, which is found at page 69, states:
Hocking in his paper 'Economic Efficiency of the Australian Airlines' . . . said:

'There are two alternative conclusions. Either the quality of service on Australian airlines is significantly greater than that in the U.S.A., or Australian airlines are technically inefficient in the sense that the same output could be produced with much less labour. Both conclusions are bad. The quality of service in terms of safety, cabin attendance, booking efficiency and so on is, we suggest, quite high enough on American airlines.
'If the Australian airlines are technically inefficient, this may not be entirely the fault of their management.'
I have obtained from the Parliamentary Library figures on the number of employees in Australian airlines, also some American airlines. I seek leave to have the table incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows-

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The table gives indicators of performance of employees in the airlines in relation to task performed. The column 'Freight and Mail Tonne Kilometres' shows figures per employee of 6,100 for Ansett and 7000 for TAA against a high figure of 37,000 for Continental and 27,000 for Braniff. Of the figures for the American airlines, the lowest is 12,400. Roughly, the American airlines carry twice the amount of freight per employee that the Australian airlines carry. Under the column 'Passenger Kilometres per Employee', the figure is 507,100 for TAA and 425,500 for Ansett as against 1,313,900 for American and 1,202,900 for Eastern. In other words, there is considerable disparity. Lest anyone say that because the Australian airlines, TAA and Ansett, are significantly smaller than the American airlines they do not enjoy the economies of scale, I refer to page 193 of the Holcroft report which deals with the issue and makes the point that economy of scale is not really relevant with airlines as it is with some other industries. At paragraph 11.35 on page 193, the Holcroft Report states:

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to costs, the Inquiry is disturbed by the apparent tendency of the present system to result in fleet capacity increases to provide for extra traffic which was induced by air fare discounting. Where this additional traffic fails to meet the profit impact test, it threatens to add to the level of core fares.
Paragraph 11.36 states in part:
Evidence given by East-West Airlines and others before the Inquiry suggests that there are, in general, few substantial economies of scale in the airline industry.

I suggested earlier in my speech that the freeing of Government restraint on the airline industry is one of the keys to reducing air fares. The answer to our problems is not to follow the route so beloved by the Opposition of having one airline. I refer the Opposition to the mess that the British have got themselves into with the British Overseas Airways Corporation as it used to be called, and British European Airways. I refer them also to the problems the New Zealand airlines have with Air New Zealand. What the Government must do and what these Bills to a very large extent do is to allow some true competition to develop between TAA and Ansett in all ways and, most importantly, to allow the possibility of a third or fourth carrier coming onto the scene.

I would like to go back and deal with the sanctity of only two airlines operating in Australia because it is often said that we cannot tolerate economically more than two airlines in this country. Holcroft examined that proposition on page 48 of his report. He said:

In . . . 1952 . . . the Government retained TAA, being, it said, opposed to monopolies. The Prime Minister, Mr Robert Menzies added ' . . . we believe that there is no room for more than two major national operators if the necessary standards of efficiency are to be maintained'. This statement is significant, because it identifies as a foundation of the two airline policy the view that the technology and scale of airline operations was such that the Australian network could not support more than two airlines of the size necessary for efficiency. Yet the evidence today is strongly against this belief in economies of scale and decreasing unit costs of providing a service. Thus the main presumption underlying the inauguration of the Two Airlines Policy is not now applicable if it ever was.

The purpose of government involvement in the airline industry is safety. Safety takes pre-eminence above all else. A secondary function of government is to prevent unfair economic competition in the market place which compromises that safety. My mind goes back to the early 1960s when I read a report of an interview with the then Director of Civil Aviation, Donald Anderson, as he was before he was knighted. He was asked by the interviewer why Australian airlines were safe. Donald Anderson said at that time-it is still true today-that profitable airlines are safe airlines. It does not necessarily follow that there are no accidents if an airline is profitable, but one can be quite dogmatic in the belief that an unprofitable airline, which is cutting costs at every avenue, will be an unsafe airline. So the Government has a responsibility to maintian minimal control on the industry so that the operators are not taken to the brink of economic hardship.

This airline industry is a great industry, and the changes proposed by the Government are reasoned and planned changes. They provide for four great advances: First of all, the consideration of the selling of Trans-Australian Airlines; secondly, the separation of freight operations from airline passenger traffic; thirdly, the creation of an independent air fares tribunal; and, fourthly, the establishment of a deregulation inquiry. The decision to look at selling TAA represents a maturation in Government thinking-a maturation that I applaud the Government for because only 12 months ago it was unthinkable that the Government would have looked at following that path. Yet that path is inevitable if we are to get costs down in Australian airline traffic. For those people who misinterpret what is going on, it does not mean that TAA will disappear from Australia or that it will no longer serve the people of Australia. As a public company it will do so every bit as well as and better than it does as a government instrumentality.

While TAA is a government instrumentality we must have a two-airlines agreement, because we have a public company competing in the market place with a government authority. Therefore, we have to have an airlines agreement Bill which protects the non-government airline from a rapacious Treasury or a rapacious government on the Treasury benches. We have to write a Bill of great complexity to cover all the eventualities. That means high costs and high air fares. The answer to that is to put both airlines on the same footing. We simply cannot nationalise Ansett because that is not a political reality, but we can sell TAA. My hope is that when TAA is sold, subject to constraints as to who owns it so that it does not become a monopoly with the other airline, we will see the abolition of the airline agreement with its greatly restrictive clauses and we will get some real competition into the market place and some lower fares.

The second great change proposed in this legislation relates to freight. Freight operations are a specialised field. It has been shameful that governments of all persuasions have denied any competition in the freight field. Because of the way in which the business has been operated it has been made very difficult for operators to get freight licences, and when licences were obtained licence holders were denied the right to import aircraft. As I said before, that is a shameful way to go. I believe the opening up of the freight market is a great and significant step forward.

The third proposal in the legislation is the creation of an independent air fares tribunal which will be free of airline and Department of Transport control. Its guidelines in fare setting will be that fares shall be related to cost and that those fares shall be nationally uniform. I do not resile for one moment from the fact that that may produce some great changes in the far pricing structure in Australia because we in this country have not been setting fares on a cost related basis. But it is important from a business point of view that we know what it costs to provide a service. I hope that the independent air fares tribunal will provide that information because then we will get a fairer and more equitable basis for fares and ultimately again cheaper fares.

The final proposal for a deregulation inquiry is of great significance. I stressed earlier in this speech that government interference at an unnecessary level in the market place leads to increased costs. I do not have a wildly optimistic view about deregulation. I do not believe that an open skies policy will be appropriate in Australia, and in one way I think an open skies policy is a bit of a blue skies belief. But I am more than prepared to examine in detail the process of deregulation to see what benefits can come from it, because any investigation of deregulation will lead to some reduction of government interference in the market place. I simply do not believe there is anyone in either chamber of this Parliament who can say what the fare between Sydney and Melbourne should be. I am quite convinced, having read the Holcroft report, that no one in the Department of Transport who is vested with the authority to set those fares, can do so either. That is the business of the airlines in consultation with an informed committee.

There are three minor clouds on the horizon with this legislation. The first refers to clause 12 in the Schedule to the Airlines Agreement Bill 1981. I do not doubt the necessity for the inclusion of clause 12 which, I think, is quite necessary for the protection of the public. However, it allows the airlines to give notice to quit when they are losing money on routes-and they will be rural routes. I cannot overstate in this chamber the problem as it relates to Queensland. It will cause all parliamentary representatives a great deal of trouble as TAA, which is losing a current figure of over $1.5m a year in providing a very valuable service through western Queensland, moves inevitably to withdraw its Friendships from that service. At present that $1.5m loss on the western routes in Queensland is being laid off and subsidised by all the other TAA traffic in Australia. Under the new Bill it will be forbidden for the airlines to cross-subsidise in that way because the fare structure will be based in jet traffic alone, not on turbo-prop aircraft.

The reason for that loss is quite simple-there are not enough passengers travelling on the routes. It is no more difficult than that. However, it is important that we have this capacity on those routes because the alternative is to go for the light twins of the commuter airlines. The route characteristics are of long stage lengths and harsh environmental conditions, with high ambient temperatures. The light twin-type aircraft that conforms to air navigation regulation 203 that is used for commuter aircraft simply does not provide the safe and effective form of transport that we need in that area. In my judgment the answer to that is to buy the right equipment but, unfortunately, that is not available at present and it is probably five or six years off. As the existing service provides a necessity for the west the answer, in my judgment, is to provide a short term subsidy until such time as the right equipment can be introduced. I make it quite clear to the Senate that in the fullness of time I shall be asking for a subsidy to keep TAA on the western routes until alternative equipment can be provided.

The second point I have some reservations about is the Independent Air Fares Committee. Part III, clause 17, of the Bill deals with the approval of discount air fares and the introduction of a third operator on to a trunk route, on which Ansett and TAA are operating. I will seek the advice of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) on this matter in the Committee stage but the clause seems to indicate that if Ansett and TAA can show that passengers are flying with the third airline and that their costs will inevitably go up because those passengers who could have flown with them are flying with the third operator, then the third operator will have to charge the same air fare as the major carriers. That would effectively deny the third carrier a place on the route. I think that is an unduly restrictive clause to put in the legislation because one can conceive an operator such as East-West Airlines or Bush Pilots Airways Ltd being able to put on equipment at odd times and attract passengers by discounting a fare with respect to the major carriers. I think that in the interests of the travelling public that facility should be provided.

The third point I make about the legislation relates to the magnitude of the changes involved. I believe there is an unanswerable case to provide some safeguard for the public in this legislation. As I said earlier, these are reasoned and planned changes. Let us look at what is involved. We have new equipment coming to all the airlines of a dimension we have never seen before. What is more, it is different equipment. Trans-Australia Airlines will have the Airbus and Ansett will have the 767s. The different equipment will dictate that there be a different operating pattern for the airlines. There will be an abolition of the parallel timetables. There will be a different fare basing structure. No freight will be involved. There may well be defects in the legislative process we have before us, as I have indicated with respect to those two earlier points.

In summary, the two airlines will be operating in a totally different commercial environment from that in which they have operated up to the present. Of course, the overall economic situation is something that we cannot foresee. The way fuel prices have changed so dramatically in the last five or six years, who knows what will come in the future? This is the greatest era of change in our history and I believe that the Parliament has a right to protect the public interest. It has a right to protect the Government's interest in the agreement. It has a right to protect TAA and Ansett. Therefore, I believe that there is a case for a review period.

I accept that the minimal period of tenure for the agreement should be eight years. That is the period that is acceptable to the Government and to the two airlines. In passing, I say that I regret the degree of misinformation that has been in the Press about this point. I can speak only for myself but I am quite happy to accept that an eight-year minimal period should be the period for the agreement. I know that Ansett Airlines accepts that eight-year period. Furthermore, I think it would be reasonable to suggest that Ansett would like some warning period. Ansett would be happy to look at a review point earlier than eight years providing the agreement is not changed within eight years. It is in its commercial interest to have a longer setting up time. I am not aware of any objections from TAA to this proposal. I am not aware that the Government, when it has a quiet think about the proposition, will have any objection either. I think it is just a responsible and common-sense way to act.

Therefore, I will be moving an amendment in the Committee stage which puts a review period into one part of the Bill and which in no way at all alters the sense or the intent of that Bill. In conclusion I congratulate the Cabinet and all those Government members who have put so much work into this Bill. It has been one of the biggest pieces of legislation that has come through the Parliament in the short time I have been here. I think it is a step forward that is of great benefit to the Australian people. We are on the right road with this legislation and it has my full support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator MacGibbon on a most thoughtful speech. In his wildest dreams he could never be accused of being a rampant socialist nor, I hope, could I be accused of being a hard-nosed tory. I think that 90 per cent of what he had to say tonight finds total agreement with my philosophy and the philosophy of the Australian Democrats. We deplore the fact that four such complex and far-reaching Bills are being rammed through the Parliament in such a short time. These Bills were introduced in the House of Representatives-very late-only last Thursday, 28 May. They were rushed through that House yesterday. In fact, it was not until 5 p.m. today that we could even get the Hansard of the House of Representatives to look at and study the debate that took place in that chamber. Now the Bills are being rushed through the Senate, although only one week has gone by since they were introduced into the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Almost every day there has been a saga of alterations to the legislation. For those who have not been privileged to attend the back bench committees with the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt)-that includes all members of the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats-the only information has come from news leaked to newspapers. Quite often during the week different newspapers have carried different versions of where the legislation has been going and to what extent the Minister and the Cabinet have been agreeable to changing it. Also confusing are the reports of the attitudes of Sir Peter Abeles and Ansett Airlines of Australia to the proposed changes. I will have more to say about that in a moment.

The performance tonight would be bad enough if it were a quiet week but the Government seems determined to make a mockery of the Parliament. Several very important and complicated Bills have been introduced all at the one time. There have been various income tax amendment Bills, the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill, the Housing Assistance Bill, the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Bill, Customs amendment Bills, the Road Grants Bill, and non-controversial matters such as the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill, the Koongarra Project Area Bill and the State and local government tax sharing Bills. On top of all that there is the razor gang omnibus legislation.

The Australian Democrats will remember the contempt with which the Government is now treating the Parliament. We will remember that for a long time. I make this point: I remind the Government that the Australian Democrats will be here at least until 1987. During that time the Government will be bringing in a great deal of contentious legislation. The Senate and Australians can rest assured that all that legislation will be given the closest scrutiny it deserves. In less than just a month the time will be over forever when the Government will be able to treat at least this chamber like a rubber stamp. All legislation will gain the attention it deserves.

We regard these airline Bills as unacceptable. We suggest that this is amply demonstrated by the fact that eight Government members in the House of Representatives crossed the floor last night to vote against these Bills. This was the biggest back bench revolt in the history of the Fraser Government and surely one of the biggest in Australian political history. I just hope that the courage shown by those Western Australians and others who crossed the floor of the House of Representatives last night will be followed by their Western Australian, Queensland, and Tasmanian colleagues in the Senate this evening. The Australian Democrats will be supporting the sunset amendment to be moved by Senator MacGibbon at the appropriate time in the Committee stage.

I regard what has been made known to me today as a deplorable tactic. I have heard it through several avenues. Each avenue and each source, particularly this afternoon, has made it palpably clear that this came from the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) himself. This information was that if the Senate tonight accepts Senator MacGibbon's amendment, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) who represents the Minister for Transport in this place would immediately report progress and that would be the end of this Bill. In other words, the Government has told the Senate-more particularly it has told its own Government members like Senator Bjelke-Petersen: 'If you and five other senators dare cross the floor on this issue tonight and support Australians obtaining cheaper air fares, this Bill will be withdrawn and will never surface again'. In other words, the situation would be that the old airline agreement which has been in operation for over 20 years, will run on and on to the advantage of Ansett Airlines of Australia. It will allow that airline to continue to hold the licence to print money and run its business on a cost-plus basis.

I believe it is a scandal that the Executive and the Prime Minister can so publicly threaten members of Parliament and that that message could be conveyed to me. As Leader of the Australian Democrats I was told that we had better watch out. Honourable senators from Western Australia, Queensland and Tasmania who support Senator MacGibbon's amendment have been told that they must watch out. If they do so, that will be the end of this amending legislation which has occupied the newspapers for the past month. I leave the Senate to make up its mind about the respectability of those sorts of tactics. One would wonder what effect this threat will have on the independent Senator, Senator Harradine, who represents a State which is savaged by the kind of air fares which people who travel to and from Tasmania are being charged.

The Government's problems on this question stem from its decision last November to truncate the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares. Once the Government received the committee's report early in February, rather than the middle of this year, it chose to ignore most of it and poured scorn on the heads of its distinguished members. The hatchet job on the Holcroft committee has been very skilfully done. If one searched the newspapers about that time, one would have found little public comment by Ministers or public servants on the capabilities or efficiency of the three members of the Holcroft committee. The scuttle-butt has gone around this place. By way of gossip, each of them has been bucketed in a very efficient way. Since early this year I have been calling for the Government to reopen the Holcroft inquiry so that it can finish its work or, preferably, the setting up of a Senate committee of inquiry into the same question. To fulfil that undertaking that I have been talking about for several months, I now move as an amendment to the motion before the Chair:

At the end of motion, add , 'but the Senate is of the opinion that a select committee of the Senate should be established to complete the inquiry undertaken by the Holcroft Committee into domestic air fares'.

Why should not the work of this committee be complete?
