To reach fully informed conclusions about questions of basic importance to the airline industry, the Holcroft committee recommended a formula for air fares. A lot of criticism has been made of the formula that was put forward by the Holcroft inquiry. I agree with many of those criticisms. I think it is a suspect formula. But any formula would be preferable to the Government's arbitrary approach to fee setting. How does any Western Australian senator tonight know that the arbitrary reduction of $9 that the Government plucked out of thin air and said: 'That is the proper reduction in the fare Western Australians should pay for a journey from the west coast to the east coast' is correct? How do we know that $150 should not have been knocked off? How do we know that it should not have been more? We will not know. Western Australia, Tasmania and Queensland have not been told the basis upon which the Government has made its judgment about the fares applying to those States. It has simply plucked the figures out of the air. I wish someone would respond and ask: 'Why are the Australian Democrats moving that this matter go to a Senate select committee?' We have proposed in the legislation the Independent Air Fares Committee. If one reads the Bills carefully one will see that it would take that Committee at least two years-probably more-to get any form of result. That means that Western Australians, Queenslanders-particularly those from the north-Tasmanians and to a lesser extent South Australians, would in that two-year period be paying massive sums to subside the journeys of people travelling between Melbourne, Sydney and Brisbane. We believe that a Senate select committee-an all-party committee-could be appointed forthwith and come up with a reasonable result within at least six months. We will push for that. In passing, I note that the agreement's treatment of the term 'trunk route' is also unsatisfactory. We think that these routes should be listed and be made known in order to protect the smaller operators. I mention the name of one company-East-West Airlines Ltd-whose arguments to Senator Mason and me have been most persuasive. It is a battling commuter airline which is trying to provide a service at a cheaper cost to air travellers. That airline seems to be, under this agreement, placed totally at the mercy of the major airlines. We will be making an appropriate comment on this at the Committee stage.

The airlines agreement proposed by this Bill is completely unsatisfactory. Under its terms the agreement could theoretically operate indefinitely plus three years so long as the Government, Trans-Australia Airlines and Ansett agreed on this. That is the reason we intend to support Senator MacGibbon's sunset clause amendment under which the Act ceases to be in force after eight years. That is, after the expiration of five years, three years' notice of termination could be given. But in any event, the agreement cannot last more than eight years. Ideally, we would want an amendment to the Bill to operate in such a way that it would be mandatory on the government of the day-whichever complexion it may be because we are talking about a time five years from now and there will be a general election before then-to let the proposed committee on deregulation do this work, produce its report and at that point force the government of the day, whether it is Labor or coalition, to take some positive act, either to notify termination or to tell the two airlines: 'At the end of eight years it will be open skies' or 'We are now persuaded that deregulation is not on and therefore at the end of eight years we will be signing a new agreement'. To me that would be palpably fair. It would be above board because within five years the Government would have to make a decision and would have to bring that decision to Parliament. Parliament could debate it. The two airlines, both TAA and Ansett, would know exactly where they stood and the whole question of whether deregulation would be a good thing could sensibly be debated in this Parliament. I share Senator MacGibbon's feelings or views that without pre-empting the work of the committee, I cannot see how any committee can come forward in a country like Australia, with its special and peculiar problems, and recommend an open skies policy. For the sake of Western Australians and north Queenslanders, one hopes that it could, but I believe that that will be the inevitable result. Under this agreement we are asked to ratify and under the Bill we are asked to pass tonight, after the expiration of five years the agreement could go on and on. The present legislation before us does not force either the Government or an airline to notify termination. The agreement could go for 10 years. At that stage one of the parties could say: 'A three-year notice of termination will be given'. The agreement could go for 100 years and then the Government could say: 'Three years from now we terminate'. I make it palpably clear that although I say this two-airline agreement is in fact giving a private company, Ansett Airlines, a licence to print money on a cost plus basis, I bear no animosity towards that company. In fact, I hold it in very high regard, for business, personal and many other reasons. It is a fine airline. It is extraordinarily well run and is a fine example--

TALK.START.PARA: —The hostesses are not what they used to be.

—I would agree with Senator Tate in a flash. I believe that Sir Peter Abeles has been misrepresented, possibly through nobody's fault, about what he wants. I had a conversation with him today. It was the only time that I have spoken with him in several weeks. He rang me specifically to say that he does not favour a sunset clause. I thought he did, because the newspapers have contained reports to that effect. He said that he had written to the Minister explaining his reasons. In fairness to his point of view, I have before me a short letter from him to the Minister for Transport giving the reasons why he would agree to an eight-year period but not to a sunset clause. I seek leave to have that letter incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Mr Dear Minister,

Referring to the new two airlines agreement and the legislative package to go with it, I would appreciate an assurance from you and your Government that by the end of the fifth year, Parliament would give us a clear indication:
(A) whether the Government wishes to give us three years' notice and, if so, if there is a new two airlines agreement to come into force at the end of eight years;
(B) alterations that would be made to the then running two airlines agreement; or
(C) if you were to decide to go for a free sky policy, under what conditions the Government would wish to do so.

I think it is really imperative that at the end of the fifth year, everybody should know what rules will be at the end of the notice period to secure an orderly transition period so that all parties can prepare for the future.
If you decide not to give us notice at the end of the five year period, then the same request would apply in any year in which you wish to give us notice.
The support of you and your colleagues would be greatly appreciated.
Yours sincerely, Peter Abeles

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The Government's Bill, if enacted, will operate indefinitely. I agree with Senator MacGibbon, who knows much more about the technology of flying than I do--
—They call him Biggles.
—Biggles?
—Bigglesworth.

—It fits, yes. With the incredible rate of growth of technology, to have an agreement under which there is virtually a duopoly-because of the lack of proper structure in TAA, Ansett can beat it on a break at any time, and that is no reflection against the people of TAA whose present structure prevents it from being an efficient competitor-and to let the agreement go on ad infinitum--
—Passengers don't.

—The passengers do not. I suggest that the honourable senator might look at profits. I am always grateful for the interjections of my friend from Queensland. For this reason, we should not tie up something indefinitely. Who knows whether within five years, eight years or 10 years, with the growth of technology and the kind of aircraft and procedures that will be available to us, we will find ourselves still hamstrung by a policy under which we have a duopoly or a virtual monopoly?

SPEECH.PARA: The idea put forward by the Australian Labor Party in the House of Representatives last night, which would have brought the agreement to a dead halt after five years, is not acceptable to the Australian Democrats. We will be voting against the Labor Party's foreshadowed amendment to that effect to be moved tonight to the question that the Bill be read a second time. We believe that the rules of the game have been announced. The agreement was to remain in effect for 10 years. About a month ago, this Senate said: 'We will approve a loan Bill so that Ansett can borrow money to buy the equipment costing hundreds of millions of dollars'. All of us know when we passed that Bill that in our minds, Ansett's mind and the Government's mind, the legislation was to remain in force for 10 years. They were the rules of the game. Once we have declared the rules of the game, once the game has begun, once the ball has bounced, I do not think it is fair to change the rules. I do not think it would be fair to say to Sir Peter Abeles, once the game has begun: 'Righto, you thought you had 10 years but now you have only five years'. Sir Peter Abeles himself has agreed to a reduction from 10 years to eight years. That is why the Democrats support the eight-year sunset clause, even though Sir Peter Abeles does not. He does not object to the period of eight years. However, we will be supporting the amendment which the Labor Party is to move in the Committee stage and which Senator Gietzelt has foreshadowed.

It is not fair that the agreement should be allowed to run indefinitely when future circumstances are so unpredictable. There is no way of knowing how much deregulation will be desirable in 10, 15 or 20 years time. We cannot afford to be locked into an agreement as restrictive as the one that the Government is suggesting. Our proposal is that after five years the Government should announce what will happen in another three years when the new scheme, whether it is to effect deregulation, partial deregulation or even continuation of the two airlines scheme, comes into operation in eight years from now, that is, in 1989. I hope that the Senate will agree to that proposal tonight. I think the Senate is living in a moment of high drama. We have a commitment from Senator MacGibbon to cross the floor and vote with the Democrats and the Labor Party on this question. I am given to understand at this stage that at least two other Government senators are prepared to do that also. If two other Government senators-I assume that Senator Harradine will vote with the Government on this issue-were to cross the floor on this issue, we could put a sunset clause into the legislation which I believe would bring justice to the airline policy in our country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomas Sen A.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Airlines Agreement Bill and the associated Bills that make up this complete package. It is a package for which I am extremely grateful. I congratulate the Government on bringing it down. I have been very closely involved with the negotiations over at least two years. It has been a long and hard haul. I believe that this package should move us towards less regulation in the airline industry in Australia and it follows that it should lead towards more competition in that industry. I have mentioned that there has been a very thorough consideration by the Government of this matter over at least two years, but that can also be said of the public. The public has been heavily involved to an extent never seen before in an inquiry such as this. I am pleased with and rather proud of the efforts of the Western Australian Liberal back benchers in leading the effort to encourage the Government to come up with what it has finally proposed.

SPEECH.PARA: What has been achieved? First of all, we are moving towards a situation in which we are eliminating to a large extent the degree of cross subsidisation that was demonstrated in the Holcroft report. We are setting up an air fares committee which will be entirely separate from the Department of Transport and which will set what it sees as cost-based fares on each route. I believe that this is the best possible move under the present regulated system. We are committed to turning Trans-Australia Airlines into a public company and we are establishing an inquiry to make recommendations to the Government on the level of shareholding that should be held by the Government and by the general public. There is to be an inquiry into the deregulation of the Australin airline industry and the report of that inquiry is to come down within five years. Five years may seem a long time to those of us who get pretty impatient but it will take at least that long, in my opinion, to investigate the system properly. The United States of America ventured into deregulation some years ago but I believe that it will be quite some time before whether the American experiment has worked can be properly and adequately assessed. So many conflicting reports have come out of the United States. My friend and colleague Senator Collard and I argue about this very subject as least once a day. He uses his selective reports and I use my selective reports. We are a long way apart in our views. This is the sort of problem that the inquiry will sort out.

Some problems have arisen with the proposed two-airline agreement. One has been demonstrated by East-West Airlines, with which I have had discussions and have exchanged many letters. I hope that its particular problem can be resolved. I believe that the new airline agreement is unduly restrictive in that it makes it virtually impossible for a new operator to enter the industry on major routes. As I have said, our regulated system, which after all sets out to protect Ansett and TAA, provides very little option for that. I believe in the gradual deregulation of the industry. I believe also that the Government has moved in the right direction.

I will outline some of the activities of the Western Australian Federal back benchers in the events culminating in the legislation before us tonight. We have had a large number of meetings with the previous Minister for Transport, Mr Nixon, and with Mr Hunt since he was appointed Minister for Transport. We have also had many meetings with the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). These meetings have involved really tough negotiations. I thank the Government for the huge step it has taken from its original stand. In particular, I pay tribute to my Western Australian Liberal back bench colleagues for the extremely hard work they have done to achieve what has been achieved. I will not support Senator MacGibbon's proposed amendment. I reached that decision only late this morning. The reason why I will not support it is that I am convinced that to pass that amendment would be to destroy everything that has been achieved so far. That decision has nothing to do with the fact that I am Deputy Whip. In fact, I decided last night that I would resign this morning from this position. I recognise very clearly the obligations that the holder of this position has to the Government. I apologise to my Western Australian colleagues who may feel that I have deserted them and let them down. That is something which I will have to live with. But I am convinced, after many discussions early this morning, that to pass the amendment would be to destroy everything that has been achieved in the last two years. I am not prepared to take that risk.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are discussing the Airlines Agreement Bill 1981 and related Bills. As we know there are four Bills in all. Much has been said about the benefits that will flow to the airline companies but very little has been said about what will flow to the paying public, the travelling public. I believe that one should look at why these agreements are put in legislation and who will benefit from them. In the first place, the two-airlines agreement provides for the Government to hand over to two multi-millionaires its sovereign right to determine air policy. I believe that that is at the back of the Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: When Sir Peter Abeles, the proprietor of the Thomas Nationwide Transport organisation, and Mr Rupert Murdoch, the proprietor of News Ltd, took over Ansett Airlines of Australia they paid out a gigantic sum of money on the stock exchange. For the next eight years the paying public will pay for that huge takeover. On top of that, when Sir Peter Abeles became the manager of Ansett and began running that company he forced new concessions on Ansett. He certainly improved the meals of Ansett and provided free drinks. Consequently, some of the travelling public left Trans-Australia Airlines and went to Ansett. TAA was then forced to give this extra service. Many people may say that that is good and in some ways it is, but it has all meant an increase in fares for the paying public.

I want to put on the record an indication of how air fares have escalated in the last three years. I think it is astounding how the prices have risen. I have not taken out figures for first class travellers because anyone who travels first class today usually has his air ticket paid for him. The prices I will give apply only to economy air fares. On 1 June 1978 the air fare from Adelaide to Canberra was $76.60. By 1 June 1981 that fare had risen to $116.20, an increase in three years of $39.60. On 1 June 1978 a person paid $79.70 to travel from Adelaide to Sydney. On 1 June 1981 he paid $119.80, an increase of $40.10 in three years. On 1 June 1978 a person paid $52.60 to fly from Melbourne to Sydney. Today he pays $88.40, an increase of $35.80. On 1 June 1978 a person paid $47.30 to fly from Hobart to Melbourne. Today he pays $74.10, an increase of $26.80. On 1 June 1978 a person paid $24.90 to fly from Canberra to Sydney. On 1 June 1981 he paid $56.20, an increase of $31.30 in a three-year period. Many of our Western Australian colleagues have complained about the air fares. On 1 June 1978 a person travelling economy between Perth and Melbourne paid $173.90. Today he pays $220.10, an increase of $46.20.

This legislation was not introduced just to enable Sir Peter Abeles and Mr Rupert Murdoch to recoup the huge amount of money that they paid out on the stock exchange when they took over that company. It was also introduced because of the hold that Mr Murdoch has today over a lot of political parties and politicians, and I believe that this should be divulged. I believe that Rupert Murdoch makes politicians and political parties jump to his tune. This is no worse than the actions of the Mafia organisation that we have condemned in this country. It is no worse than the actions reported recently in the Melbourne Press of the Vietnamese who are cutting off the fingers and threatening people in the Vietnamese community. Today Peter Abeles does not have to threaten people. In the past he has displayed that characteristic. That is one of the reasons--

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—I heard Senator Walters laugh. She should take into consideration the fact that the Airlines Agreement Bill and the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill are designed directly to help Murdoch simply because he holds a power over political parties. I believe that is evil; it is wrong and it is undemocratic. I believe that the people of Australia should revolt against such a person standing over politicians. Australia is one of the last places where democracy exists. We should not allow stand-over people to operate in this country.
—His father, Keith Murdoch, brought about the fall of the Scullin Government in 1932.
—Is that the same Murdoch?

—That is the same family. I believe that this type of attitude should not be tolerated. It is the general public who will be paying for this new agreement. Such a situation is incorrect. This country should be looking to transport as one of its main avenues to creating a tourist industry. While we are paying the high prices I have mentioned, we can never do this. The tourist industry would be capable of putting many of our young people back to work, but because governments bow and scrape to stand-over people such as those I have mentioned, we will never progress to full employment. All these airline Bills simply relate to the Government's doing what it can for the very wealthy, not for the paying public. Australia is an island continent on which people have to travel long distances. Aircraft is the only suitable method for long distance travel. We should be working out, as a Senate, ways and means of decreasing the cost of travel in this country. People who have to travel from Western Australia, from Tasmania, from the north of Queensland, from my own State of South Australia, and from the Northern Territory, from Darwin down, are entitled to some recognition of the prices they have to pay. In many cases, they work in isolated, hot areas and at least once a year their families go to cooler climates. The cost of transport today is so astronomical that it is becoming prohibitive for the general family to travel.

SPEECH.PARA: We can see the plums that have been given to the major airlines but absolutely nothing has been given to the commuter airlines. Let me give one illustration. Pagas Airlines in South Australia plays a great part in providing transport in that State. It provides a transport service to Leigh Creek and to many other parts of South Australia and into the top end of Queensland. Pagas Airlines wanted to purchase a Nomad aircraft and I made representations on its behalf last year. Had that airline been able to borrow money in this country, which it could not do, to purchase that Nomad aircraft, the interest rate it would have had to pay would have been between 17 per cent and 19 per cent, which was prohibitive. That company tried everywhere in this country to get the money to purchase that aircraft but it could not do so. It was then forced to look at the Brazilian aircraft, the Bandeirante aircraft. The Brazilian Government gave the company the necessary finance at 7 1/2 per cent adjustable interest. That, I believe, is a disgrace. We have lost the aircraft we could have manufactured in this country. The Government gives subsidies and guarantees to major airlines purchasing aircraft overseas, but it does absolutely nothing for commuter aircraft companies that fly into the outback of this country. It does nothing for the people who live in isolated areas, whatever State they live in. Certainly TAA is running a service in the outback of Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —And doing a good job.

—And doing a great job. But under this agreement it can opt out of that service. I believe that is a disgrace. All Australians should have equality, irrespective of whether they live in cities or in outlying areas. I believe that has to be taken into account. As I said before, transport is a vital issue. When I came to this Senate I said that transport was so vital to this country that we, as a Senate, should be endeavouring to reduce the cost of transport. If we were doing our job here tonight we would not be giving plums to very wealthy individuals who own companies. We would be looking at what would benefit the whole of this country; at what is good for the nation, what is good for the people.

SPEECH.PARA: We should form committees to look at this matter, as Senator Chipp has suggested. That should be looked into sensibly and rationally. We can reduce the cost of transport in this country. We should be looking at ways of improving all the conditions in the industry. This Senate should be looking at ways and means of keeping aircraft flying around the clock. Aerodromes are situated in cities but because of noise pollution they have to close at 11 p.m. If we cannot get quieter aircraft, those aerodromes should be placed outside metropolitan areas. As I say, our aircraft are so costly they should be flying 24 hours a day. With co-operation and forward planning they could be. But we do not want to do this. We want to keep air fares up. As I say, there is no benefit to the general public. All the benefit goes simply to the very wealthy of this country, and I object to that. At the appropriate time in the debate on the Independent Air Fares Committee Bill, it is my intention to move the following amendment:
Leave out all words after 'That', insert:
'the Senate is of the opinion that the Bill is deficient in that it does not provide for-
(1) cost allocation reviews on a sufficiently comprehensive and frequent basis;
(2) the involvement of the public, including consumers' representatives, in the review process; and
(3) recognition of the profitability of the major airlines in the conduct of reviews by the Committee'.

The people really do not have a say in this eight-year agreement that is provided in this legislation. A committee comprising three people is to be set up but I notice that no one from the general public, the paying public, and no one from the trade union movement is to be a member of that committee. I believe the committee should be broadened. I believe that a member of the paying public, a person who works in this country and pays for his airline seat is entitled to be on that committee.

As I have pointed out, the cost escalation of air fares in this country in the last three years is a disgrace. The standard of aircraft has improved. With the introduction of the Airbus, there is no reason air fares could not be reduced. The Airbus most certainly will replace DC9 aircraft. I presume that the Airbus will fly from Sydney to Melbourne and that a number of DC9 aircraft will be replaced. There is no reason why the fares on the routes that aircraft will fly could not be reduced. As I said, I believe that unsatisfactory airfields in capital cities should be relocated to remote areas where they will not annoy people. Alternatively, quieter aircraft should be used. I understand that the Airbus will be a quiet aircraft. It is quieter than the Boeing 767 which Ansett Airlines of Australia will buy. I believe that the Senate should stand up for itself. It should not be stood over by the people I have mentioned. I ask the Senate to consider the amendments that the Opposition is moving and to support them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is discussing a package of Bills affectionately known as the airlines Bills. I will not go through their details at this stage. It is no secret that over the last few months we have been looking at the two-airline agreement, the report of the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares. I take on board Senator Chipp's comment that he has not had much time to look at the legislation but I can assure him that quite a few other people have been looking constantly at the Airlines Agreement Bill and the related Bills over a long period so that we hope we can put the airlines of Australia in a better position.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall inform honourable senators of the history of the matter, particularly in relation to the Holcroft report and the much mentioned and, I suppose, much maligned term 'cross-subsidisation'. I must say that my discussions with the airlines some years ago first alerted me to the fact that they were aware that there was a problem with cross-subsidisation-that is, people on long haul routes were paying more than they should compared with those people travelling on the short haul routes. But there was a problem in that, even though they recognised this situation existed, they were finding it difficult to right because of the political implications that would be involved in the highly populated, dense traffic areas of Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane if, without any explanation or justification other than their own figures, they tried to increase the air fares on those short haul routes at a greater rate than on the long haul routes.

Fortunately, the Domestic Air Transport Policy Review gave them the vehicle by which to start righting that wrong. This they did. They pointed out the inequities. Since that time, every air fare increase, to my knowledge, has seen the flag fall component rise at a greater rate than the distance component. This meant that the short haul passengers were bearing a more equal share in the air fare structure in Australia. That was going pretty well, but somewhere along the line a group of people in Western Australia got together and called themselves the Fair Internal Air Fares Committee. Those people got in on the act when the act was just about over. I think I have mentioned here before that that committee put our colleagues from Western Australia under pressure, the like of which few of us have had to experience. They became pretty emotional. It is quite easy to be emotional about disadvantages in a State a long way away. I come from a far away State, and, indeed, I plead guilty to being parochial on more than one occasion. Of course, this campaign got up quite a head of steam. But I frankly do not know what the committee was on about. By the time its members recognised the wrongs, the airlines and the Domestic Air Transport Policy Review had recognised them and the machinery was in place and was correcting that wrong. But by the same token, we had this well orchestrated, well financed campaign, the repercussions of which are still reverberating around Western Australia.

Because of that pressure, the Government established the Holcroft committee to report to the Government. Its original reporting time was to be at the end of January. The committee acknowledged that in correspondence. However, when it was seen that the committee was to take a little longer, and because of a few other factors which are not necessarily relevant to the Bills tonight, the Government said: 'We want you to report at the end of January'. I think it was about the middle of February when we got the report. That report-I have spoken before on it-mentions cross-subsidisation. The campaign got under way again. Let us have a look at cross-subsidisation in the course of discussing these Bills. First of all, I think it must be said that if there are disadvantages, they do not all apply to Western Australians. The end-to-end traffic is generated 50 per cent either way. It was not only Western Australians who would have been disadvantaged. The people in the east travelling west would also have been disadvantaged. This campaign generated a tremendous amount of unreal expectation in the minds of Western Australians. At one stage it was even calculated that because of the Domestic Air Transport Policy Review and the Holcroft report the people of Western Australia could expect a $200 reduction in the return economy fare, an expectation that could never have been realised, but still it was part of the campaign which was generated over there. The Holcroft report mentioned an $11m subsidy on the Sydney-Melbourne run was being contributed to by the long haul passengers. The Melbourne-Perth route in turn was subsidising to the tune of about $8m. I tried to explain in another speech the fact that the Holcroft report never substantiated those claims and never gave us the methodology. The report suggested a new air fare formula-I have spoken on that before-and indeed agreed that the report justified it, but the repercussions of that formula were never looked at. It was just taken for granted that it was right. Using the new formula the total revenue for each sector was worked out and the revenue obtained under the old formula was substracted from it. Therefore, he arrived at the figure which we have seen in the tables in the report and said that that was the tune of the cross-subsidisation. Three basic factors are wrong with that.

First, the report does not take into consideration multi-stage journeys, circuitous routing or discounting. About 20 per cent of the two million passengers each year on the Sydney-Melbourne leg are multi-stage passengers. Thus about 400,000 of them are multi-stage passengers. The flag fall at that time was $21.80. If one multiplies that figure by 400,000 one arrives at an amount of $8.7m or thereabouts. One has almost accounted for two-thirds of the so-called cross-subsidisation already. There is circuitous routing. People going to Alice Springs or Darwin quite often use the Sydney-Perth-Adelaide leg. There is discounting. Over the whole Australian network about 60 per cent of the passengers pay full fare and about 40 per cent of the passengers pay a discounted fare. For very obvious reasons the people on long haul routes who have to pay a higher fare go into a travel bureau and do their homework before they book and look for the best fare. The discount fares on long haul routes total about 52 per cent. In other words more than half the fares paid on long haul routes are discounted. About 48 per cent are at full fare. That is another figure that must be put into the equation when we try to understand where the so-called cross subsidisation has gone wrong. To use plain common sense which sections, if the Australian airline network was put up for sale, would honourable senators look to buy? It is quite obvious that they would opt for the densely populated areas, that is, the Sydney-Melbourne or Melbourne-Sydney-Brisbane run. The whole idea of suggesting that those routes are cross-subsidised to the extent mentioned is completely ridiculous. In the last speech I made on this subject, I incorporated a table which enabled people to decide whether there is cross-subsidisation. It is well nigh impossible to come up with a particular figure, but one can do a notional amount of work to see how fares are standing up. As I understand it, that table has been spread far and wide and has not once been challenged. That table showed that, at the time of the Holcroft report there was still slight cross-subsidisation from long haul to short haul. That fact was recognised and, as I said, it was being righted well before the pressure group in the West got into the act. After the Holcroft formula has been applied we now have substantial cross-subsidisation from short haul to long haul. It has reached the ridiculous stage where even the short haul routes such as from Melbourne to Tasmania are now cross-subsidising the long haul routes. That was never the intention. If that formula had been right in the first instance, we would not have needed that subsidy towards Tasmanian travellers.

I submit that the campaign to which my colleagues have been subjected and which has been transmitted through them to this place has been based on a pretty false premise. They have used a fair bit of emotionalism; they have used, or misused, the Press. Some of the Press statements which have been released cannot be substantiated. They have been quite scurrilous. Their people have called into question one of the best, safest, most efficient and cheapest airline systems in the world. I admit that it does have faults, but we must take into consideration all the problems which occur in providing Australia with airline services. My colleague Senator MacGibbon mentioned the discounts that are available in the United States. There are discounts in America, but it was not too many years ago when Australia offered more discounts than America. America went overboard with its discounts, so much so that the airlines literally could not afford them.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were all going broke.

—That is certainly another point; they certainly are going broke. So many discounts were offered that, if a person rang up to book a flight, it would take the reservations clerk about two hours to give him the best deal he possibly could. Those airlines found that they had to put on an extraordinary number of people in the reservations area, so any benefit that might have accrued to those airlines by filling their aircraft was soon dissipated by their overheads connected with the extra reservations clerks. At that stage those airlines cut out most of their discounts and Australia was offering more discounts than they did. Even now-I could stand correction-I believe Australia is one of the few countries which offers discounts for children and students.

SPEECH.PARA: We operate our airline system in a regulated way. I frankly believe that this is the only way we can provide an adequate service to as many Australians as possible. If we deregulate the industry, we would have the best and cheapest airline system in the world between Brisbane-Coolangatta and Sydney-Melbourne. I represent people other than those who travel on those routes. We have to recognise, whether in the field of communications or transport, that Australia has its problems. It has a small market place to start with for any transport system. We are spread over a pretty large land mass. What makes it harder is the fact that 70 per cent of our population lives within 30 kilometres of the coast. I do not believe that they are the only people who should be serviced. Our two trunk operators last year carried, in round figures, 11 million passengers. O'Hare International Airport in Chicago handled 48 million passengers. That sort of figure gives honourable senators some idea of the difference in the market place.

Recently we all received, courtesy of the Northern Territory Government, a rather expensive publication on the myths of the two-airline policy. I will not go into all the aspects, but will pick up one point concerning the effect of deregulation in California. I find it novel for the Northern Territory Government to use that example. The area of California is 411,014 square kilometres. The population is 22,694,000. The Northern Territory covers 1,346,200 square kilometres, which is about three times as large as California. It has a population of 115,700. Let me compare those figures with my State of Queensland which has an area of 1,727,000 square kilometres and a population of 2 million, which is one-tenth of the population of California. The total area of Australia is 7,682,000 square kilometres and the population is nearing 15 million. It is hardly a fair example to compare us with California. The Northern Territorians have always been worried-and quite rightly so as they live in an isolated area-about the Darwin services. I venture to suggest that there would hardly be a city of the population of Darwin which is around 60,000 which has similar air services. Airlines come to it from all over Australia. Nearly every day Boeing 727 services run from Melbourne via Adelaide and Alice Springs or from Melbourne, via Sydney, Brisbane and Mount Isa. Other services come through Gove, Port Hedland and so on. I think those people are entitled to that service, but let us not start knocking what has provided that market place, small though it be, with a system that is pretty good. My own State of Queensland, which has less population than either Sydney or Melbourne has nine jet airports operating every day of the week. It is hard to finance that sort of operation, yet we do so and still keep air fares at a reasonable rate vis-a-vis the rest of the world.

Currently America is going through the throes of deregulation. My colleague, Senator Thomas, mentioned the fact that we argue about what is happening in America and we use any evidence we like. We can use any evidence we like from America concerning deregulation to justify whatever argument we want. It would be accepted that with deregulation, even though there is such a tremendous market place, the industry is certainly going through some sort of turmoil. When and if it ends most people will have a service of sorts, but many will not have the services they were used to. There will be a lot more commuter operators, and the few trunk operators will be fairly stable. The commuter operators will never be stable while deregulation exists. The unfortunate part is that, as commuter operators come in, go broke and get out, the cost of money becomes more expensive to borrow as it has to be recouped. A certain problem accrues to the passengers who seek to use the services. The disruption in schedules is bad enough, but obviously air fares will ultimately bear the cost of that disruption.

It is necessary for our airlines to be viable. They deal with a lot of very expensive equipment, some of which is only basically paper equipment when they buy it. Quite often deposits are paid before the aircraft manufacturer has even cut metal. It is necessary for them to become viable. If companies go broke after having paid deposits for equipment, the whole industry begins to get into disarray. Then, once again, the fare-paying passengers will ultimately bear the cost. It is also essential for adequate maintenance that the airlines be viable. I repeat, the first two things that suffer when an airline begins to lose money are things that passengers never see, that is, aircraft maintenance and crew training. We must remember that the cause of the DC10 crash in Chicago, when the engine came away from the wing, was put down as nothing more or less than cost cutting on maintenance. That the airline concerned was not the only one involved in such practices was very noticeable. Both governments and communities have a vested interest in ensuring that airlines remain viable without necessarily sheltering them too.

As I have said, the Australian market place is pretty small but Australian costs are also higher. In round figures, without going into too much detail, the direct operating cost per hour of a Boeing 727 in Australia, as against that of the same aircraft in the United States, is about $1,000 higher. There are many reasons, not least of which is that our work force has better conditions than any other country in the world. It has entitlement to long service leave which other countries have never heard about-employees there get perhaps four weeks annual leave after 20 years service. I believe that the Australian worker is entitled to that virtually on the day he begins work. Similarly the Australian worker is in a more favourable position with regard to the payment of penalty rates and other concessions. Another most important aspect is that we have to keep such a large inventory of spares. So there are many reasons why our direct operating costs are higher but that fact must be recognised. Ultimately it must be borne by the fare-paying passengers. When those factors are taken into consideration our air fares do not shape up too badly.

Another subject, one on which I have asked a question in the Senate, is that of curfews. Senator Elstob mentioned it indirectly. Very soon the A-300 Airbus will be in operation in Australia. Shortly after that we will have the Boeing 767. Both aircraft are powered by the same basic engine. There are differences but I need not mention them here. Their noise footprint is basically the same-or a little less than that of the F27. The F27, indeed the Lockheed Electra, can operate for 24 hours a day out of any of our major airports. It is essential that this Government soon take a decision-I would appreciate it if the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) could say whether such a decision has already been taken-on allowing aircraft with a suitable noise footprint to operate 24 hours a day. Airlines can get the most utilisation out of their aircraft only if they can keep them flying. It is significant, and to our airlines' credit, that our utilisation is one of the highest in the world. If we can get rid of the curfew, particularly for aircraft that meet the requirements, it will help to keep our air fares down.

As I have said, we operate in a regulatory environment. I can see that situation continuing for a long time. The only thing to change it would be a massive change in our demographic situation. Unfortunately, that does not appear to be on the horizon. We would need not only a massive increase in population but also a population shift from the seaboard to our inland areas.

One matter of concern to me and my colleagues in Queensland is that of western Queensland air services. I have acknowledged on other occasions, and I acknowledge here, that the people of Western Australia have paid full cost-related internal air fares. Yet every time a Western Australian uses a trunk operator he or she subsidises air travellers in western Queensland. That is an injustice. It must be recognised, and the people of western Queensland must expect to pay a cost-related air fare. There is provision in the legislation for the Government to pay a subsidy, albeit an interim one, if such fares become prohibitive. Once again we must be careful because it would be counter-productive to pay such a subsidy as would attract to the air services people who would normally travel on non-subsidised buses which are operated by private bus operators. That in itself would be a disservice because if the bus service were reduced those who did not have air services would suffer. Obviously, consideration must be given to that aspect.

This Government must take on board the fact that there might be need for an interim air service subsidy in western Queensland, particularly since there will not be available in the immediate future an aircraft to take the place of the F27. We in Queensland must accept that the F27s cannot go on forever and a day; that the older they get, even though they are safe, the more uneconomical they become and the less likely it is that they can be kept on those services. In meetings that my colleagues and I have had with the companies concerned and with the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt), we have fortunately been given guarantees that TAA will not walk away from its responsibilities. I think that ultimately a change will be made, but the services will still exist. It might be by way of an amalgam of an F27 and other commuter aircraft until such time, in 1985 or 1986, as aircraft such as the De Havilland-8 or the Saab Fairchild are available for regular passenger transport services.

We work in a regulatory environment, but we must also provide as much competition as possible in that regulatory environment. That is one of the reasons why I am supporting this package of Bills. The Government has recognised the need to provide a service over as much of Australia as possible but it has also recognised that we cannot be too protective. In this package of Bills we have also recognised the increasing role played by regional operators. My approach to the legislation was along the line that not only would the regional operators have to be given a fair go but also they must be allowed to expand, and indeed give the trunk operators a bit of curry-which they need.

We have also instituted an air fares committee. That is a good idea. I do not think it will give everybody the result expected but at least it is an independent body that can look objectively at the situation. The deregulations committee will give us an idea in a few years time of how the Australian airline situation measures up and whether we should move towards further deregulation, hold the line or whatever.

In conclusion, I say that my main consideration in my support for these Bills is that we should provide a good, viable, safe air service to all Australians, not just to one section of this country or group of people, as may be possible in the constraints within which we operate. For that reason we should look at this legislation not as some great new economical hypothesis dictating that we should do this, that or the other but as providing, within the environment in which we operate, a service that will be as competitive and viable as is possible. I support the package of Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Few measures emphasise more effectively than these Bills the philosophical poverty and actual corruption of the Fraser Government. They are one instalment of the pay-off to Rupert Murdoch for his unflinching prostitution of Press ethics in the interests of the Fraser Government's political survival. As he did in the United States to secure those soft loans, Rupert Murdoch trades off political support for commercial advantage. Tonight we are seeing one of the instalments in that trade-off which was made before the last election. This Government, which claims a non-negotiable philosophical commitment to market forces, small government and consumer sovereignty, legislates to provide a completely captive market for at least eight years for two companies which might as well be called Tweedledum and Tweedledee. That repudiation of the Government's claim to legitimacy was rationalised by the Minister for Transport, Mr Hunt, when presenting the Airlines Agreement Bill second reading speech in the House of Representatives last week on these grounds. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I was concerned to allow a reasonable period of operations under these new arrangements before contemplating further amendments particularly bearing in mind the massive investment of some $800m made by TAA and Ansett to acquire new fuel efficient aircraft to maintain their high standards of service. I believe every minute of the 8-year period of the agreement will be needed.

Where, one might ask, is the daring entrepreneur of Liberal Party fable? Instead we have flaccid and flabby seekers of government patronage and absolute guarantees of freedom from competition. The very magnitude of the investment which the Minister cited as being required to re-equip with modern aircraft, $800m, is of itself an enourmous barrier to entry by new firms. But even that enormous market barrier is not enough for daring entrepreneurs like Rupert Murdoch and Sir Peter Abeles and for a government which complies readily with their wishes.

Happily there are a handful of Liberals in both Houses who actually believe some of that Liberal Party rhetoric that we read so much about at election times. They will not accept this perversion of the Liberal Party's stated principle. Some of them have voted, and presumably some of them will vote, accordingly. For that stand on what are supposed to be the fundamental principles of their own party they have been bullied, threatened and harassed by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and by his toadies, among whom can be numbered the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) who apparently effectively dealt with Senator Thomas today. If I were Senator Thomas I would be more concerned with the next Senate pre-selection in Perth if I wanted to remain in this Parliament than I would with the threats of Senator Durack.

It is appropriate that the Minister, Mr Hunt, should use the high capital cost of entry as a spurious argument for guaranteeing a captive market for the Government's favoured friends. The Minister's behaviour throughout, like that of the Government he represents in this matter, has been an amalgam of devious misrepresentation, blatant misrepresentation and incompetence. On 18 September last year he introduced a Bill into the House of Representatives, although the House was to be prorogued that day, and stated that a draft agreement was in the process of being prepared. No time frame was placed on the duration of that agreement. No hint was given as to the duration of that agreement by the Minister.

The next day, after the Parliament has been prorogued, he issued a Press statement saying that the agreement had been signed. I note for the record that the Fraser Government was obviously much more efficient at conducting its business in those days than it has been in recent months if the agreement was being drafted on one day and was signed and announced the next. On that day, 19 September, the Australian Financial Review alleged that the agreement signed had a duration of 10 years. Mr Hunt refused to comment on the accuracy of that story. He refused either to confirm or to deny that the agreement signed did, in fact, cover a 10 year term. We now know, of course, that it did. Just prior to the election, as a stunt, the Government set up the Holcroft inquiry. With the election safely out of the way, that inquiry was scandalously truncated at the end of January. It was given seven months to do its job. The next week the Government announced that it would conduct an inquiry into deregulation. That inquiry was to have five years to report from the time it was set up and the Prime Minister and others indicated that it probably would not be set up for two or three years. So on the one hand we had seven months for the Holcroft inquiry and on the other we had seven years or more for this farcical inquiry into the deregulation of the air industry.

The Minister for Transport, under attack from some of the Liberal politicians to whom I have already referred and probably under some pressure even from his own party, decided to hit back at his critics at the Country Party council meeting in Canberra held on 7 March. He was particularly under attack from Western Australians. In the Sunday Telegraph of 8 March, which reported the meeting, he is reported as stating:
. . . if there is no two-airline system the parts of Australia that will suffer most will be Darwin and Perth.
It appears that the reason he advanced in support of that allegation was this allegation:
. . . it was not until the two-airline system came into operation that the State--
That is, Western Australia-
Achieved regular scheduled services to the eastern States.
That simply is not true. The two-airline agreement dates from 1952. There have been scheduled services from Perth since the 1940s at least. The Minister continued:
I am sure the people there-
That is the people in Perth and also in Darwin covered by the scope of these remarks-
Would not have access to the more sophisticated wide-body jet services that will be coming on stream in the '80s-

That is, unless the two-airline agreement continued. Why that should have been so he did not explain, except for some spurious allegation that the wide-bodied aircraft would be concentrated on the most populous routes so they could make the most money. How much money they made, of course, would be a function of the fares they charged, which was an independent variable. Leaving that aside, what if the people in Perth and Darwin-particularly the people in Perth-did not have access to wide-bodied aircraft? I am sure that the normal traveller from Western Australia-as distinct from those who have their fares paid by other people-paying his or her own fare is concerned primarily with what it costs. He is far more interested in a lower air fare than in a 727 wide-bodied aircraft. I note this in passing: If Mr Hunt is so concerned about Western Australians having access to wide-bodied aircraft, why has he introduced into the Parliament an agreement which gives Ansett Airlines of Australia power of veto over the use of the wide-bodied Qantas Airways Ltd aircraft by domestic passengers?

After that fraudulent and incompetent attempt to justify his position, the Minister for Transport has introduced legislation deviously designed to prevent any amendment to the agreement appended to this Bill. It is a question of all or nothing, so it is alleged; and 'nothing' means a continuation of the present agreement. The Parliament has been disfranchised by this Government and Rupert Murdoch has been given the power to veto within three months the legislation which the Parliament may or may not pass. All Australians have been disadvantaged by the two-airline agreement. The industry has been stultified. It has featherbedded inefficiency. We have the idiocy of parallel scheduling and compulsory waste of a type that refuses to allow the 1,000 seats a week which are vacant on Qantas aircraft between Perth and the eastern States to be utilised. All of those things will continue under the new agreement proposed by the Government.

Indeed, with the absurd two airlines agreement we have successfully combined the worst features of both worlds-of a capitalist economy and a centrally planned economy. Western Australians have suffered most of all because of the two airline subsidy. Because of the cross subsidies, in particular, which have received a good deal of publicity, the absurdity of governments supporting a system which discriminated against the most naturally disadvantaged, by geography, of the potential customers of the airlines, which is, of course, the reverse-it violates both the laws of the market to which the Government is supposed to be committed and the other generally, socially accepted--
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —It being after 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The absurd system which has prevailed-and which to some extent possibly still prevails-is that the most disadvantaged, by reason of geography, of potential customers subsidised the relatively advantaged customers. This violated both the laws of the market to which this Government is supposed to be committed and the generally, socially accepted policy in Australia that in certain circumstances there is an obligation on the society in general to compensate people for particular disadvantages. For those reasons, Western Australians are particularly conscious of the faults of a two-airline agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: Before moving on to discuss that matter, I point out that Senator Ryan has drawn my attention to the fact that East-West Airlines Ltd has sought permission to operate a commuter service between Canberra and Sydney at a cost of $46 standard economy fare compared with $56, the price currently charged by the two major airlines. That application has been blocked pursuant to the powers and the intent of the two airlines agreement. I wonder what Senator Reid will do in regard to this legislation, on a matter which so directly concerns the people she purports to represent.

Most of the Government members of parliament who have so far voted against this legislation-only the House of Representatives has voted on it so far-not surprisingly have been Western Australians. Three of those who voted against the Government will nevertheless almost certainly be swept out of their seats at the next election-partially because of this legislation-not on any personal grounds but because the only way to get rid of the two airlines agreement is to get rid of the Fraser Government. To get rid of the Fraser Government, it may be necessary to get rid of those three or maybe four Western Australian members of the House of Representatives. They must go. One of the things, ironically, which will help to sweep them out of their seats will be this legislation, if it is passed. I notice that Senator Martin was invited to the Lodge tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is very good.

—Yes, I understand that the prime occupant of the Lodge has not spoken to her for several years. I wonder whether the prospect of a Ministry was dangled before her enticingly if this Bill is passed. If it was, I sincerely hope that she will resist the temptation.
—Senator Walsh, I think you should concentrate on the Bills and not make personal allegations that cannot be substantiated.
—Let Senator Martin deny it. It is my understanding that it happened.
—When she is not here, of course.

—She can come into the chamber. I suggest that the sordid manoeuvrings which we have seen in the last few weeks by assorted senior members of this Government are highly pertinent to the legislation being debated.
—What does that mean?
—What was that? Did he say: 'What does that mean'?
—Just go on with your speech and get it over with.

—I thought he said: 'What does that mean'? I would have thought that it was fairly self-evident. I shall deal with some of the specific disadvantages that this legislation, if passed, will continue to impose on Western Australians. There are, and have been for a very long time, a thousand empty seats a week on scheduled Qantas flights between Perth and the eastern States. Qantas is eager to carry domestic passengers. It would carry them at fares considerably lower than the domestic airlines are able to charge. If those seats were permitted to be filled, six Boeing 727 flights between Perth and the eastern States a week would become redundant. That would save a quarter of a million litres of fuel, among other things, which ought to be attractive to a government which has a stated policy of fuel conservation.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst this agreement does not explictly prohibit those seats being utilised, it gives the power of veto to Ansett. Western Australians can anticipate a continuation of the excellent service they have to the east whereby they have a choice basically of leaving Perth at midday or midnight due to the absurd system of parallel scheduling which also will continue. As a by-product of parallel scheduling it is necessary to spend-this is currently under way-about $40m on Perth Airport to cope with diarnal passenger peaks and the congestion which that induces. If the services were spread over a longer period, the congestion would not arise and the expenditure would not be required, at least for the present, and probably in the foreseeable future.

Finally, I express my disgust at some of the tactics which have been used by people other than members of the Government with an interest in this matter and particularly by those who have been associated with Ansett Airlines. Last week I was visited by a News Ltd journalist who said that he wanted to have a talk about the Western Australian dissident members of parliament. I said that that would be okay. I was informed by the journalist that the story was around that the dissident Western Australians were being influenced by a group of Perth very wealthy businessmen. Although no names were mentioned the implications were that they were probably people such as Mr Holmes a'Court and Lang Hancock. The more important implication was, of course, that these Western Australians had been bought off.

It may well be beyond the comprehension of the two chief executives of Ansett that, having bought off the Fraser Government, they could not buy off every member who was supposed to be associated with it. It may well have been incomprehensible to them that that could have been caused by any reason other than that somebody else had paid a higher price.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walsh, I think you are getting pretty close to being offensive to some members of the Senate.
—On the contrary.
—I think you are suggesting that certain senators could have been bought off. I think that is not a fair allegation.

—The suggestion made to me was that because a limited number of Western Australian politicians were resisting government policy, they had been bought off. On the contrary to reflecting upon them, I said to certainly one of the more important journalists-I do not know them all-that I did not believe the honourable member for Moore (Mr Hyde), whom I have known reasonably well for a number of years, would do that. I was quite certain that he would not be in anything like that. This probably will not be disputed at least in this chamber, but I am not noted for readily handing out accolades to Liberal Party politicians. I do not know precisely who it was who attempted to spread that scurrilous rumour to discredit those members of the Liberal Party who had been standing up to Mr Fraser. Whether it was an executive or a senior executive of Ansett Airlines or someone in the Government, I do not know. But I have no doubt that it was a deliberate attempt to plant a story like that to try to get some confirmation from other people in Parliament so that the story might take off and hopefully discredit those who had taken a stand on what they saw as principle. That tells us a good deal about scruples or lack of them of the people we are dealing with.

SPEECH.PARA: I have heard a lot of rumours about what might happen to the various amendments that are going to be moved. I will watch with particular interest at the way the Western Australian senators vote. Two of them are in the Ministry and of course they will vote with the Government. There are four other Government senators from Western Australia. I will watch with particular interest to see how they vote. I am sure that the electors of Western Australia will also watch with particular interest to see how they vote. I suspect that the members of the Western Australian Liberal Party of Australia preselection council, the next time Senate preselections come up will also watch with some interest. It is perhaps fortunate for Senator Durack, having just scraped through the last Liberal Party preselection council meeting, defeating the crook Crichton-Browne by only one vote, that he will not be facing a preselection council the next time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by acknowledging some of the remarks made by Senator Collard who, I think, set out very well the position about the disadvantage Western Australia has suffered in the recent air fares controversy. I am grateful for his recognition of the fact and for his hopes that that situation will be rectified. I cannot let the occasion pass without saying a couple of things in reply to Senator Walsh. He is always interesting to listen to, but he is much, much better when he is factual. I could not grasp who he was really attacking tonight. Is it that he thinks that attempts have been made to bribe some of the senators on this side, or does he believe that stories have been spread that attempts are being made to bribe us? I could not grasp what he was getting at. I respect Senator Walsh when he is factual but not when he indulges in this hyperbole. He seems to understand pretty well and have much the same opinion as I do of the honourable member for Moore (Mr Hyde) in the other place. I say in all courtesy to Senator Walsh that if he said 'Good day' to a few more of us now and again, he might know a little more about us. I try as hard as I can to make his acquaintance and he does acknowledge that I pass him now and again. If he knew us a bit better he would not be making allegations like that. I know that it is the function of the Opposition to oppose and to oppose strenuously. I respect Senator Walsh and all others on the opposition side for that. But it seems to me that things get a little out of hand. I will leave it at that because that is not really what I am here to speak about. I will leave the Government to deal with whatever allegations are of interest to it and about what Senator Walsh had to say.

SPEECH.PARA: I indicate that I will be supporting the amendment which will be moved by my friend and colleague, Senator MacGibbon. I will support no other amendments because I believe that his amendment comes closer to what is good for this country. I repeat that Senator MacGibbon's amendment comes closer to what is good for this country than anything else I have heard. By coincidence, it also seems to represent the views of Sir Peter Abeles, at least those views which he gave on one occasion to some of us. I know there is argument about the interpretation of those views but I, at any rate, have no doubt in my mind as to what was said on the occasion I am referring to by Sir Peter Abeles, and neither has any of my colleagues who were there at the same time. But this is not to say that what Sir Peter Abeles wants is what the Government is going to do. I know that the Government is going to resist strenuously that allegation. I think it will be able to prove that some of the things that have been said by people on the other side tonight, about multimillionaires running this Government, are quite wrong. I ask honourable senators in all seriousness: Is anyone, multimillionaires or anybody else, standing over this Government? Standing over this Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser)? Standing over Malcolm? Not now, not ever! I think the Opposition understands that as well as I do.

I mention something that was said by my friend and colleague in the other place, Mr Peter Shack, the honourable member for Tangney. It sums up what some of us here are trying to do tonight. He says that he sees it as his responsibility to come into the chamber and vote for things which, he believed, if passed would make good law. I think that is what we are trying to do tonight. It certainly sums up the objective of Senator MacGibbon's amendment. The Government feels, no doubt-and I have no doubt about its sincerity-that what it is doing is in good faith. It thinks that the Bills it has presented are good for the country. Mostly they are. I am the first to concede that enormous progress has been made in certain directions. But, as I said some years ago in another place and on another Bill, all we want is one little amendment which will improve things enormously. That is the amendment that I will support. This amendment clearly sets a limit of eight years on the agreement. That is plenty of time, surely, for the companies to get settled in, to make the agreement work, to make profits and to provide for the future.

Some weeks ago, the Government guaranteed the loans which the airlines will use to re-equip themselves. I believe that this is fair enough and that the open-ended nature of the agreement as stated in the Bill is just too much. Notice of the termination of the agreement must run over three years. That means, if the agreement runs for five years it will be plus whatever, whenever and maybe forever. Then three years notice of termination can be given. This is not satisfactory to a number of us. We have put our case very strongly for quite some time to the Government. We regret that the Government has not accepted what we have put to it. I wish that the Government would go that little bit further, but they are not going to. They have not, and I regret that. I will be supporting Senator MacGibbon's amendment, which makes the Bill acceptable to me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you keep using the plural and not 'he'? Why do you keep saying 'they will not'? It is 'he will not', is it not?

—I think that there is a collective view. As a former member of the Cabinet, Senator Chipp, you should know better than I do that there is a collective will. I think that will is being fairly exercised. I have never been in the Cabinet and I would say that after this evening it is a cert that I never will be; so I will not have the experience that you have had. I have been engaged with people of integrity--
—Have you been told that?

—No. I have been engaged with people of integrity in the House of Representatives, in my own State and with people of every political persuasion. I have been engaged in conversations and discussions with members of my own State Council of the Liberal Party for several years. Senator MacGibbon's amendment is a culmination of all the efforts of those discussions and of that work. I hope that we succeed for the good of Australia. I accept without reservation what Senator Chipp said earlier on these matters, but I have to say that no one has threatened me, no one has cajoled me. The discussions I have had with those who have been involved have been penetrating and diamond hard, but without acrimony. I feel that no one has pressured me. I can only offer this as my own experience and not necessarily as a contradiction of what Senator Chipp said earlier. I understand the position of the Deputy Whip, Senator Thomas. I understand the position of those who cannot see things in the same way as those who will be supporting the proposed amendment. I accept without any rancour their attitudes and what they are going to do. I hope that they feel the same way about what we are trying to do.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the Senate would have to say that I have not invested much wind in this place yet. Indeed, I do not intend to do so. What I say here will be what I believe it is necessary to say and will not be said just for the sake of speaking. When I spoke in the Senate on 29 April, for the sake of time, I incorporate in Hansard a document by the Nobel laureate, Professor Hayek. I wish to read part of that document tonight, because I think it sums up what we are trying to do. It states:

There is some justification at least in the taunt that many of the pretending defenders of 'free enterprise' are in fact defenders of privileges and advocates of government activity in their favor, rather than opponents of all privileges. In principle, the industrial protectionism and government-supported cartels and the agricultural policies of the conservative groups are not different from the proposals for a more far-reaching direction of economic life sponsored by the socialists. It is an illusion when the more conservative interventionists believe that they will be able to confine these government controls to the particular kinds of which they approve. In a democratic society at any rate, once the principle is admitted that the government undertakes responsibility for the status and position of particular groups, it is inevitable that this control will be extended to satisfy the aspirations and prejudices of the great masses. There is no hope of a return to a freer system until the leaders of the movement against state control are prepared first to impose upon themselves that discipline of a competitive market which they ask the masses to accept. The hopelessness of the prospect for the near future indeed is due mainly to the fact that no organized political group anywhere is in favour of a truly free system.

That is an exposition of how I feel about many things which governments, State and Federal, do. I understand the difficulties. I know that we cannot abolish a state of affairs which has grown up over many years. We cannot sweep it away overnight. But I feel that when little steps can be taken, as Senator MacGibbon said earler, they ought to be taken. That is where I stand. That is why I will support the amendment, which I believe is basically good for Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sim Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly to make my position quite clear. With respect to Senator Chipp, I read recently in the West Australian a report of a statement by him to the effect that any Government member who did not oppose the legislation had been subject to coercion by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). I wish to make my position quite clear. I have not been subject to coercion by anyone. I have never spoken to the Prime Minister, nor has he spoken to me, about this legislation. I make my own independent judgments without coercion.
—Not even in the party room?

—I do not go into the party room. I have never been coerced. My judgment on this matter has been independent from the start. When this group in Western Australia first tried to subject us to pressure, I wrote to the group telling the group of my views. I said in simple terms that I would not support the group. That goes back many months. I have never diverted from that course. My view is my own independent judgment. I respect my colleagues from Western Australia who disagree with me. They have made their independent judgment and I respect it. They have never tried to coerce me, nor have I ever tried to coerce them. So the view I express in support of this legislation is in line with my own judgment, no one else's, and without coercion from anyone. I just make that point quite clear for Senator Chipp.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to speak at length. I do not believe that many of the arguments used by those who support deregulation or the variants of deregulation have any validity at all. I support philosophically the idea of a free market force. It must be a pragmatic one. I am very interested in the situation in the United States of America. I accept that one can use all the arguments relating to the United States to whichever advantage one wishes. No stronger view has been expressed in favour of free enterprise than that expressed by the new Reagan Administration. It has expressed very clearly a philosophy in favour of private enterprise. I was very interested to note on an article by Barbara Donnelly of Associated Press-Dow Jones on Friday 22 May, which expressed the views of the Chairman of Alitalia, Umberto Nordio, who had had discussions with the Reagan Administration concerning the unmitigated disaster that deregulation had meant to the United States airlines. He is reported as saying after discussions with leaders in the Reagan Administration that they had expressed quite clearly that that Administration:
. . . intends to change the free-for-all airline deregulation policy that has brought even major US carriers to the brink of collapse.
He said:
Key Reagan contacts clearly grasp the notion that the deregulation policy of the Carter Administration was mistaken. They have shown a clear intention of changing it.
The report went on to state:
Braniff-
That is a great domestic and international airline-
. . . will declare bankruptcy in the near future . . . He also singled out Pan American Airlines . . .

Another great American airline which has been engaged in a takeover of other airlines. For example, the National airline, a big airline, has been taken over by Pan Am because it was at the point of collapse. Mr Nordio said about Pan Am:
. . . a company in very serious difficulties.
Braniff is about to go under. Watch Braniff, watch Pan Am. If Braniff doesn't go bankrupt it will be because it will go the route of Chrysler towards Government subsidy.
Later he said:

The American companies are currently the first to line up at the CAB (Civil Aeronautics Board) to ask for a change in deregulation. And right there with them is the State Department, which knows what Carter's pseudo-idealistic policy did to US international relations.

That deals with international airlines, but these big companies are also domestic carriers. Let us look at the situation in the United States. Great cities, such as Philadelphia, no longer have regular commercial jet services. They are served by small commuter airlines. I commend the comments by Senator Collard both tonight and in his speech on 9 April on the Airlines Equipment (Loan Guarantee) Bill as ones which deserve study. I think he has put the situation clearly.

I conclude by saying that I am opposed to some of the changes which have been made to air fares, but the arguments that Australian air fares, particularly on long haul routes, are the dearest in the world are absolute nonsense. I recommend that the Senate look at the tables which were incorporated in Hansard by Senator Collard, which prove this point. I also commend the comments by Senator Collard concerning the methodology of the Holcroft inquiry, which completely ignores the points he made tonight about the multi-stage routes, which give an entirely different picture of cross-subsidisation.
