I am not against changes and I am not against more competition, but I believe that this legislation will mean, because of the fact that the airlines are to use new and different equipment, greater competition on our routes under some form of control.

Deregulation, as some of my colleagues have recommended, has proved in the United States to be an absolute disaster. The American airlines are suffering a severe financial loss. The fact is-I think as Senator Collard said-that the first two things that suffer are maintenance and crew training. Braniff, one of the companies that I have just mentioned, has already been fined because of its failure to carry out proper maintenance. In other words it is taking short cuts to save money. The Australian airlines-because they have been reasonably profitable but not overprofitable-have had a magnificent safety record. I think it is correct to say that the airlines conduct their maintenance tests over and above the regulations laid down by the Department of Transport. The first area that suffers when airlines start to lose money is safety. I make this point clear.

I support the legislation because I believe it is in the interests of Australia. Despite the weaknesses and problems, and considering the points that have been made by Senator Collard that we have a small market compared with other countries and long lines of communication, I believe that we have an airline system in Australia equal to any in the world. Those of us who have flown on domestic airlines in other countries would find it very difficult to find a service generally comparable to that which we enjoy in Australia. Therefore, for these reasons, I support completely the arguments used by Senator Collard. I declare myself free from coercion and I support this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: -The issues involved in these pieces of legislation have been canvassed at length in the House of Representatives and are now being canvassed in the Senate. We are dealing, as I see it, with only one amendment to the second reading motion and that is an amendment moved by Senator Chipp which relates to the establishment of a Senate select committee to complete the inquiry undertaken by the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares. All of the other matters to which honourable senators have addressed themselves have related really to the clauses of the Bill and to the proposed amendments to be moved in the committee stage by Senator MacGibbon, Senator Gietzelt and Senator Elstob. I presume that the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) is not anxious at this stage to call a point of order on me if I advert to those matters.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all I must be the only member of this chamber who has not been spoken to by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), Sir Peter Abeles, Rupert Murdoch, Trans-Australia Airlines, East-West Airlines, or anybody else. I am not complaining about that; that is how I like it as a matter of fact. However, I have examined the matters that have come before us in the correspondence that has been received and I have studied it quite carefully. In particular I have looked at the East-West material that has come forward and also the answers that only as recently as yesterday have been given by the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) to those particular propositions and considerations. So it is now a matter for the Parliament to decide. I will oppose the amendment to be moved by Senator MacGibbon in the Committee stages because I believe that that proposal is an abdication of the responsibilities of both the Government and the Parliament. It establishes a situation where the operations of the agreement simply lapse after a period. In my view there is a need for a positive proposal to be advanced and for that to be submitted in sufficient time to get a reflection of the people's view on this matter before this airline agreement lapses.

As I understand it there is not a great deal of argument about the details in the 1981 agreement. It has been pointed out in the Minister's second reading speech that the Airlines Agreement Bill 1981 is better than the current agreement which, of course, can only be terminated after five years notice. The proposed legislation does do what in fact I feel ought to be done. That is, it requires the Government to make a firm commitment to the two-airline policy. I will quote from the Minister's second reading speech. He stated:

. . . before its re-election to office last year, the earliest one could expect that notice of termination of the current agreement could be served is after the next election, due in 1983. Such notice would have to specify a termination date of at least five years from then, say the beginning of 1989, or eight years from now. I have earlier made a commitment in respect of the termination of this agreement five years hence should certain circumstances occur. In deciding upon such arrangements I was concerned to allow a reasonable period of operations under these new arrangements before contemplating further amendments particularly bearing in mind the massive investment of some $800m made by TAA and Ansett to acquire new fuel efficient aircraft to maintain their high standards of service.

All these matters have been thoroughly investigated. To my way of thinking to have an amendment to the Bill which simply allows a government of the day, by not taking any decision whatsoever, to allow the important issue of airline services throughout Australia to lapse, purely by the effluxion of time, would be an irresponsible act. The government of the day must be forced to advance a positive proposal and, of course, once having advanced that positive proposal to give notice of the termination of the airlines agreement and the period of that notice would go over the subsequent election. In other words the people of Australia would then have the opportunity, as is their right, to determine whether the positive proposal by the government of the day is valid.

The other aspect to which I will advert relates to the question of deregulation. If Senator MacGibbon's proposal were put forward, if the inquiry came down with a proposal for deregulation and if the Government did not make any decision but just simply went along with the lapsing of the arrangements then, of course, there would be a situation of deregulation. In my view there is no joy in that for my State. I concede that Western Australia has a particular point of view which ought to have been considered, but if I were the Government I would deregulate Western Australia, give it to Qantas Airways Ltd and the international airlines and balance it up by giving the domestic airlines New Zealand. I think everything would be all right under those circumstances. I therefore indicate that I will not support that particular proposition in the Committee stage.

With regard to the amendment moved by Senator Chipp, there is already so far as my State is concerned, a Senate Select Committee on Passenger Fares and Services to and from Tasmania. I hope that that Committee will direct its attention to the question of air fares between my State and the mainland. I look forward to its report and until such time as it comes down, I will not be influenced to vote for the proposition advanced by Senator Chipp as an amendment to the second reading of the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has been debating this evening a very important series of measures, the first of which is a Bill to give the approval of Parliament to a new airlines agreement. It is quite clear from the length of the debate we have had in the Senate and from the debate in another place that in this Parliament there as been a very great interest in and concern about the propositions that are contained in this new airlines agreeement and the associated legislation. The Government has attached very great importance and significance to the negotiations for this new airlines agreement which it felt was necessary to secure as long ago as about 1978 after the Government itself had undertaken a review of domestic aviation policy. Since then the Government has believed that the existing agreement was deficient in many respects and needed to be brought up to date. It has taken the consistent view that it supported the principles of the two-airline policy but that it believed the existing policy needed to be reviewed and renegotiated. Those negotiations with the other parties to the agreement have been going on from as long ago as the middle of 1978.

SPEECH.PARA: The general tenor of this debate seems to indicate that the Senate accepts that the agreement that has been renegotiated and which is before us for approval tonight is a significant improvement on the existing agreement. There are a number of aspects which clearly are improvements. The Government particularly was concerned to free up the existing agreement to make it more competitive, and I think it is clear that those policies have been achieved. The Government also has been concerned for some time about the general level of services provided by our aviation policy under the two-airline agreement and in other respects. As I think Senator MacGibbon pointed out earlier in this debate, great technical changes have been taking place in the airline industry and the Government therefore felt that appropriate changes were needed to our aviation policy.

The Government is pleased that the major operators in this area have been prepared to embark upon significant changes in their own equipment policies and attitudes. It is also pleasing that they have been prepared to renegotiate the agreement. We must bear in mind at the very threshold of this debate that the existing agreement provides that the company-Ansett Airlines of Australia-and Trans-Australia Airlines-the other party to it-have very significant rights and that agreement cannot be determined without notice of five years being given to those parties by the Government. So there are very significant existing rights. For the Government to be able to achieve the purposes of the policies I have mentioned and to implement them, it has been necessary to persuade the companies to give up the rights they have under the existing agreement and to enter into the new agreement which we have before us for approval this evening. That is in fact what the other parties to the agreement-the company and the Australian National Airlines Commission-have been prepared to do.

In addition to these broad policies I have mentioned, the company and the Commission have been prepared to make changes in relation to their equipment. These very large purchases of new, modern equipment, I think everybody will agree, will make revolutionary changes in the nature and quality of the major airline services throughout Australia, particularly on the trunk routes operated by the major operators. Of course, other major changes are occurring in other aspects of aviation affairs in this country. They also need appropriate changes of policy, and they also are recognised in the new agreement and in aspects of this legislation. So, all in all, we are now about to embark upon a very great era of change in policies as required and in what services are to be provided for the Australian people under those policies.

The Government was able to complete negotiations for a new agreement in September last year but since then it has reconsidered the agreement and has been able to renegotiate with the other parties. It has now come forward with what I think everyone agrees is a better result than that achieved in September last year. The Government has also taken a number of other very significant steps. First of all, it set up the Holcroft Independent Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares. That inquiry made a major investigation into the fare setting formula. The Government accepted the recommendations of that inquiry and also took a major step towards implementing them in April this year. The report of that committee has also made a major contribution to changes in policy and to the air fares that Australians are paying, bringing about a fairer system.

The Government has, in the development of this present agreement and in the development of the legislation currently before the Senate, also indicated some other major changes. One of the major changes has been the decision to establish a public company and to transfer the assets and operations of TAA to that public company and for the other major operator in future therefore to be on an entirely commercial basis. That should have major significance in the achievement of the Government's desire for greater competition, even within the two-airline policy. In addition to that step, the Government said that it will inquire into the feasibility of the disposal of some or all of the shares which initially will be held 100 per cent by the Government, with perhaps the achievement of a further competitive environment with that company becoming an entirely private operation.

Further, the Government has said that it will establish another committee of inquiry to undertake an assessment of the advantages and disadvantages of deregulating the domestic aviation industry. This is the most important step of all. By this step it has raised the question and the possibility of the replacement of the two-airline policy, which has operated now for nearly 30 years in this country, with an entirely new aviation policy. That committee will observe these new major changes which undoubtedly will occur because of the factors I have mentioned and because of the new agreement and the new legislation that we have before us this evening. That inquiry will assess the situation in regard to the agreement over the next five years. It will be asked to report to the Government within that five-year period in order to enable the Government, the Parliament and the public to assess the results of these major changes which, I have said, have been occurring and which will occur over the period. It will enable full consideration by the Parliament as well as by the Government of what has occurred and of the report of that inquiry. At the end of the five-year period that we are now looking at we will be in a position to have a major debate and a major rethink of these aviation policies which we have been pursuing in one form or another now for such a long period.
The Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt), in his second reading speech, which I on his behalf have given here, went even further and said:

As soon as the inquiry has reported, the Government will ensure there is a full parliamentary debate on its report. Should the inquiry make recommendations supporting deregulation for the domestic aviation industry, and the Government accept those recommendations, the Government would then move immediately at the end of the five-year period of this agreement to give the three years' notice to terminate the two airlines agreement in accordance with its provisions for termination.

That would give full effect to the decisions that may well be taken at the end of that five-year period, and then, in an orderly, efficient and sensible way, to implement any such decisions that may be taken. In other words, the Government wants to be in that position at the end of five years. We have had a good deal of debate about the question of termination of the agreement. Amendments to have a fixed determination of it at the end of eight years have been foreshadowed. That is the five year guaranteed period before anything can be done, on the assumption that there presumably would be an immediate giving of three years' notice and that the agreement would then come to an end firmly at the end of that eight-year period.

Of course, the agreement does not provide for that in so many terms. The agreement provides that at the end of five years it can be determined only by three years' notice by any party to it, which, of course, includes the Government. This is a vitally important aspect. No doubt there will be some more discussion in the Committee stages. The Goverment would adopt the arguments that Senator Harradine so very clearly stated here. We have indicated that if, at the end of the five-year period, the recommendation is that the agreement be brought to an end, if the Government and the Parliament accepts it, the Government will be in a position to bring that agreement to an orderly conclusion, and nobody will be disadvantaged or will suffer from it.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can you say that? There will be a different government by that time. You will not be governing.

—We can make undertakings only on an assumption as to the positon we would be in. I am giving them on that assumption. That is what the Government has said in regard to the undertaking that we have given here.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that, after the Government's very long period of negotiations with this company and the Commission which have entered into this new agreement the agreement, achieved after those very hard fought negotiations, be the final agreement that has been entered into. We have it before us tonight and it provides for this form of termination to be adhered to. The Government proposes to honour the agreement it has entered into. Senator Chipp has proposed an amendment which is different from the one I mentioned. His amendment reads:

A end of motion, add, ', but the Senate is of the opinion that a Select Committee of the Senate should be established to complete the inquiry undertaken by the Holcroft Committee into domestic air fares'.

I wish to deal briefly with that matter before I conclude my remarks. The Government is opposed to that amendment. It is our view that it is entirely unnecessary. The Government has in this legislation for the period of the new agreement, whatever it may turn out to be, provided for a new independent air fares committee which will conduct an inquiry at various levels into the fare setting formula. The Minister said that within six months it will ensure it conducts the sort of inquiry that was undertaken by the Holcroft committee, but the Government does not intend to wait for that to be done. The Government has said already that it will appoint consultants to complete the Holcroft calculations in relation to domestic fare setting formula.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you let Holcroft do it?

—Holcroft reported when it finished its inquiry. There were some further calculations and inquiry to be done. The Government said that it proposed to do that. I am pleased to be able to inform the Senate that, having approached a number of independent consultants to complete this work by Holcroft, the Government has today selected Price Waterhouse and Co. for this purpose. The work of the consultants will be tabled and made available to the Independent Air Fares Committee to assist in undertaking its calculations in the future. The point is that the Government has now selected the consultants to complete this work. It is very technical work and quite inappropriate for a committee of the Senate which would not be suited to deal with it. It will be done by consultants of a high calibre. In future, this sort of inquiry will be done at various levels and on a broad basis of methodology every two years or three years. The inquiry will carry out major and minor reviews of fares and will also look at discount fares. The questions that were addressed by Holcroft will be thoroughly investigated at regular intervals by the Independent Air Fares Committee which is part of this package of legislation before the Senate. I hope that it also will be supported. For those reasons, I trust that the Senate will give this important Bill a second reading and will reject the motion that Senator Chipp has moved for an inquiry by a select committee of the Senate. I trust that we will be able, in due course this evening, to pass this important measure.

That the words proposed to be added (Senator Chipp's amendment) be added.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had more than a fair hearing at the second reading stage and do not propose to go over the ground that I covered in the speech that I made then. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 3, after clause 8, insert the following new clause:
Cessation of Operation of Act
9. (1) This Act, unless sooner repealed, shall cease to be in force at the expiration of 8 years after the day on which the agreement referred to in section 5 comes into force and effect.

(2) For the purposes of section 8 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, when this Act ceases to be in force by virtue of sub-section (1), it shall thereupon be deemed to have been repealed by an Act other than this Act.

I do not wish to debate some of the points that have been raised and propose to comment on two issues only. The first concerns the point raised by Senator Harradine. From listening to him it was clear that he believed that if the proposed amendment were passed a vacuum would exist. I can assure the honourable senator that a vacuum would exist only if the Government took no action and I find that inconceivable. The second point of which I have been made aware of is that there has been a misinterpretation of what I have said regarding the intent of this amendment. I understand that Cabinet believes that the Act would be amended in a way that is, in fact, not contemplated. There is abroad an impression that somehow or other a review period would be brought in at the end of eight years; that, without any warning or setting up time, a new airlines Bill would have to be introduced. Of course that is not true. Of course the three year warning would apply, so that the need for this review period would have to be exercised after some 4 1/2 or 5 years of the term of the agreement had elapsed. In no way would the terms of, or the essential interest provided in the Bill, be altered in any way.

The Bill is a reasoned and planned move to improve the airlines of Australia. We live in a time of change. The changes proposed are more extensive than are proposed in any other such legislation that has come before this Parliament. We will have new equipment. We will have new technology. The two major airlines will have different equipment and that in itself will produce different scheduling agreements. There will be a new fare basing system. As I indicated in my speech at the second reading stage, there is in my mind some uncertainty about certain clauses of the legislation and as to how they should be interpreted. I suggest that we should not be locked in irrevocably, without a review facility. Above all, who can foresee what the economic climate and conditions will be in Australia in the future? To all these things must be added the possibility that the investigation into the selling of Trans-Australia Airlines will recommend that it be sold. One cannot foresee what the recommendations from the deregulation inquiry will be. It is common sense to have some review position in this Bill.

The amendment will not change the spirit, the intent or the legality of the present Bills. It will provide nothing more than an opportunity for the Parliament to look at the circumstances that relate to the operations of the airlines at the time. As far as I know, there is no objection at all from the operators. As I said earlier, I am not aware that the Government will have any objection to this recommendation when it has time to think about it quietly. I believe it is necessary in the interests of the Australian community that this review period be provided. I believe it is in the interests of the Australian Government. I believe it is in the interests of TAA and Ansett Airlines of Australia. I commend the amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with everything that Senator MacGibbon has just said, except for one point-that he is sure if this amendment is passed, the Government will accept it and see the wisdom of it. It has come to my notice today from about five different sources that the message has come out with crystal clarity from the office of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) that if, in a few moments, this Senate passes this amendment, the Minister in charge of the Bill will immediately move that progress be reported, we will assemble in the Senate and the Bill will be withdrawn, never to be presented again. That would mean that we would have to rely on the old agreement. If honourable senators have any self-respect as members of the House of review and if they believe in what they have been saying in speeches-that this chamber should not be subject to Executive or Prime Ministerial direction-let them know as they vote tonight that they will not be voting from a detached point of view.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat what Senator MacGibbon said. I say this because of what Senator Harradine said in his speech at the second reading stage. What does this amendment mean? It means that there will be a sunset clause in the agreement. No government in its right mind, whether it be Labor, Liberal or coalition, would allow the agreement to go for eight years before giving proper notice to the airlines that it intended either to terminate the agreement after 8 years or to have an open skies policy. Notwithstanding the undertaking given by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) in his speech tonight, that the Government would make an announcement in five years, if the report on deregulation said, as I expect it to say, that an open skies policy was not suitable for Australia and the Government then proposed no further action, this agreement, if this amendment is not carried, would just carry on and on. It could well carry on for 20 or 30 years, plus three years, the three years being the time in which notice has to be given under the terms of the agreement. I do not believe any private company should have that sort of licence virtually to print money on a cost-plus basis. That is what a duopoly means under this agreement. I believe some check should be placed on that. The sunset clause contained in Senator MacGibbon's amendment gives that protection to the Parliament and to Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Withers Sen The Rt Hon R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be supporting the amendment moved by Senator MacGibbon. I was further encouraged to do so by the reply of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) in winding up the second reading debate tonight. The Attorney admitted on behalf of the Goverment that the existing agreement, which will be repealed by this Bill, has become unworkable and out of date. I put to the Senate that it had become unworkable and out of date because there had been no pressure point on any of the parties to get together to have a new agreement. This agreement has gone on and on because it is an open-ended agreement subject to five years notice. No government, neither on our side of politics nor the Whitlam Government in its three years, was prepared to give the five years notice of termination. Senator MacGibbon's amendment gives that notice now. A lot has been said about how the airlines would be affected. I have come to the conclusion that the airlines are entitled to eight years. I come to that conclusion because they were informed that during the life of this Parliament the present Goverment would not give the five years notice. They have been saddled with the proposition that there will be no notice in the life of this Parliament and then, if notice were given in the next Parliament, they would have five years to put their house in order. I believe that undertaking ought to be honoured by the Parliament. That is what the agreement does. It gives them five years for certain and then at any time after that date three years notice may be given. All that Senator MacGibbon's amendment does is to convert that minimum of eight years-the five plus three-to a maximum of eight years.

SPEECH.PARA: The airlines are not disadvantaged by having their minimum converted to a maximum. They have eight years in which to recover their costs, to have their investment amortised and to put their house in general financial order. I do not believe any government, as Senator Chipp said, would allow the whole agreement just to collapse in chaos at the end of eight years. That is not in the realms of practical politics. Of course, even if the amendment is lost, such a scenario is possible. Who knows which government will be in power in five years time?

TALK.START.PARA: —We do.

—Oh well, we have always been eternal optimists! But one does not know. None of us knows. None of us might be here at that time. In five years time, the government of the day may give five years notice, converting the eight years minimum to the eight years maximum. If a government were stupid enough, it could then sit back, do nothing and have chaos at the end of eight years. I know that Senator Harradine said that there may well be an election in between. But there may not be an election in between. As I understand it, there seems to be a movement about the place to have four year parliaments. If we go down the track of four year parliaments, with fixed terms, it may well be that within those three years a government would have the capacity to give notice in its first year with only three-quarters of its term to go before the three years ran out. Therefore, I say that most of the arguments that have been put, with respect to those who put them, do not hold up.

SPEECH.PARA: I say again: This amendment converts the eight years minimum to the eight years maximum. The airlines will not be disadvantaged but I believe the community will be advantaged, because there will be that pressure point upon the two airlines and the Government to make certain the agreement does not run on and on so that it becomes like the present agreement-out of date and unworkable. There is an admission on all sides that new technology is coming. There is an admission on all sides that the different equipment will revolutionise the airline industry in this country. Yet for some reason which totally escapes me the Government wants an open-ended agreement. I would have thought that on the Government's own argument, namely, that the present agreement has become unworkable and out of date, and on the Government's own admission that new technology will revolutionise the airline business in Australia, the Government itself would welcome this sunset clause. Therefore, I will be voting in support of the amendment moved by Senator MacGibbon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition noted that Senator MacGibbon moved precisely the same amendment as was moved in another place about this time last evening and that it there attracted support from a considerable number of Government members to the extent that the amendment was lost by only three votes. As indicated by my colleague, Mr Morris, who is the spokesman for the Australian Labor Party on these matters, we regard this as being only a second-best proposition. We do not quite share the enthusiasm that Senator MacGibbon has for the amendment. Nevertheless, we believe that this is a House of review and that the Senate should take into consideration the debate that took place in the second reading debate. Further, we believe that the Government's position is untenable. Without necessarily agreeing with all of the views of the free marketeers that have been expressed so ably in the debate both here and in the other place, I say that we have some doubts about the legality of the proposal, although we have been assured by Senator MacGibbon that they are not necessarily valid and that they can be cast aside. Therefore, we take the view that the Opposition will share the views of those members of the Government parties who have the courage of their convictions. Accordingly, we will be supporting the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Friday, 5 June 1981

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is important to start by saying what will achieve a desired result. It is my understanding that there is general agreement that the desired result is to ensure that the matter does not go on indefinitely in the way to which reference has been made by my colleagues, Senator Withers and Senator MacGibbon. We want to know whether, after all of the steps which have been provided for in the package of legislation are taken and the Executive acts in the manner to which reference has been made, that matter will come back to the Parliament? Will the Parliament be able to debate it? Will the Parliament be able to act to ensure that one way or another the people of Australia will be able to know what is proposed in relation to the future of the domestic airline industry in Australia? What will ensure that that review will, in fact, take place? What will ensure that adequate notice is given to those who are involved in operating the airlines to enable them to have a lead time sufficient to adjust to whatever decisions are taken by the Parliament?

SPEECH.PARA: What it boils down to is a desire to ensure that after there has been the deregulation inquiry, after there has been the restructuring of Trans-Australia Airlines from a statutory authority to the structure of a public company, after there has been the further inquiry and consideration of the provisions of the Holcroft recommendations by, as we understand from the remarks of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) tonight, Price Waterhouse and Co.; and after there has been a chance to see how the Independent Air Fares Committee works, the matter will come back to the Parliament with an expression of view by the government of the day and with an assured opportunity for each of the Houses of parliament to express their views and to play some part in the matter.

I have believed throughout the considerable period of some 2 1/2 years during which these matters have been discussed that if we want to achieve the results which apparently the Opposition, the Australian Democrats and every person who has spoken in this chamber would like to achieve, the first, most important and essential step is to restructure TAA from being what in effect is part of the Public Service and subject to the limitations of the fact that it does not have a financial gearing ratio which would enable it to operate commercially or a freedom from the Public Service-there are all sorts of problems such as running up a bill of $140m for superannuation during a period when the airline made about $20m profit-so that all these problems can be overcome. I think that once TAA is put onto a commercial basis-irrespective of who owns the shares-and once that structure has been ratified, we can look to a number of changes taking place automatically, as result of the impact of human nature and its competitive aspect.

Therefore, I believe that the single most important step that can be taken to achieve the results which have been talked about by various senators in this chamber today is the restructuring of TAA. Considerable and understandable concern has been expressed by our colleagues from Western Australia, in both the House of Representatives and this chamber. I do not want to dwell on the history of that. I say simply that I believed that there was a way which would serve the purpose of the Western Australians who wanted to limit the period of five years. I believed that there was a way that would serve the purpose of the Government which has undertaken to give the airlines and the various other interests reasonable notice, that is, five years plus three years notice. An amendment could have been introduced which would have the effect of ensuring that after about 4 1/2 years and before five years action would have to be taken.

In the period in which I have been a member of this Parliament, I have never known more confusion to be created by what I would have thought was a relatively simlpe proposal. It has been called a sunset clause. It has been referred to by Sir Peter Abeles in the telex which was incorporated by Senator Chipp earlier in the debate. In a telex addressed to the Minister for Transport, Sir Peter Abeles said:
On your enquiry I would like to confirm to you once more that a sunset clause is not acceptable to Ansett and has never been acceptable.
The words I wish to emphasise follow:
This could enable a government of the day to let an agreement run to the last day and the uncertainty of the future could not be accepted by this company . . .

The telex continued. That is a total and absolute misunderstanding of what this amendment, moved by Senator MacGibbon, seeks to achieve. If it is passed, it will ensure that before the five years are completed the matter is discussed by the Parliament and that then either the Act is amended to extend the provision or, alternatively, three year's notice is given by the government of the day which, under the airlines agreement is required before it can be given the approval of both Houses of parliament. That is a matter to which I do not think anybody has adverted yet but which is rather important in a consideration of all of this matter. With all the confusion that followed because of the use of the words 'sunset clause' and the impression that was given that people wanted to drop the shutter at the end of eight years without notice, I think it is important to say what I believe, from what I have understood from the speeches I have heard, many people wish to achieve. They want some way by which the matter will be reviewed before five years so that we know what will happen, so that Parliament has a say in what will happen and so that the companies have time to know and to plan in accordance with the decision that is taken.
This morning, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) answered a question in the House of Representatives and used some words to which I will refer. He said:
The report of the deregulation inquiry will plainly need to be published and debated. The Goverment will plainly need to state its views in relation to it. It will do so.
He also said:
. . . the Government will be publishing that report. We will be making a statement about it-
To the Parliament. He also said:
These are all firm commitments of the Government.

I have been told that in news services there has been some suggestion that in a discussion I had with the Prime Minister today the Prime Minister threatened me and tried to heavy me. I can only say that the relationships between the Prime Minister and me remain as they have been over quite a long period of time. Having read the answer that was given this morning, having endeavoured to clarify what the Government means and having endeavoured to clarify what was sought by the amendment, I believe that a form of words which I suggested be given as a formal, a clear, undertaking by the Government will serve the purpose of ensuring that, subject to this Government remaining in power at that time, and I have every trust and confidence that that will be so--

TALK.START.PARA: —You did not sound too confident.

—That prospect is one which is as remote as the Opposition's support for what I am just going to say. If there is a change of government, that will be a matter, as it would be anyway, for the government of the day, because any government can propose to the Parliament an amendment to the legislation once the day has passed on which this Parliament has approved the two-airline agreement. From the moment the two-airline agreement is passed by this Parliament nothing alters the contractual obligations. It cannot be altered by statute without incurring certain responsibilities at law. So, from the time that the principal Bill with which we are concerned is approved, there is an agreement in relation to which there is a five-year minimum and in relation to which there is a requirement for three years' notice to be given after both houses of Parliament have supported the giving of three years' notice. If the Opposition wishes to change the legislation and it happens to become the government, it will have the opportunity to do so. I have been informed that the present Government will give the following undertaking: The Government will make a statement of its views and proposed action in relation to the report of the deregulation inquiry. That statement will be made to the Parliament before 30 June 1986-in other words, five years from now-and there will be an opportunity for the Parliament to debate the matter at that time. In other words, the objective which was sought--
—Who gave you the undertaking?

—The undertaking will be given in this chamber by the responsible Minister. That is my understanding. If it is not, I will be surprised. I have every reason to believe that that undertaking will be given. That undertaking achieves what was sought, which was to ensure that before five years is up the results of the deregulation inquiry, the results of the further Holcroft consideration by Price Waterhouse & Co and the results of the Independent Air Fares Committee's work, will be able to be brought before the Parliament with a statement as to what is proposed and debated by both Houses of Parliament and the appropriate action being taken by Parliament. I am prepared to accept that clear, specific and firm undertaking as a sufficient basis to ensure that the prospects which were sought will be achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I refer to the fact that the honourable member for Tangney, Mr Shack, who moved a similiar amendment in the House of Representatives, apparently also had the same objective because in speaking last night he said that if the amendment was accepted:

The Government of the day will then be in a position to give notice after five years and consideration of the findings of the deregulation inquiry. If the Government chose to go down the deregulatory path there would be a three-year transitionary period, after which time the agreement in toto would expire at the end of eight years.

That position will be achieved if the Government and, I would add, the Parliament of the day four and a half years to five years hence but before 30 June 1986 so decides, and for that reason I believe that the undertaking, if given, will ensure the objective which most people sought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the difficulties for honourable senators in determining which way they will vote in relation to this legislation and this amendment has been the great deal of confusion which has surrounded the issue of the two-airline agreement for some months. It is unfortunately in the context of some of that confusion and some of the controversy that tonight's debate and tonight's vote are seen.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —That makes it difficult-I am not assisted by honourable senators opposite-to state rationally one's position. As a senator from Queensland, I would have preferred a different two-airline agreement. I would have preferred a situation which would give more encouragement to such vigorous charter--

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a suggestion tonight from Opposition senators that they will support an amendment to be moved by Senator MacGibbon, for reasons very poorly stated by Senator Gietzelt. The attitude expressed informally by Opposition senators gives no confidence to someone like me as to the bona fides of certain people in this chamber as they vote on this amendment. That is a factor in my decision and I make no apology for it. Queensland has a vigorous charter airline, Bush Pilots Airways Ltd, which has done much to extend the benefits of air travel to Queenslanders. I am not happy about the position that an airline such as that is placed in by the two-airline agreement. Nevertheless, tonight we are facing one of the realities of life and that is that the two-airline agreement expires on 30 June. With all my reservations about the proposed two-airline agreement, I would rather see that one than see the continuation of the present one. That is one of the grounds on which one must make a decision.
—Pressure.
—There is no pressure, none at all.
—Confession hour.

—It is not a confession hour. Votes have been speculated on and I have the right, as has every honourable senator, to explain my vote, whichever way it goes, on the reading of a Bill or an amendment. I wish to state my position. Others have stated theirs at great length and if I am given the opportunity, I shall state mine briefly. The great difficulty is that in one vote one has to indicate a choice between a range of options. I have indicated that I do not like the proposal. However, if it does not go through, we will continue with the present proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not speak at length on the statements made by Senator Rae on the subject of the misunderstood so-called sunset clause, except to say that he has essentially stated what I think had to be known. It is unfortunate that Sir Peter Abeles of Ansett Airlines of Australia has also so muddied the water and made it difficult for people to establish their attitudes when he appears to have set certain parameters. There appears to be a 'Parliament can like it or lump it' attitude. I do not say that that is what he has meant, but that is the atmosphere which has been cast in Press reports. I have not discussed the matter with him, either singularly or in any committee, but I have read Press reports and heard other versions of things that have been said. I do not think he has conducted himself wisely for whatever purpose he wanted to achieve. I have to conclude, on the basis of words he has stated, that he does not understand what a sunset clause is. That is not helpful.

Nevertheless, we are faced with a decision and it is not a 'to be or not to be' decision. I shall vote against the amendment, not because I think there could not be some useful things achieved by it. But I am not prepared to let an open-ended situation go on whereby the present airlines agreement obtains. I think the proposed one is preferable. I accept the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in Parliament this morning as to the Government's intention in relation to the deregulation investigation. I accept that this is a statement of the Government's decision. I accept that the Government is genuine in setting up that inquiry and that by a combination of that inquiry and inserting the five year clause with a three year option, we can move towards a situation which is acceptable.

One of the great difficulties of having to debate an airlines agreement, much less negotiate it, which is an enormous difficulty, is the fact that our airlines industry is in a state of considerable change. I am sure that it is the fervent hope of all of us that an inquiry into deregulation- a proper, considered inquiry-will pick up the main trends of change and will give us some guidance on what is necessary in the development of this industry in Australia.
Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, it is tempting to become short-tempered with people who clearly have no understanding of the subject.
—You are just a girl who can't say no.

—It is tempting to be scornful of those who can speak only in terms of cliches and slogans. This has not been an easy question to resolve. I will not have two bob each way. I will be voting against the amendment, not because for one minute I reject the purpose to which, Senator MacGibbon, Senator Withers and others would attempt to address themselves but, as I have said, because I accept in good faith statements that have been made in the Parliament. I hope the Parliament will accept in good faith what I have stated as the basis for my reasons for voting against the amendment. This is not to be taken as a full endorsement of this Bill or of the new two-airline agreement, but as a decision of what is best for the airline industry in Australia today.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, I will not speak for long because I have no confessions or apology to make about my attitude on the matter. I do not think people realise the seriousness of the speech we have just heard. Here we have an honourable senator who was elected to this chamber--
—Don't misrepresent me.

—The honourable senator is the one under charge. The honourable senator was elected to this chamber to carry out what she thinks is right and proper for the people, but when it comes to a vote she finds that she does not have a free hand because of what has taken place previously. It has been suggested that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) influenced her. She says that it was Sir Peter Abeles. We all agree that the present legislation is wrong and should be altered. The Government's attitude is that it has no alternative but to carry this legislation because it does not want to continue with the old agreement. We have reached a stage now where neither the Prime Minister nor people outside the Parliament accept that the Senate has the power to amend. The purpose of the legislation is not to alter the agreement, but to amend it. We are losing all our power. The honourable senator is prepared to be a party to this situation because she does not have the freedom to vote as a result of the circumstances surrounding the matter.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MARTIN
TALKER.TIME.STAMP: (12.24 a.m.-I wish to clarify one point. I believe there was an inference in Senator Cavanagh's speech about the role of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser)

TALK.START.PARA: in relation to decisions. I sought to discuss the matter with the Prime Minister this evening to clarify the Government's intention. That was all. At no stage has anyone sought on behalf of the Government to influence my opinion on this matter. I sought to have some matters clarified. I hope that nobody will read anything other than that into Senator Cavanagh's words.

—If there was anything objectionable in my remarks I retract them. I thought that there had been some influence. I retract my remarks, because the fact that the honourable senator sought an interview with the Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, arouses a greater suspicion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is opposed to this amendment. I dealt with it at length in my reply to the second reading debate. I gave the reasons why the Government would oppose it. The amendment had been foreshadowed at that stage and I felt it important to set out my reasons at some length. I mentioned, of course, that the Government had been in negotiation with the company and the Commission for some time to achieve a new agreement. I said that great strides had been made in those negotiations and in the renegotiated agreement that the Government has brought before this chamber this evening for ratification and approval. The Bill provides in clause 5:

SPEECH.PARA: The agreement between the Commonwealth, the Commission and Ansett being the agreement a copy of which is set out in the Schedule, is approved.

That is what we have sought from this chamber this evening. The Government, and I think the Committee, believes that the new agreement is a vast improvement on the existing agreement. It has been achieved after long and hard bargaining and negotiations. The agreement provides for a method of termimation. This is set out in the agreement itself. It states that there is a guaranteed term of five years, and that after that time expires notice may be given by any of the parties to terminate the agreement but if the Government gives such notice, as Senator Rae has said, it has to obtain the approval of both Houses of Parliament and it has to give three years' notice. That is the nature of the agreement that we have entered into. The Government proposes to honour the agreement it has entered into as a result of these negotiations. It believes in honouring its agreements and it also believes that the agreement will achieve great benefits for the nation.

I mention also the big changes that have occurred to the Government's aviation policies. The Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) in another place and I in this Senate on his behalf have made extensive reference to the Government's policies and in particular to the inquiry into the advantages and disadvantages of deregulation of the aviation industry. There has been a striking change of policy because of the long commitments that have been made by the two-airline policy by successive Liberal-National Country Party governments. The Minister and I have pointed out that we propose that the inquiry should take place over the next five years but that before that five years is completed the Committee should report and that the Government and the Parliament should be in a position to evaluate that report and to decide the direction in which the industry is to go. The Government, the Parliament and the airlines would need flexibility in making what would then be some very major new decisions.

I believe that Senator Rae is quite right in his analysis of the amendments that have been suggested, namely, that there has been much misunderstanding about the nature of the sunset agreement. Certainly, there is a lot of misunderstanding on the part of honourable senators opposite not only about this matter but also about most other things-certainly about anything which has any legal characteristic. Undoubtedly, there are some legal difficulties in relation to the Parliament on the one hand approving this agreement and then including a clause of this sort in the same Bill.

I am not arguing this question on legal grounds. I am arguing it on the grounds that the Minister who I represent has pointed out very forcibly in two debates in this Parliament-that it is the nature of the agreement, the nature of the negotiation and the fact that we have entered into an agreement which we intend to stick by. We also intend to stick by the undertaking that we give in this Parliament and elsewhere for a proper inquiry into deregulation to report before those five years are up so that all these major questions can be resolved within that period. It is a very sound assumption that we will be the government over this period of five years. It is the policy of this Government to make a statement of our views known in relation to this matter and the proposed action in relation to the report of the deregulation inquiry. That statement will be made to the Parliament before 30 June 1986 and there will be an opportunity for Parliament to debate the matter at that time. Those are very firm and solemn undertakings that we are giving as a government. Of course, they will be very firmly adhered to. For those reasons and in these circumstances I sincerely hope that the Committee will not adopt this amendment because I think its purposes are certainly achieveable without the amendment passing and on the basis of the undertaking that I have given.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Withers Sen The Rt Hon R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak again because of the speech of Senator Rae and the reply just given by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack). I wish to deal particularly with the undertaking given by the Attorney. What the amendment proposed by Senator MacGibbon does is to ensure that before the end of eight years new legislation must come back into this chamber. It is as simple as that. At the end of eight years the legislation falls to the ground. It might be argued as to whether that would be upheld in the courts but the intention of Senator MacGibbon's amendment is that before the end of eight years a new Bill must come back into this Senate, either to extend the present Bill or to have a new Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney-General has just given an undertaking. I accept it as being given in good faith and that the Government will adhere to it. But what does it tell us? The only new information in it is that a statement will be made before 30 June 1986. That is the only new thing that we have learnt. On any report which the Government commissions, it makes a statement of its views and of its proposed action in relation to the report. What is new about this? There will be an opportunity for Parliament to debate the matter at that time. With respect to the Attorney and my very good friend, Senator Rae, that is what happens day after day in this Parliament. There is a specific time for reports to be brought down. Often ministerial statements are attached which give the Government's view that they will take some action, refer the matter to an interdepartmental committee or have another inquiry. A debate takes place. In effect, what is lost is the legislative power of this chamber. That is what Senator MacGibbon's amendment is all about. It is reserving the legislative right of this chamber in eight years' time. This undertaking given by the Government does not do that. There is no undertaking that the Government will introduce a Bill. There is no undertaking at all about the legislative process. There is an undertaking about the parliamentary debating process. It is no different from any other report which the Government commissions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether a long list of committees would agree with that.

—It ought not to be. The only statement we have is that it will happen before 30 June 1986. Therefore, much as I am sympathetic to the appeal of my friend, Senator Rae, and whilst I accept the undertaking given by the Attorney-General, I just say 'what is new?'. There is nothing new, nothing novel about it. I repeat that the Senate will still lose its right to legislative scrutiny at the end of eight years. For those reasons I am not prepared to accept this as a substitution for the amendment moved by Senator MacGibbon. I will still vote for the amendment moved by him.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the proposed new clause (Senator MacGibbon's amendment) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Durack) proposed:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to say very briefly that I believe the interests of the people who are involved in short haul air travel and who are disadvantaged by the huge increase in the amount of the flag fall-and that particularly applies to northern Tasmania and Canberra residents as well as to those who would wish to be tourists visiting either area, each of which has a major tourist industry-would be well served if the Government would consider seriously, as I trust it will, the application which has been made by East-West Airlines in relation to the operation of a service between Canberra and Sydney at a rate which will not be related to sharing through flag fall charges the cost of the operation of a total national airline system with all the attendant overheads which have caused, under the current Holcroft formula, that figure to go so high. I hope that consideration will be given to permitting some regional operators to provide short haul regional operations in relation to the Canberra-Sydney route and perhaps the Melbourne-northern Tasmania route so that until the deregulation inquiry has been completed and until the survey of the recommendations of the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares has been completed and all the other things which this chanber has debated are taken into account, people will not be massively disadvantaged as they are at the moment. I therefore ask the Government to show some good faith in relation to the intentions which have been expressed, at least for a trial period or a limited period, by approving the application which has been made by East-West Airlines for provision for a special Sydney-Canberra operation in competition with the two major domestic airlines.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES (TAX SHARING AND HEALTH GRANTS) BILL 1981LOCAL GOVERNMENT (PERSONAL INCOME TAX SHARING) AMENDMENT BILL 1981

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speeches in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?

—Mr Deputy President, before I grant leave I remind the Minister for Finance that this morning I made a request that the Senate rise at a reasonable hour. The Attorney-General, who was then in charge of the chamber, said that he hoped that some suitable arrangements could be made whereby the Senate would rise at a reasonble hour. Apparently no suitable arrangements have been made. It is now nearly 10 to one in the morning and it looks as though we are going to be here half the night.
— No, we are not. We are just introducing the Bills.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator McLaren

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Senate is to rise as soon as these Bills are introduced, I will grant leave.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
STATES (TAX SHARING AND HEALTH GRANTS) BILL 1981
The States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Bill 1981 has two main purposes:
(A) To give effect to new arrangements for the payment to the States of tax sharing grants during the period 1981-82 to 1984-85; and
(B) To give effect to new arrangements for the payment of health grants to the States and to the Northern Territory in the same period.

The new arrangements for the payment of tax sharing and health grants reflect the outcome of major reviews which the Government has undertaken of the existing arrangements for assistance to the States for general revenue and health purposes.

The existing tax sharing arrangements, which are authorised in the States (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1976, provided for a review to be undertaken prior to 30 June 1981 and the hospital cost sharing agreements with four States and the Northern Territory expire at 30 June 1981. These latter arrangements, together with certain other assistance for health purposes, have been revised so that, with the exception of payments to South Australia and Tasmania under their continuing hospital cost sharing agreements, the health grants will now have the character of general purpose payments. As such, they are appropriately included in the present Bill and, from 1983-84, they will increase each year in the same proportion as the tax sharing grants.

The new tax sharing arrangements have been determined by the Government after careful consideration of the views put forward by the States in a submission received last February and after consultation with the States and the Northern Territory at a Premiers Conference held on 4 May. The new health grants arrangements reflect the Government's consideration of the Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals, discussions with State Health Ministers and the outcome of the Review of Commonwealth Functions. This Bill, in short, reflects detailed consideration of the wide range of views that have been expressed on these matters. It also reflects, as I shall explain, the continued attention by the Government to the pursuit of policies which are both economically necessary and consistent with the States accepting greater responsibility for the operation and financing of State services.
New Tax Sharing Arrangements

A major feature of the new tax sharing arrangements is the switch from using personal income tax to total tax as the base for purposes of calculating the tax sharing grants to both the States and the Northern Territory. A sharing of total Commonwealth tax collections provides a more equitable basis for determining the provision of general revenue assistance as it will mean that the tax sharing grants will grow at the same rate as total Commonwealth tax revenues. It will avoid possible problems in the future if there were to be changes in the mix of Commonwealth taxation. As total tax collections tend to fluctuate somewhat less than personal income tax collections, it should also help to reduce uncertainty in the year-to-year levels of grants to the States and the Northern Territory.

Under the Bill, total tax collections by the Commonwealth are defined by reference to those taxes set out in Schedule 1. These taxes cover over 99 per cent of total tax revenue as defined in the Budget Papers and, apart from certain minor taxes, fees and fines, the items excluded for purposes of the new arrangements cover only those taxes and charges that are effectively set aside for specific Commonwealth purposes or for the Australian Capital Territory. These exclusions are both appropriate and will simplify administration. I emphasise that the rate of growth of total tax collections as defined, which will determine the rate of growth of the tax sharing grants, will not differ to any noticeable extent from the rate of growth of total tax shown in the Budget Papers, except in circumstances where the Commonwealth imposes a special tax surcharge or rebate. In that event, as is the case under the existing personal income tax sharing arrangements, the gain or loss to Commonwealth revenue will not be counted for purposes of determining the grants.

The tax sharing grants will not be determined by reference to total taxation until 1982-83 as the move to a total tax base will involve a transitional year in 1981-82 in which the basic percentage of total tax collections to be provided to the States will be established. That percentage, which is expected to be about 20 per cent, will be derived by taking the States' tax sharing grants in 1981-82 as a percentage of total tax collections, as defined in 1980-81.
Tax Sharing Grants in 1981-82

For 1981-82, the total tax sharing grants for the States and the Northern Territory will be calculated by increasing the 1980-81 tax sharing grant for the States and the Northern Territory combined by 9 per cent. An amount of $78.1m will then be added to take account of the transfer of certain Commonwealth functions to the States and the Northern Territory and of the population component in the formula for determining the Northern Territory's grant. The total amount payable to the States and the Northern Territory under this arrangement will thus be $6,929m, or 10.2 per cent more than in the current financial year.

The distribution of this amount between the States and the Northern Territory in 1981-82 cannot be finally determined until final population figures as at December 1981 are available. That portion of the amount derived by increasing the current year's grant by 9 per cent will include special allocations to three States totalling $27m, which were decided upon at the Premiers Conference of 4 May and are set out in column 2 of Schedule 2. The distribution of the remainder of that portion will be on the same weighted population basis as for this year's grants.

I should emphasise that, if any changes in relativities were to be effected as a consequence of consideration of the forthcoming report of the Commonwealth Grants Commission, further amending legislation would be required. As honourable senators will be aware, it is generally accepted that the general revenue grants should be distributed between the States so as to enable each State to provide government services of a standard broadly comparable with those of each other State without imposing higher rates of taxation or other charges. However, there are considerable practical and conceptual difficulties in determining the appropriate relativities. Accordingly, the Government will carefully examine the Commission's report and consult with the States before reaching a decision as to any changes in the distribution of general revenue grants and as to the arrangements which should apply after the current financial year as regards the right of states to receive special grants.

On present estimates, the total amount of the 1981-82 tax sharing grant payable to the Northern Territory is $315.1m. In accordance with the Commonwealth's intention that the population element in the formula in the memorandum of understanding with the Northern Territory should be fully observed, an additional sum of $5m is included over and above the Territory's share of that portion of the total tax sharing grant derived by increasing this year's grant by 9 per cent. The amount of $315.1m also includes a sum of $4.0m in respect of the transfer of Commonwealth functions to the Territory. With the concurrence of honourable senators, I incorporate in Hansard the following table which contains the latest estimates of the tax sharing grants payable to each State and the Northern Territory in 1981-82.
