(a) The amounts payable to each State and the Northern Territory are subject to revision in the light of final population figures for December 1981 and are subject to change in the light of any decision to alter relativities following the review of relativities by the Commonwealth Grants Commission.
Tax Sharing Grants for 1982-83 and in Subsequent Years to 1984-85

Following the transitional year in 1981-82, the total tax sharing grant for the States for any particular year will be determined by applying the basic percentage of total tax to collections of total tax in the previous year. The Northern Territory's grant will be determined by reference to the formula in the memorandum of understanding, but with the substitution of total tax for personal income tax. Provision for the Northern Territory's tax sharing grants for these years will be made in the annual Appropriation Bill and the Territory will continue to be eligible for special grants payable on the recommendation of the Commonwealth Grants Commission.

A number of features of existing tax sharing arrangements will continue under the new arrangements. I refer, in particular, to, firstly, the retention of the right of the States and the Northern Territory to impose surcharges or give rebates of personal income tax under stage 2 of the fgederalism arrangements; secondly, the retention of the Commonwealth's right to be able to declare an increase in, or rebate of, any Commonwealth tax to be a 'Special surcharge or rebate', and hence excluded from the total tax sharing base; thirdly, the continuation of arrangements for consultation between the Commonwealth and the States and the Northern Territory on changes in Commonwealth taxation which affect the tax base; and, finally, the guarantee that the States and Northern Territory grant in any year will be not less, in money terms, than in the previous year.
Tax Sharing for Local Government

The Government has also decided on the continuation of the existing generous arrangements whereby local government is entitled to 2 per cent of net personal income tax collections. I note that tax sharing grants to local government have been increased from 1.52 per cent of net personal income tax collections in 1976 to 1.75 per cent in November 1979 and to 2.0 per cent in May 1980. The associated Bill to amend the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1976, which I will introduce shortly, is a machinery provision to enable that Act to remain in force after the States (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1976 has been repealed. The amendment Bill includes various definitions-presently included in the States (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1976-on which the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1976 relies.

Before turning to the new health grants arrangements I should like to refer to one or two aspects of proposals made by the States to the Commonwealth in regard to the tax sharing arrangements. In particular it needs to be recognised that the States made it quite clear in their February submission that they regarded the existing arrangements, as reflected in the States (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1976, as unsatisfactory and requiring amendment. The main proposed change sought was for an assured minimum growth in general revenue payments. In effect, the States sought a share of the tax pool or a guarantee, whichever was the larger.

Acceptance of this proposal would have committed the Commonwealth to a minimum growth in general revenue grants of one per cent to 2 per cent faster than gross domestic products-that is, possibly 5 per cent to 6 per cent per annum in real terms. This would have been inconsistent not only with the need to restrain public sector expenditure but with the need to limit the Commonwealth's own expenditure commitments.
Health Grants

I turn now to the new health grants arrangements. As I have indicated, these are included in the present Bill because of the Governmens's decision to change the basic character of Commonwealth assistance for health from assistance specifically directed to that purpose to payments which are for general purposes but which are identifiable as health grants. The Government sees this change as a move towards ending divided control over the provision of health care services in the States and the Northern Territory and thus eliminating potential costs and inefficiencies that can be involved in such duplication. The arrangements contained in the Bill are an interim step towards full absorption of health grants into the tax sharing grants.

In determining the form of the health grants arrangements, the Government has been guided by two fundamental principles: Firstly, the States should assume their full constitutional responsibility for the provision of health services and should be free to determine their own priorities as to the allocation of funds for those services; and secondly, those people in the community who can afford to pay for the cost of health services they receive should do so either by way of personal payment or through health insurance; but those who cannot afford it should continue to have access to free basic health treatment. This Bill is only concerned with the Commonwealth's direct grants to the States for health purposes. It must, of course, be considered in the context of the overall revision to health care arrangements which were outlined in statements in the House by the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) and by me in this chamber on 29 April 1981.

For purposes of the Bill, the States and the Northern Territory are divided into two main groups, according to whether their hospital cost sharing agreements expire on 30 June 1981 or 30 June 1985. In the case of South Australia and Tasmania, whose hospital cost sharing agreements expire on 30 June 1985, the required funds will be provided under the authority of this Bill unless these States decide to terminate their agreements and join the new arrangements. Provision is made to meet this eventuality. Assistance to these two States in lieu of payments for community health and school dental programs is provided in the form of special health grants which, in 1981-82 and 1982-83, will be approximately equal to the real level of the total of such payments in 1980-81. After 1982-83, these special heath grants to South Australia and Tasmania will escalate in proportion to the appropriate previous year's increase in total taxation collections, as defined. In the case of New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland, Western Australia and the Northern Territory, there will be one grant in place of separate assistance previously provided in respect of public hospitals, community health and school dental services.

The amount of this overall grant for 1981-82 will be determined by increasing the equivalent of 1980-81 assistance by 10 per cent and deducting from that sum 60 per cent of the Commonwealth's assessment of the capacity of each State and the Northern Territory to raise additional revenue if the States concerned were to impose charges of $80 a day for shared ward accommodation and $110 a day for private ward accommodation, $15 an outpatient occasion of service and an average cost a bed-day for compensation patients. The assessment of additional revenue raising capacities, for 1981-82, which will be determined by the Treasurer on the advice of the Minister for Health, will be made on the assumption that the specified charges should not apply before 1 September 1981 and that there would be one month's lag in the collection of revenue. Towards the end of the financial year 1981-82, there will be a reassessment to take account of any relevant revenue raising experience. In addition to these grants, there will be a further $16m provided to Queensland, for 1981-82 only, to cushion the adjustment that State would otherwise experience.

In 1982-83, the total health grants for these four States and the Northern Territory will be approximately the same real level as in 1980-81, less 100 per cent of the additional revenue, compared with 1980-81, which the Commonwealth consideres could be raised if the specified charges were in place. The distribution of the total derived in this manner would then be determined in the light of advice from the Commonweath Grants Commission. The terms of reference of the Grants Commission inquiry will be announced shortly. After 1982-83, the total annual health grant for these governments will increase in proportion to the increase in total tax collections in the appropriate previous year. That is, it will increase in the same way as the tax sharing grants. The Bill also provides for further possible variations to inter-state relativities after 1982-83 in the light of consideration of the report of the Grants Commission. A condition attached to health grants for those governments is that eligible pensioners and disadvantaged persons and their dependants, as assessed by the Department of Social Security, are to have free access to shared ward accommodation and services rendered in public hospitals.

In conclusion, I emphasise that, in deciding on these new tax sharing and health arrangements, the Government has had very much in mind the urgent need to restrain the growth of public sector expenditure so as to make room for productive growth in the private sector without giving rise to inflationary pressures that could only damage the economic prospects for Australia. The Commonwealth has a recognised responsibility for economic management and the Government firmly believes that these new arrangements are in the longer term interests of the nation as a whole and of individual States. It is acknowledged that these arrangements are less generous than their predecessors. This needs to be viewed in the light of a number of factors. I mention, in particular, the generous nature of the arrangements which have applied since 1976-77, resulting in large increases in the real level of general revenue payments each year since then; the apparent rapid improvement in levels of services provided by the States in recent years, as indicated by the average increase of about 3 per cent per annum in real per capita terms in State recurrent expenditure on goods and services between 1975-76 and 1980-81; and the fact that the States have been able to reduce the burden of their taxes in recent years.

Beyond this, it needs to be kept in mind that the relative size of the public sector has not been reduced to any extent since the large increase that occurred in the mid 1970s. The Government believes that there is scope to place greater reliance on the private sector and, in present and prospective economic circumstances, a pressing need to free resources to allow an expansion in the private sector. This view has been fundamental to economic decisions taken by the Government in recent times and will remain at the core or its economic strategy. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
LOCAL GOVERNMENT (PERSONAL INCOME TAX SHARING) AMENDMENT BILL 1981

This Bill is complementary to the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Bill 1981 I have just introduced. Relevant details of the Bill were outlined in the second reading speech to that Bill. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Gietzelt adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), in his statement to the Parliament on 30 April, observed that the Review of Commonwealth Functions has been the most significant and far reaching ministerial review of its kind ever undertaken by a Federal government. The Prime Minister announced some 350 decisions aimed at transferring to the private sector and the States functions more appropriately performed by them and rationalising functions which properly belong to the Commonwealth. The overall objective of the Review is to establish conditions under which there can be increased opportunities for all and better care for those in need. As the Prime Minister said in his statement, the immediate aim of the review was to streamline and fine down Commonwealth operations. He further said:
Big government concentrates power, loses perspective on its own limitations, and leaves less room for people to make their own choices.

The elimination of unnecessary costs of government is an essential ingredient of a sound and growing economy. And a sound and growing economy is important to all Australians and their families. The implementation of the Government's decisions arising from the Review commenced on the day of the Prime Minister's statement. Some decisions can be implemented almost overnight. Others cannot be achieved as quickly but initiating action has been taken. Positive demonstrations of the Government's determination to withdraw from inappropriate activities and streamline Commonwealth operations are already in evidence.

The Government is committed to following through the decisions announced by the Prime Minister with all expedition; decisions which are in the best interests of all Australians. In reaching its conclusions, it weighed all considerations, in particular the longer term gains to the Australian community. The Government will not be swayed from the speedy implementation of the decisions. The measures contained in this Bill are part of the implementation process. The large majority of the decisions announced by the Prime Minister are being implemented by executive direction as they do not require legislation. Several amendments will become effective from the date when royal assent is given. However, some provisions will not become effective until necessary obligations are discharged or arrangements completed.

Further legislation may be required after more detailed reviews of some functions have been completed. Negotiations with the States are required to implement some decisions. In particular, later legislation may be needed to encompass decisions on such matters as student loans, the Curriculum Development Centre, the transfer to the South Australian Government of Australian National Railways staff and deregulation of the Australian National Railways and the Australian National Line.

I shall now outline the individual provisions in the Bill which give effect to decisions on each of the three major areas examined by the Review-the private sector, the States and the Commonwealth sector.
Transfer to Private Sector

The Bill includes provisions which enable the transfer or sale to the private sector of several activities currently undertaken by the Commonwealth. The Government's view is that activities of a commercial kind are generally best performed by the private sector, where they are open to the disciplines of competition. Not all such transfers require legislation.

The Minister for the Capital Territory is empowered in Part II, Division 3 of the Bill to direct the Canberra Commercial Development Authority to enter into an agreement for the sale of the Belconnen Mall. Upon completion of the sale the Canberra Commercial Development Authority Ordinance 1974 will be repealed. Similarly, the Minister for the Capital Territory is empowered in Part II, Division 4 of the Bill to direct the Canberra Retail Market Trust to enter into an agreement for sale of the Canberra Retail Markets after which the Canberra Retail Markets Ordinance 1971 will be repealed. In accordance with the decision that the Australian Post Courier Service be abolished, Part III of the Bill removes from the Postal Services Act 1975 all references to that Service.

Part IV of the Bill deals with amendments to the Wool Industry Act 1972 to give effect to the Government's decision that the Australian Wool Testing Authority and some wool stores operated by the Australian Wool Corporation be sold. The continued issuing of test certifications and ready trade acceptance of such certification is essential to the sale of the Australian wool clip. This has influenced the legislative provisions made for the sale of the Authority.

Clause 115 of the Bill will allow for the formation of a body corporate owned by the Australian Wool Corporation to assume the present functions of the Authority, and to facilitate its sale as a going concern to a final owner. Provision is made for the Corporation to hold an interest in the body which is the final owner to such an extent and on such terms and conditions as the Minister approves. If necessary, the Corporation may act as a guarantor for the purchaser. Certificates issued by the authority prior to its sale will retain their validity. Any certificate issued by a new testing body in which the Corporation has an interest will be a legal certificate in the same way as those presently issued. The proposed amendment to Section 76 of the principal Act will empower the Minister to direct the Corporation to dispose of land or buildings which comprise wool stores under Part VII of the Wool Industry Act where, in his opinion, these are surplus to minimum wool storage capacity.

Part V of the Bill will amend the Bankruptcy Act to ensure that as much as practicable of the bankruptcy trustee work that is currently being performed by the Commonwealth will be handled by the private sector. The amendments seek to create a framework in which creditors and debtors will make greater use of the facilities in the private sector for handling these matters:

Firstly, estates with divisible assets of over $10,000 will be administered by a registered private trustee unless the Court exercising jurisdiction in bankruptcy or the Registrar in Bankruptcy is satisfied that there is no registered trustee willing to administer the estate.
Secondly, some changes are being made to ensure that the trustee is not subject to any restrictions which might impede the performance of his trustee function in a proper and businesslike manner.

Thirdly, most of the statutory responsibilities currently exercised by the Official Receivers will either be considerably reduced or else transferred to the trustee of the estate (whether public or private).

Part XIII of this Bill provides for the Minister for Housing and Construction to enter an agreement for the sale of the business of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation. The Corporation was established in 1965 to insure lenders against losses on housing loans. It has been successful in serving as a catalyst for the development of a mortgage insurance industry in Australia, with the result that three private mortgage insurers now operate in competition with HLIC. The Government has concluded that mortgage insurance can now be provided efficiently by the private sector without direct Government involvement.

In selling the Corporation the Government expects to see the continuation of a competitive mortgage insurance industry with the business of HLIC taken over as a going concern. Accordingly the Corporation will continue to operate on its present basis up to the time of sale. Any purchaser of the Corporation's business will be required to have the necessary strong financial backing. Sale will be subject to the understanding that the purchaser maintains the level of services now provided by the Corporation. The sale will not prejudice the interests of policy holders or those persons whose housing loans have been insured by the Corporation. The Commonwealth will stand behind the liabilities of the Corporation on insurance policies written up to the time of sale.
The Government acknowledges the contribution of the management and staff to the Corporation's success. It will ensure that they are treated fairly and equitably.
Deregulation

The Government's determination to remove unnecessary and ineffective regulation of industry is reflected in several components of the Bill. Part II of the Bill gives effect to the government's decision to deregulate a number of activities currently being carried on in the Australian Capital Territory. The repeal of the Architects Ordinance 1959, the Surveyors Ordinance 1967 and the Agents Ordinance 1968 will enable the professional organisations in each sphere to regulate their own affairs. The Bill will repeal the Prices Regulation Ordinance 1949 and empower the Milk Authority to determine the maximum prices for milk in the Australian Capital Territory.

By amending the Landlord and Tenant Ordinance 1949 the Bill will abolish the office of Rent Controller and the Fair Rents Board thereby removing fair rent control in the Australian Capital Territory. All other functions of the Rent Controller which do not relate to rent control will now be exercised by the Minister or his delegate. By repealing Part III of the Co-operative Societies Ordinance 1939 the Bill will give effect to the Government's decision to deregulate co-operative trading societies. Control of trading hours for the sale of goods will be abolished by the repeal of the Trading Hours Ordinance 1962. Other minor amendments to various Ordinances consistent with the Government's decisions are also included in the Bill.

Acquisitions of shelf and shell companies are, at present, notifiable under Section 26 of the Foreign Takeovers Act. The Government has decided to exempt from notification acquisitions of shell and shelf companies. The proposed amendments in Part XII of the Bill will reduce and simplify the notification requirements for foreign investors and further improve the efficiency of the foreign investment screening process.

Part XVIII of the Bill repeals all Price Justification legislation, following the Government's decision to abolish the Prices Justification Tribunal. Provision is made in this part for the preparation and tabling of the final report of the operations of the Prices Justification Tribunal and for the transfer to the proposed Petroleum Products Pricing Authority of those PJT records that relate to the production or supply of petroleum products or to associated services. A separate Bill to establish a Commissioner for Petroleum Products Pricing is being introduced.

Part XX which amends the Remuneration Tribunals Act 1973, provides that a person simultaneously holding two full time offices may at most receive only one salary and one annual allowance. This provision is included in the light of Part XIV of the Bill which would permit the holder of the full time office of Commissioner for Petroleum Products Pricing to be appointed also as the full time member of the Temporary Assistance Authority, should that be necessary.

The other purpose of Part XIV of the Bill is to amend sub-section 23(1) of the Industries Assistance Commission Act to allow the Minister to refer to the Commission matters relating to assistance to industries generally without referring to a specific industry or group of industries. This amendment is proposed as a consequence of the Government's decision to request the Commission to investigate the scope for modifying or improving the Customs by-law system.
Industry Assistance

The Review's approach to reducing costs on the community included identifying areas with less need for specific government initiatives to promote particular business activities. Parts X and XI of the Bill provide for the Export Expansion Grants scheme to be extended for an additional year with the grant rates being halved for the additional year and for the Export Market Development Grants scheme to be extended for an additional year. The export incentives schemes are being referred to the Industries Assistance Commission for inquiry and report by 31 December 1981. The extension of the export incentives schemes will give time for the Government, following the report of the IAC, to consider the future of the schemes and for industry to be able to take the Government's decisions into account in their export planning. Bills have been introduced earlier this sittings relating to export inspection charges for fish and dried fruit. Inspection charges will be extended in the next two years to a range of other primary products. Legislation to give effect to the reduced taxation concessions announced by the Prime Minister in his 30 April statement is being introduced.
Transfer to the States

The Review of Commonwealth Functions identified major programs appropriate for early transfer to the States. Such transfers are part of this Government's consistent policy of allowing the States greater freedom in deciding how they will spend their available finances. The transfer will eliminate unnecessary overlap, waste and interference in the delivery of services and programs. Part XXI of the Bill provides for the amendment of the States Grants (Urban Public Transport) Act 1978 so as to give effect to the Government's decision to terminate specific purpose assistance to the States for urban transport as from 30 June 1981. The Government takes the view that urban public transport is an area which is properly the responsibility of the States, and that henceforth it should be for State governments to determine the total amount of funds to be allocated for their urban public transport programs.

Honourable senators may be aware that, at the Premiers Conference on 4 May 1981, the Commonwealth announced that the States' overall entitlements for 1981-82 under the tax sharing arrangements would include a special adjustment of $50m to offset the termination of specific purpose grants for urban public transport. The Bill also gives effect to the Government's decision to terminate assistance to the States for transport planning and research after the current year. Again, the Government views this as an area in which the States must bear the prime responsibility. The majority of the projects which had been funded under the program related predominantly to State and Local Government concerns. The Commonwealth will, however, continue to provide funding for the Australian Road Research Board-ARRB-and the Australian Railway Research and Development Organisation-ARRDO. Separate legislation is being introduced to give effect to the new tax sharing provisions with the States, and hospitals and related health services funding.
Rationalisation of Commonwealth Activities

Other parts of the Bill deal with a range of decisions to rationalise Commonwealth Government activities. I remind honourable senators that the Government made its decisions in this area with several clear objectives in mind: Firstly, to make sure government activity does not inhibit private sector expansion; secondly, to reduce unnecessary demands on the taxpayer by cutting back on bureaucracy; and thirdly, to achieve the greatest efficiency and effectiveness possible. Part VI of the Bill is to give effect to the Government's decision to remove the options, currently available under the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971, of making compensation appeals against determinations of the Commissioner for Employers Compensation to State and Territory courts and commissions. It also transfers the present jurisdiction of the Commonwealth Employees Compensation Tribunal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. All matters not heard or part-heard by the Compensation Tribunal at the time Part VI is proclaimed will be transferred to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal subject to appropriate transitional provisions provided in the Bill. Matters before the State and Territory courts and commissions at that time will continue to finality but no new applications for judicial review may be made after the date of commencement.

The Bill provides for aspects of Compensation Tribunal procedures that may be more advantageous to an employee appellant than present aspects of procedures before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to apply to compensation appeals before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Thus, for instance, the time for lodging of appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in such matters will be 60 days not 28 days. The Attorney-General (Senator Durack) has received from the Administrative Review Council a report concerning rights of appeal under the 1971 Act and related matters. The amending Bill is consistent with each of the Council's recommendations in relation to the Commonwealth Employees Compensation Tribunal. Part VII of the Bill provides for the amendment of the Audit Act 1901 to provide that all payments of remuneration or allowances to Commonwealth employees shall not be made in cash unless the Minister for Finance otherwise determines. However, it is expected that a few exemptions will be granted and that they will apply mainly to industrial type payrolls.

Part VIII of the Bill retains the Commonwealth Teaching Service but provides for the abolition of the office of Commonwealth Teaching Service Commissioner. It provides for the transfer of the functions currently performed by the Commissioner to the Department of Education, the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority and the Public Service Board. A significant factor in the decision to abolish the office of Commissioner was the reduction in his responsibility which will occur with the imminent transfer of Commonwealth Teaching Service members employed in the Northern Territory to a Northern Territory Teaching Service. The Department and the Schools Authority will be responsible for functions associated with the on-going operation of the Australian Capital Territory further education and schools systems respectively including appointments, promotions, deployment of staff and discipline. The Board will be responsible for terms and conditions of service, including the conduct of arbitral proceedings and for authorising the creation and abolition of teacher positions by the relevant authorities.

Part IX repeals section 5 of the National Health Act thereby removing the requirement for the Director-General of Health to be a medical practitioner. This amendment would give effect to an earlier recommendation made by the Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration. The proposed amendments to the Lands Acquisition Act 1955 in Part XV gives effect to the Government decision that the overseas property activities of statutory authorities be transferred to the Department of Administrative Services. The Act will apply to all overseas property acquisitions by agreement-including acquisitions by statutory authorities-in the same way as it applies to acquisitions by agreement in Australia. This will achieve a consistency of approach in the Government's property dealings and will avoid any wasteful competitive biddings between Commonwealth instrumentalities on overseas property markets. A side benefit of the amendments will be that overseas property transactions will be included in the schedules of property acquisitions provided to the Parliament.

Part XVI of the Bill will repeal the Legislative Drafting Institute Act of 1974, by which the Legislative Drafting Institute was created. The Institute was established for the purpose of training legislative draftsmen, mainly for the benefit of this Parliament but also to assist other countries, especially developing countries, in the training of draftsmen. Five annual training courses have been conducted by the Institute, each of about 10 to 12 persons, and a course currently in progress will terminate in November of this year. Most of the trainees have come from other countries. It is intended that, in future, training and assistance of this kind will be given in the form of on the job training, in either the Office of Parliamentary Counsel or the Legislative Drafting Division of the Attorney-General's Department.

Under the Navigation Act 1912 the engagement and discharge of merchant seamen comes under the supervision of mercantile marine office superintendents. It has been decided that the present degree of supervision, which is a carry-over from earlier days when such supervision was needed in the interests of the seamen, is no longer necessary. Part XVII of the Bill therefore amends the Navigation Act to provide for the reduction of such supervision. This is being achieved mainly by amendments that will allow seamen to be left behind from their ships for legitimate reasons, such as proceeding on leave, without going through formal discharge procedures and to rejoin their ships without going through formal re-engagement procedures.

Part XIX amends the Preference to Australian Goods (Commonwealth Authorities) Act 1980. Its purpose is to give effect to the Government's decision that the purchasing function of the Department of Administrative Services is to be extended to encompass purchases over the Finance Regulation 52 limit of $10,000 for statutory authorities and departments. The legislation will provide a basis for a major rationalisation of Commonwealth procurement operations.

The Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) will introduce a separate Bill to provide for the amalgamation of the Australian Capital Territory Totalizator Agency Board and the Liquor and Poker Machine Licensing Boards. An amendment is being moved to the Archives Bill to provide for charging for archival storage of certain records of Commonwealth business undertakings.
Conclusion

The timely and efficient manner in which the Government's decisions are being implemented reflects their widespread acceptance. The measures which comprise the Bill, together with many more being implemented administratively, are a significant step towards reducing the cost of government to the community and so contributing to economic growth and the well-being of all Australians. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Gietzelt) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX (ASSESSMENT AND RATES) AMENDMENT BILL

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill will give effect to some taxation measures recently announced by the Government. Included in the measures are the changes to a number of taxation concessions referred to by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) on 30 April 1981 when he spoke in another place about decisions made following our Review of Commonwealth Functions. Another matter covered is the income tax rebate for contributions for basic health insurance. Also dealt with is the announcement on 29 April 1981 that there is to be half-indexation of personal income tax for 1981-82, and that that year is to be the last in which the system of tax indexation will apply. I turn to the details of each measure.
Reductions in Taxation Concessions

Mr President, the point has been made before, but it is appropriate that I mention it again now. It is that taxation concessions are, in a practical sense, as much a call on the Budget as are direct outlays. That is true even if the effect of a concession is only to delay the collection of tax. It follows that, when Government expenditures come under review, taxation concessions are among the things that have to be looked at.

An outcome of the examination made in the course of our Review of Commonwealth Functions was a decision to reduce the value of some income tax concessions. Among the concessions to be reduced are the 20 per cent loading on depreciation rates on plant, the investment allowance and the rebate of tax that is allowable to shareholders for capital subscribed to petroleum exploration and mining companies. Also to be affected are the immediate deduction allowable for the cost of converting oil-fired or liquefied petroleum gas-fired plant to operate from alternative energy fuels and the deductions that are allowable for capital expenditure incurred on the development or operation of a mine or oil field.

As indicated in a statement accompanying the Prime Minister's speech on 30 April, the reduced level of each concession will generally apply in respect of expenditure incurred by a taxpayer after that day. However, expenditure incurred after 30 April 1981 under a contract entered into earlier, or in respect of work carried out by the taxpayer which was commenced earlier, will continue to qualify for the present levels of concession. The deduction for capital costs incurred by a taxpayer in converting oil-fired or LPG-fired plant to use alternative energy sources is to be allowable in equal instalments over 2 income years instead of being wholly deductible in the year in which the expenditure is made.

The special loading on depreciation rates for plant is to be reduced from 20 per cent to 18 per cent. The investment allowance deduction of 20 per cent is to be reduced to 18 per cent, with corresponding adjustments to the shading-in rates for plant costing less than $976. Deductions for capital expenditure incurred in the development or operation of a mining property or an oil or natural gas field are to be calculated, where appropriate, by reference to a maximum statutory life of the mine or field of six years, instead of five years. Finally, the rebate of tax available in respect of moneys paid on shares in petroleum exploration and mining companies, or to certain interposed companies, is to be reduced from 30 per cent to 27 per cent of the moneys so paid. The reduced rebate will in general apply to moneys paid by a taxpayer after 30 April 1981, but moneys paid subsequently in respect of calls made on or before 30 April 1981 on shares owned by the taxpayer at that date will retain eligibility for the present level of rebate.
Income Tax Rebate for Cost of Basic Health Insurance

As foreshadowed on 29 April 1981 by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar), an income tax rebate is to be allowed for contributions paid by a taxpayer for basic hospital insurance or basic medical insurance cover. The rebate is, of course, part of the Government's new health arrangements. The new rebate will be available at the rate of 32 cents in the dollar-equivalent to the standard rate of tax-for contributions paid for basic medical or basic hospital insurance cover for the taxpayer, the spouse of the taxpayer and any children of the taxpayer or his or her spouse. It will apply to eligible contributions made on or after 1 July 1981 in respect of cover from then on.

This new rebate is to be quite separate from the general concessional rebate that covers various classes of private expenditure, including payments for medical and hospital expenses. Because of this a person may receive the new rebate even if he or she is not entitled to the general rebate. This means that tax savings from this concession will not depend on a taxpayer's total rebatable expenditure being more than $1,590.
Tax Indexation

The Treasurer announced on 29 April that half tax indexation would apply for 1981-82, as indicated by the Prime Minister in the policy speech of 5 September 1980. This Bill will give effect to that announcement. The benefits to individual taxpayers from the tax reductions proposed by these amendments are significant. In total, they will amount to some $500m in respect of the 1981-82 year. In line with the practice of previous years, the indexation adjustment is based on the increase of the average consumer price index for the four quarters ended March 1981 over the average from the four quarters ended March 1980. This was 9.9 per cent. The law provides for a discounting of this percentage for the effects of the Government's oil pricing policy and the health care financing arrangements announced on 24 May 1979.

The discounting produces a net increase of 7.6 per cent. On this basis, half-indexation means adjustment of the personal rate scale, and dependent and related rebates, by 3.8 per cent-that is, a half-indexation factor of 1.038. Indexation of this order will have the effect that the tax threshold will change from $4,041 for 1980-81 to $4,195 for 1981-82. Subject to the first $4,195 of taxable income being tax-free, the standard rate of 32 per cent will apply to incomes up to $17,894 instead of $17,239. The 46 per cent rate will thus not apply until taxable income exceeds $17,894. The maximum rate-60 per cent-will first apply at $35,789, instead of at $34,479 as at present.

The increases in dependant and associated rebates due to indexation will mean, for example, that the maximum allowance for a spouse will rise from $800 to $830, and for a sole parent from $559 to $580. When allowance is made for these changes in both the rate scale and rebates, the tax free income for a person with a dependent spouse will rise from $6,541 in 1980-81 to $6,788 in 1981-82, and for a sole parent from $5,787 to $6,007. The tax reductions will be reflected in reduced pay-as-you-earn tax deductions from 1 July 1981.
With the concurrence of honourable senators, I incorporate in Hansard a number of tables showing the effect of the tax scale and rebate changes on tax payable for 1981-82.

The tables how, for example, that a taxpayer on the standard rate of 32 per cent, and having a dependent spouse, will be $1.50 a week better off as a result of the changes. As the Treasurer indicated in his statement on 29 April 1981, the Government has decided that discretionary adjustments to the taxation rate scale and rebates are preferable to the existing tax indexation arrangements. This Bill will therefore delete from the law-as no longer necessary-the provisions under which the present system of indexation operates. In future the Government will pursue on a discretionary basis-and usually in a Budget context-its policy of reducing taxation where circumstances make it appropriate and responsible to do so. The Bill is explained in detail in an explanatory memorandum that is being circulated to honourable senators, and I do not think that I need say more at this stage. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the House of Representatives acquainting the Senate that, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Accounts Committee Act 1951, Mrs Kelly, a member of the House of Representatives, has been appointed a member of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in the place of Mr Beazley, discharged.
Motion (by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not seek to delay the Senate unduly. However, given the difficulties with the hours we are sitting at the moment, one must necessarily choose the most appropriate occasion. I wish to raise a matter relating to the recent revision of medical benefits. I have received a letter from some constituents, whose names I will not reveal for obvious reasons, in relation to the change in medical benefits payable for artificial insemination by donor, a procedure normally known as AID. These people, who are residents of Queensland, find it necessary, by virtue of Queensland laws, to travel interstate for this form of medical treatment as AID is not available in Queensland. Recently they received a communication from the Infertility Clinic, Medical Research Centre, Prince Henry's Hospital, advising them that there had been some changes to the medical benefits available for the treatment that is currently undertaken for AID. I seek leave to incorporate this letter in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-

A very recent (mid-May) decision of the Medical Benefits Schedule Revision Committee of the Commonwealth Department of Health will bring about a major change in health insurance fund payments for artificial insemination, using donor semen. The current charge for a first insemination is $70.40 (under items 2112, 963, 2216 and 1859) and for subsequent inseminations is $52.40 (items 2112, 963 and 1859). From June 1st, 1981, the above Committee has ruled that the only item number under which a benefit is payable will be 2105 ($9.00) with the exception of the first insemination when item 2216 may also be payable ($18.00). Thus, the net amount payable by patients using the service will be $43.00 for each insemination. Usually, three to four inseminations are made in each cycle and the average number of cycles to achieve a pregnancy is three, making a total of nine to twelve inseminations and a net average cost of $387.00 to $516.00 (none of it claimable from health insurance funds). Individual patients may of course be liable for smaller or larger charges.
We feel that this Commonwealth Department of Health decision is highly regrettable. We wish to provide you with the following information and to make certain suggestions.

1. We wish to continue to offer this service for couples unable to achieve pregnancy by other means, who elect to have this form of treatment-we recognise that such treatment is not acceptable to some couples, but is keenly sought by others.

2. We can continue the service only if the charges remain similar to those currently made, as no other funds are available to pay the staff required to provide the service, nor is there any realistic possibility of such funds being made available by the State Health Commission.

3. We intend to suspend the service as from the 1st of June, 1981, until at least July the 1st, i.e. for one month, in order to bring the gravity of the situation to your attention and to take stock of the steps that we might be able to take to improve it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That letter outlines what becomes a very substantial change in the cost position of people in this position undertaking this course. This couple have been travelling to Melbourne for this treatment for some time now. From the details they have given to me in relation to the way in which they have undertaken this treatment, they obviously have tried to do it in the cheapest possible way in terms of travel to and from Melbourne and expenses incurred along the way. For example, they indicate that by travelling non-stop by car it costs an average of $145 each way for each trip. It is necessary for these trips to be made over a period of, apparently, at least 3 months for some chance of the treatment to be successful. Even doing this by the cheapest possible means it is costing them over $1,000 after Medibank Private refunds. I emphasise that this is done in the cheapest possible way with no overnight accommodation during trips between Brisbane and Melbourne, a distance of more than 1,000 miles.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of an unfortunate cancer affliction, AID is the only option that this couple have to have children. They make the point that it seems to them that with this very particular infertility problem they have been singled out compared with patients with other medical problems. I think we would all agree that that is a serious medical problem and, for people in that position, a heartrending one and one which should be treated with the greatest possible degree of sensitivity. They believe it is the only successful alternative they have, given the husband's sterility. I do not seek to delay the Senate at all unduly tonight. I have attempted to state this matter as briefly as I can. I have given Senator Peter Baume, the Minister representing the Minister for Health, some information about it in advance. I would like to ask the Minister whether the situation of people such as these can be taken into consideration and whether, with this dramatic change in medical benefits which amounts now, as I understand it, to only the benefit of a consultation fee payable for each treatment, the Government might consider the very particular effect that this change in medical benefits can have on individuals in this situation.

I know it is not a function of medical benefits that a government should have to judge the cost of treatment of a couple living in a suburb of Melbourne versus a couple living some thousands of miles distant but who must necessarily travel to Melbourne for their treatment. This couple clearly were prepared to undertake the cost of the travel and the additional cost above the medical benefits that they held. The change in medical benefits payable has put them in an impossible position, as I am sure it has put quite a number of people. I seek the Minister's illumination of the issue, if possible, and at least an undertaking that the Government may consider the effect of this decision and its social and personal ramifications, which are very great and real indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators are only too well aware that, whilst the Standing Orders and other rules of this place are intended to enable the full, free and fair debate of matters of concern to the people we represent, it is not unknown to use the rules available to us for less high-minded purposes. In this context, I draw attention to what I see as the rationale behind the notice of motion given to the Senate this morning by Senator Ryan for the disallowance of the Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance. I hasten to add that I do not dispute her right to give it. I do not dispute that she has followed the forms of the Senate and acted within the forms available under a statute of Parliament. Further, I am not concerned with the subject matter of the notice, for this is relevant to the point I wish to make.

SPEECH.PARA: My concern lies rather with the use of an important and precious right of a private senator as a device to hold over to the next sittings a matter which, in my view, should have been determined within the Senate as it is presently constituted. The matter which is the subject of this notice of motion first arose during this period of sittings. The issues were debated twice. The first time was on a motion for the adjournment of the Senate and the second time was on a substantive motion to take note of a statement made in this place on behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. It appears to me that propriety demands that any action sought as a result of Senate consideration should similarly be determined by the present composition of the Senate. A device is available to the Government to bring forward the subject for debate during the present sitting period. In turn, and possibly in accordance with the ways of politics, a countervailing device may become available to thwart that stratagem, and so on ad infinitum. The Government parties considered this matter and determined not to continue that course commenced by Senator Ryan this morning.

The point I make in this adjournment debate is that, based on an assumption-perhaps valid, I do not know-that the numbers will be there after July and conversely, that the numbers are not there at the moment, a matter which has been considered in this place already and, I might add, which has largely been overtaken by events, is deferred in the interests of politics until the next session.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That extraordinary statement from Senator Lewis must be replied to immediately. What a stunning piece of obdurate sour grapes even by Senator Lewis's own spectacular standards in that respect! He is complaining, simply, that the legislative initiative has been taken out of his and the Government's hands. What more deserving a case for taking out of the hands of the Government could this one be? The initiative has been hitherto in the Government's hands from day one. What a spectacularly insensitive performance this has been. How spectacularly insensitive to the civil liberties and rights of ordinary Australians has been the course of action so far undertaken by the Government, by the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) and by Government senators, including Senator Lewis. When one goes back to the beginning and looks to the circumstances in which the ordinance was originally promulgated, one sees it as a sneaking back stairs bit of Executive law making. It was done without reason, without foundation and, in fact, without precedent in law.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. With all due respect, Senator Evans is debating the subject matter of the notice. He is debating the ordinance which Senator Ryan has given notice to disallow. I was not talking about that at all. I was talking about the proprieties of the use of the Standing Orders of this place.

—I am talking exactly about the issue of propriety. Senator Lewis is interjecting, but I will not do him the honour, which he so contemptibly does not deserve, of having that nonsense read in the Hansard record. The point of order claims that I am not addressing myself to Senator Lewis's speech, if it can be so dignified, and that I am really discussing the substantive merits of the motion. Nothing could be further from the truth. The remarks of Senator Lewis went to the question of the propriety with which Senator Ryan had in fact acted in seeking to ensure further parliamentary consideration at a time and place of her own choosing. Nothing could be more relevant to assessing the proprieties of Senator Ryan's action than by looking by contrast to the impropriety of the Executive action and the action of Government senators which had preceded it. Perhaps, on that basis, I can proceed to continue with my remarks.
—There is no point of order. The honourable senator may proceed.

—I address myself briefly to the issues of impropriety which are also evident in the behaviour of the Government and of Government members and which has led up to this episode. The impropriety began, as I said, with a sneaking back stairs bit of Executive law making which was not based on any empirical evidence of a kind that is subsequently able to be justified or ever could be justified. It resulted in a situation of overkill in the performance, perhaps understandable when given the nature of the law they were dealing with, by the law enforcement officers of the Executive. This was followed up with a further bit of Executive impropriety in the insistence upon retaining the prosecutions which were manifestly unjustified to retain.

SPEECH.PARA: This has been followed by the further Executive impropriety of Mr Hodgman admitting, subsequently, that the ordinance had no legitimate foundation in principle, but he refused to withdraw the prosecutions. The Executive and Government misbehaviour and lack of propriety has further resulted in Government senators determining not to recommend to this chamber, notwithstanding the acknowledged breach of any reasonable standard of civilised civil liberties, that the ordinance be disallowed because they did not want to embarrass their particular Minister whom they knew to have made a fundamental error of judgment and to have misbehaved by reference to any reasonable standards of principle.

We have had a further demonstration tonight of the attitude of Government senators, one and all, and of their likely response if this matter did come forward into the chamber. When we add together the elements of that long litany of insensitivity, misbehaviour, and general reluctance to concede even the most fundamental standards of humanity and legal propriety in the way these people are being dealt with, the result of it all is that the course of action undertaken by Senator Ryan is no more than any responsible legislator would set in train to maximise the opportunity of a parliamentary disallowance of this indefensible Ordinance, to maximise the opportunity of the women who have been caught up and prosecuted and charged with an indefensible criminal proceeding. A situation will be created as a result of Senator Ryan's initiative whereby this Parliament can debate the matter in a calm, sane and rational atmosphere. So long as people such as the bucolic Senator Lewis and those who think and behave like him have the opportunity to express themselves in these terms. There is no prospect of justice being achieved in practice or of justice being seen to be done, or of the legislation coming out as it should, that is, removed from the statute book and not allowed to remain there in 1981. For all those reasons, it is a perfectly defensible course of action that has been set in train by Senator Ryan. It is a perfectly understandable reaction that Senator Ryan, or any reasonable legislator or any reasonable citizen witnessing the procedures of this chamber, and particularly the procedures tonight, would wish to create a situation whereby the question of the disallowance will be dealt with in a proper, calm and rational atmosphere, at some distance from the particular events which have given rise to the circumstances tonight.

The speech of Senator Lewis, and I have chosen to ignore every one of his interjections because they ought not ever to be dignified in print in Hansard by being acknowledged, can only be described in the way I began by describing it, that is, as an exercise in the worst possible kind of sour grapes and a disgraceful performance on the part of any legislator who wants to claim the respect of his colleagues in this chamber, let alone of any member of the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not hold the Senate for long. I think I should respond to Senator Martin's comments on the question of artificial insemination and the case she raised of the constituent from Brisbane whose costs will be increased by a recent administrative decision. The Senate may care to reflect upon the fact that the question is really one about rebates for services, not about fees. It is really a question of charges, not of costs incurred in the medical sense. The letter the honourable senator produced sets out the situation in terms of medical benefit changes. It does set out a regrettable situation with the doctors involved in that they have indicated that they are going to withdraw their services for a month as some kind of protest against the changes. I think that for any professional group that is unfortunate. That part of the letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: We intend to suspend the service as from the 1st of June, 1981, until at least July the 1st, i.e. for one month, in order to bring the gravity of the situation to your attention . . .

In other words, we have here a group of people who are concerned about changes in their rebates. The only persons who will suffer from their actions will be the patients, and I am a little disappointed about that. As a result of discussions by the Medical Benefits Schedule Revision Committee a ruling was given that in future artificial insemination using donor bank semen would attract the following benefits: Firstly, a consultation benefit for consultation by the medical practitioner for the woman; secondly, for each insemination by a medical practitioner, a benefit at the rate applicable to a medical consultation; and thirdly, for each mucus test performed, the benefit that would be appropriate.

The Committee to which I have referred consists of officers of the Department of Health and representatives of the Australian Medical Association. In other words, the medical profession is directly represented on the Committee in helping to work out the rebates to apply to the appropriate schedule fees. Previously the Department had given a ruling that, in respect of artificial insemination from specific donor to specific recipient, benefit was payable for the processing and freezing of the donor semen. Recently hospital units have been using this ruling for artificial insemination employing donor bank semen. The honourable senator will realise the difference between bank semen and the specific recipient-specific donor procedure.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first one is AAH?

—No, AAH refers to the husband, but it could relate to any specific donor. The itemisation in the medical benefits schedule relates to each specific medical service. That is the way in which medical benefit rebates are constructed. In other areas where there is a question of using a substance-for instance, the processing of blood, of corneas or of bone, which do not relate to a specific medical service, no benfit is attracted. It was considered that the processing of semen should be regarded similarly. Therefore, the ruling was given that in future this processing would not attact benefits. That was the basis on which the ruling was given. The items in the schedule cover professional services rendered by medical practitioners. It is considered that the processing of blood, semen and so on is basically a technical procedure and therefore does not come within the scope of these particular forms of medical benefit. The honourable senator asked whether I would refer the situation to my colleague in view of the changes in cost to the constituents who have written to her. I will certainly refer it to my colleague and ask him to give it such further consideration as he is able.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 31 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Did the Bureau of Transport Economics, in 1979, find that by comparison with other airline systems in the world 'the operating cost per unit of output of TAA and Ansett is particularly high'; if so, what has been done since that finding to improve the two airlines' efficiency.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The quote referred to by the honourable senator comes from Appendix A6.1 of the Domestic Air Transport Policy Review which was published in 1978. In the summary of that Appendix (p. 7) it was also stated that '. . . it should be pointed out that these findings are not necessarily an indication that the airlines themselves are poorly managed or operated. . . . The appropriate conclusion to be drawn from this study is that Australia's major airline system is not technically efficient by world standards.'

However, the nature of Australia's domestic air services network, covering an area similar in size to the USA but with a population of only 14 million concentrated mainly on the south-eastern coast seriously affects any comparisons of technical efficiency.
The general thrust of the Government's domestic aviation policy since the Review has been to increase competition. The first steps taken were to re-negotiate the Airlines Agreement.

The airlines too, have taken decisions which will increase the level of competitiveness in the industry. The most significant decision has been to acquire different front line aircraft types with TAA selecting the Airbus A300B and Ansett obtaining a range of Boeing aircraft with the B737 to be introduced in June.

In May 1980, the Government established the Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares which presented its Report on 16 February 1981. It was then tabled in Parliament on 25 February. The Government adopted the principles contained in its recommendations of a cost based, nationally consistent approach to air fares by the use of an air fare formula comprising a flagfall and a distance rate for the national jet network. The Government also endorsed the Inquiry's view that as wide a range of discount fares as possible be provided without increasing the burden on the full fare paying passenger.

Statements have been made in the Parliament recently confirming the Government's intention to establish TAA as a public company, and establish an independent fare committee to determine all domestic air fares. An inquiry into deregulation has also been announced which is expected to report within four or five years. All these initiatives are evidence of the Government's commitment to maintain a safe and efficient airline system.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 26 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Will a ban be immediately placed on the export of all Australian wildlife species to Rio de Janeiro in view of the answer received from the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs disclosing that the Rio de Janeiro zoo authorities showed lamentable judgement in their custody of four grey kangaroos who died in captivity.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs has supplied the following answer in response to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Before any further applications to export Australian fauna to the Rio de Janeiro Zoological Garden are approved, the zoo will be re-assessed to determine whether it has the necessary expertise and facilities to satisfactorily care for Australian fauna.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the financial position of community pharmacists deteriorated markedly since 1977-78 when the last increase in dispensing fees became effective, and has the average gross income per pharmacy from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme risen by only 3.4 per cent in 1979-80 relative to 1977-78, compared with an 18 per cent increase in average weekly earnings during the same period; if so, has the Government representative on the Joint Committee on Pharmaceutical Benefits Pricing Arrangements and/or the proposed Pharmacy Fees Tribunal, been instructed to press for an urgent increase in the remuneration for dispensing Pharmaceutical Benefits prescriptions from $1.31 to $1.65 per prescription; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The last increase in the dispensing fee was 5c, effective from 1 July 1977 and resulted from a determination made by the Chairman of the Joint Committee on Pharmaceutical Benefits Pricing Arrangements dated 18 September 1978.
I am unable to comment on movements in average gross income per pharmacy because the latest factual information relates to the financial year 1977-78.

The Pharmacy Guild of Australia had a proposal before the Joint Committee for a 34c per prescription increase prior to the constitution of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal. The Tribunal has replaced the Joint Committee as the appropriate authority to consider remuneration to chemists for dispensing of pharmaceutical benefits. There are no Government representatives on the Tribunal.

The Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal is required to conduct its first enquiry and bring down its findings by 1 July 1981 but the level of increase, if any will be a matter for the Tribunal. The Government will ensure that all the relevant facts available to it are placed before the Tribunal.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Neal Sen L.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Health aware of an article in the Bulletin of 12 May 1981 which states that the Commonwealth Department of Health has allowed the practice of transcendental meditation to be claimed for medical benefits.
(2) Is this report accurate.
(3) Have United States of America courts refused transcendental meditation medical status.
(4) What is the basis for the Department of Health's support for transcendental meditation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) No. Medical benefits are not payable for transcendental meditation (TM) as such. However if TM was prescribed as a relaxation technique by a medical practitioner during the course of a professional attendance, benefits would be payable for that attendance under the appropriate consultation item. In this situation the benefits are payable on the grounds that there is a physical attendance by a legally qualified medical practitioner upon the patient.
(3) I am not aware of the views of courts in the United States of America concerning TM.

(4) The fact that benefits are payable for an attendance at which TM is prescribed should not be construed as an indication of support for the practice. As medical benefits are attracted for consultations by legally qualified medical practitioners, it would be neither practical nor desirable to attempt to restrict the way in which doctors choose to conduct their consultations. I might also mention that a request for a specific Medical Benefits Schedule item for TM was rejected.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Nature Conservation Advisory Committee

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) As a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, is the Australian Capital Territory Nature Conservation Advisory Committee to be abolished.
(2) What were the functions of that institution.
(3) Was it performing its functions inadequately in any way, and, if so, in what way was it inadequate.
(4) What action is proposed to take over the functions originally performed by the Australian Capital Territory Nature Conservation Advisory Committee.
(5) As a result of the action, what Government services can be expected to be affected, and in what way will they be affected.

(6) As a result of the action will any information which was available in the past not be available; if so, what is the nature of that information, and in what ways has it proved useful when it was available.

(7) As a result of the Review will any informed advice or co-ordinating capacity which was available in the past not be available; if so, what is the nature of that informed advice or co-ordinating capacity, and in what ways has it proved useful when it was available.
(8) What is the estimated saving in abolishing the Australian Capital Territory Nature Conservation Advisory Committee.
(9) What is the estimated short and long term cost of not having the services of the Australian Capital Territory Nature Conservation Advisory Committee available to the Government and the community.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Capital Territory has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The Committee was set up in the early 1960s to advise the Department in regard to development of the Tidbinbilla Nature Reserve. It has since advised the Department on a number of other conservation issues.
(4) The Department will seek advice and assistance from non-Government sources as required.
(5) No Government services will be affected.
(6) No significant difference in the available information is anticipated.
(7) No significant difference in the informed advice or co-ordinating capacity is anticipated.
(8) There are no significant savings as fees were not paid to Committee members.
(9) No short term or long term costs to the Government or the community can be indentified.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Ansett Airlines of Australia: Operating Profit

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 March 1981 (Hansard, page 485), Senator Button asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, a question without notice, concerning the financial statements of Ansett Airlines of Australia tabled in the Senate on 10 March 1981.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Clause 11 of the Airlines Agreement Act 1972 requires that the financial information in respect of that part of the business of Ansett Transport Industries Limited, and of its subsidiary companies, relating to the operation of air services, that is to be furnished to the Minister for Transport for presentation to the Parliament, shall be compiled from the accounts of the Company that have been audited as required under the provisions of the Companies Act 1961 of the State of Victoria as amended from time to time.

The annual Financial Report of Ansett Transport Industries Limited in respect of the operation of air services for the year ended 28 June 1980, tabled in the Senate on 10 March 1981, includes certification by two directors that the Balance Sheet and Profit and Loss Statement included therein have been compiled from the accounts of the Company that have been audited as required under the provisions of the Companies Act 1961 of the State of Victoria as amended.
Company tax is levied at the rate of 46 per cent, not 47 1/2 per cent.
Ansett has reported a total profit from airline activities, after allowing for non-operating items, of $14.669m.

The amount set aside for tax does not indicate that the real profit before tax would be in the vicinity of $43m. Operating profit before tax was $28.326m as stated in the Company's Profit and Loss Statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1206) Senator Hearn asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, a question, without notice, concerning the possible effects in Tasmania of a move toward the greater use of private contractors in road building.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided me with the following information in answer to the honourable senator's questions:

The Roads Grants Bill 1981, which was introduced into Parliament recently by the Minister for Transport, provides that Commonwealth grants for construction works on National Roads (i.e. National Highways and declared Developmental Road projects) will be conditional upon tenders being called and dealt with in accordance with approved arrangements.

The Government's objective is to ensure that maximum value is obtained from its very substantial outlays on National Roads which are, of course, eligible for full Commonwealth funding. The Government considers that only by the creation of a competitive environment can it be sure that this objective will be achieved.

It is not the Government's intention to exclude State Road Authorities and Local Authorities from carrying out National Road construction works. It has therefore been decided that State and Local Government Authorities will be free to bid for the works in competition with private contractors. Given the road construction experience which these authorities have gained over the years they should be in a good position to compete for such works.

The legislation will not require National Roads maintenance works to be put out to tender. Moreover, the tender requirement will not apply to any project in the Arterial Roads and Local Roads categories. It will be entirely a matter for State and Local Government Authorities to decide the method of carrying out the relevant works (i.e. by contract or day labour).

As some 90 per cent of total roads expenditure is on Arterial and Local Roads, considerable scope exists for the continued employment of State and Local Government day labour forces on these roads if they prove to be unsuccessful in competing with contractors for particular works on National Roads.

The use of contractors on roads is not a new concept and they are already widely used in most States and Territories. Overall, direct payments to the private sector account for between 50 and 70 per cent of the total value of works carried out on National Highways in most States.

The Minister for Transport is aware that most roadworks in Tasmania are carried out by the Department of Main Roads and that a large day labour force based at Ulverstone is currently engaged on National Highway works. However, no major construction firms are at present based in the State and it should not be assumed that jobs would necessarily be lost if private contractors from interstate were successful in winning tenders for works on National Roads. For example Leighton-Candac-a Sydney-based firm-is constructing the Bowen Bridge. Apart from a small management team, the workforce engaged on the bridge was recruited from within Tasmania.
