TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1454) Senator Cavanagh asked me as the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, a question, without notice, concerning rail fare concessions.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Commonwealth Government announced that fringe benefits would be extended to sickness beneficiaries. However, there are considerable administrative problems involved in extending transport concessions to these beneficiaries. Indications are that the States are not prepared to extend transport concessions to sickness beneficiaries on the services operated by them, including Adelaide metropolitan services. Agreement is also required with the State systems before the concession can be granted on the majority of services operated by the Australian National Railways Commission which are over interstate routes involving State railways. The Government is currently examining the situation in the light of these difficulties.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1459) Senator MacGibbon asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, a question, without notice, concerning requirements for cabin attendants in relation to airline safety requirements.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The requirement for cabin attendants is primarily related to passenger safety considerations.
An Air Navigation Order promulgated by the Department of Transport defines these safety requirements as applicable to Australian airlines.
Providing the requirements for the training of cabin attendants are complied with and the minimum specified number is carried, the Department of Transport's safety requirements are met.

Frequently airlines elect to carry more cabin attendants than is required by safety regulation. The duties of these additional staff are related to the provision of cabin services and as such are a matter for the commercial judgment of the operator.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 May 1981 (Hansard, page 1573), Senator Lewis asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Transport, a question, without notice, regarding the Australian National Line's (ANL) 1979-80 financial results and the implications of recent industrial action taken by maritime unions against ANL in support of claims for a two crew roster system on Australian registered ships.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
I am aware of the Australian National Line (ANL) loss position, and the recent industrial action of the maritime unions, as referred to by the honourable senator.
The introduction of the two crew system would increase ANL's costs by up to some $5m a year. As ANL is required to operate along commercial lines this increased cost would need to be recovered.

The coasting trade is one aspect being presently examined by the joint shipowners/unions committee on the revitalisation of Australian shipping. Any recommendations which arise from that forum regarding the level of regulation will be carefully considered by Government.
The Government is not giving consideration to selling the assets of the Australian Shipping Commission.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 May 1981 (Hansard, page 1574) Senator Hearn asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Transport, a question, without notice, concerning the possibility of introducing a 50 per cent discount on the freight rate for carrying Tasmanian pensioners' vehicles on the Empress of Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Commonwealth Government currently subsidises the losses incurred by the Empress of Australia by an amount up to $2.3m a year. It has also recently agreed to subsidise air fares to and from Tasmania.

ANL already offers substantial discounts on rates for accompanied private vehicles carried on Empress of Australia and private vehicles carried on all ANL vessels across Bass Strait under the Air Transfer Scheme. In these circumstances, further reduction of the vehicle rates could not be justified.
